The NABJ's website says the event is a conference for journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\nABC7 Chicago is now streaming 24/7. Click here to watch\n\nTrump's campaign and NABJ said he will participate in a Q&A with political journalists in front of an audience of convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community. It will happen at noon Wednesday.\n\nABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott will moderate the event with The Faulkner Focus Anchor Harris Faulkner, who is also a co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor Political Reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in this year's convention, and her confirmation is pending.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public, but it will be live-streamed via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the organization said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump will then head to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania for a rally.\n\nLast week, Trump also revealed plans to return to Butler, Pennsylvania for the first time since his attempted assassination. {"uri": "8250174647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "07:46:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T07:46:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T07:45:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/trump-to-attend-national-association-of-black-journalists-convention-in-chicago/", "title": "Trump to attend National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Chicago", "body": "Trump to attend National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Chicago\n\nFormer President Trump will visit Chicago, Illinois, for the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) Convention, his campaign announced Monday.\n\nThe convention will be held at the Hilton Chicago at 720 South Michigan Avenue and Trump will participate during its opening day on Wednesday, July 31, at noon CST.\n\nThe NABJ said on its website that the convention is a conference for journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\n\"This year's convention in the Windy City will attract industry leaders, innovators, and influencers in journalism, media, technology, business, government, community service, health, arts, entertainment, academia, and more,\" the website said.\n\nTrump will take part in a Q&A with political journalists in front of an audience of registered convention spectators. The discussion will focus on the most pressing issues facing the black community, the Trump campaign and the NABJ said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nThe event will be moderated by anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News Harris Faulkner, ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba.\n\n\"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history by implementing America First policies on the economy, immigration, energy, law and order, and foreign policy,\" the Trump campaign claimed in a press release.\n\n\"Historic rates of Black voters now support President Trump, and the reason is simple: Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has, including landmark unemployment rates for Black Americans, increased median income for Black households, historic permanent funding for HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), comprehensive bipartisan criminal justice reform, and nearly $50 billion in funds to revitalize Opportunity Zones,\" his campaign continued.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic Party's presumptive presidential nominee, was also invited to participate in the convention, but she has not confirmed her attendance.\n\nLemon said the NABJ invites presidential nominees to the convention in each presidential election year.\n\nFormer Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton attended NABJ conventions in the past, either as presidents or presidential candidates.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public and will be The NABJ's website says the event is a conference for journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\nTrump's campaign and NABJ said he will participate in a Q&A with political journalists in front of an audience of convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community. It will happen at noon Wednesday.\n\nABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott will moderate the event with The Faulkner Focus Anchor Harris Faulkner, who is also a co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor Political Reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in this year's convention, and her confirmation is pending.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public, but it will be live-streamed via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the organization said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump will then head to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania for a rally.\n\nLast week, Trump also revealed plans to return to Butler, Pennsylvania for the first time since his attempted assassination. {"uri": "8251620661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:40:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:40:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:36:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-invite-black-journalist-convention-022103993.html", "title": "Trump invite to Black journalist convention sparks a backlash", "body": "A planned appearance by Donald Trump at a convention of Black journalists has prompted an intense backlash, with members of the organization saying the invitation is inappropriate and should be rescinded.\n\nMembers of the National Association of Black Journalists erupted in protest Tuesday following the announcement that Trump would attend a Q&A at the convention this week in Chicago. A co-chair of the event, Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah, announced she would step down.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah said in a post on X. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nThe reaction from NABJ members underscored the divisiveness of the former president as both he and the likely Democratic nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, seek the support of Black voters with less than 100 days until the November election.\n\nThe NABJ announced Monday that the former president would take part in a special conversation to discuss \"the most pressing issues facing the Black community\" with moderators Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, a Fox News anchor; and reporter Kadia Goba of Semafor.\n\nThe organization, which has hosted presidential hopefuls in the past, does not endorse political candidates.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement announcing the Q&A.\n\nThe session would give members an opportunity \"to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" he added.\n\nTrump's campaign used the announcement to tout the Republican nominee's record, writing he's \"the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one\" and linking to polling showing Trump's popularity growing among Black men.\n\nThe chair of the NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, Femi Redwood, said on X she was \"disturbed\" to not be included in discussions about whether to invite Trump, citing \"damage he has caused Black queer and trans people.\"\n\nCarron J. Phillips, a 2019 and 2020 NABJ award winner who described the convention as \"the only safe haven\" for Black journalists, wrote on X that Trump's presence made the space unsafe and called it \"single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history.\"\n\nSome members pointed to past Trump statements about Black journalists, including April Ryan, White House Correspondent for The Grio, who the former president once called \"very nasty\" and a \"loser.\" Ryan, the 2017 NABJ Journalist of the Year, said on X that the event featuring Trump was \"a slap in the face.\"\n\nDr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the National Newspaper Publishers Association President and CEO, said in a statement he opposes Trump's scheduled appearance at the convention and urged NABJ leadership to withdraw the invitation.\n\nA Trump campaign spokesperson did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nSome Black journalists defended the invitation. Leroy Chapman Jr., editor in chief of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said on X that he was looking forward to the session and that \"we need to 'normalize'\" presidential candidates answering questions from journalists. Symone D. Sanders Townsend, a political commentator on MSNBC, echoed the sentiment: \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did.\"\n\nLemon said NABJ invites presidential candidates to the convention every year and that the organization had engaged in conversations with both Trump and President Joe Biden for over a month. Biden had planned to attend before he dropped out of the race, and Harris is unable to speak in person because of other commitments, said a person familiar with her plans who was granted anonymity to talk about scheduling matters.\n\nSeveral Chicago-based groups -- including some that marched at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee and plan to do the same at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month -- announced an emergency action to protest Trump's appearance at the convention.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": Here's why and how to watch", "body": "Former president Donald Trump will be a guest Wednesday in Chicago as part of the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention and career fair.\n\nTrump will participate in a conversation and Q&A with journalists in front of registered convention attendees.\n\nModerators for the event are: Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of \"Outnumbered\" on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, was invited to this year's NABJ convention. It is unclear if she will be able to attend.\n\nThe event will begin at 12 p.m. central time and is not open to the public. It will be live-streamed on the NABJ YouTube page and the NABJ Facebook page.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists is a non-profit educational and professional organization of more than 4,000 Black journalists, educators, students and media professionals headquartered in College Park, Maryland.\n\nThe NABJ focuses on providing innovative, quality programs and services to its members. It advocates for Black journalists and media professionals worldwide. By serving and participating in national and global student and professional chapters, many NABJ members support and directly engage with Black media professionals in their local communities.\n\nThe annual NABJ Convention and Career Fair is a multi-day conference for career development, networking, innovation and education. Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have attended NABJ conventions either as presidents or presidential candidates.\n\nThis year's convention will take place July 31 to Aug. 4 at the Hilton Chicago, 720 S. Michigan Ave.\n\nMore: Donald Trump to speak at Black journalists convention in Chicago, draws criticism\n\nNABJ's confirmation that Trump will attend the convention quickly drew ire on social media.\n\nNABJ member Carron J. Phillips, a graduate student at S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communication in Syracuse, N.Y., bluntly panned the decision to grant the former president a platform as \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history.\" CBS sports reporter Ashley Nicole Moss posted on X, formerly Twitter, that she found NABJ's choice \"extremely disappointing.\"\n\nWhite House correspondent April Ryan emphasized Trump's reported history of attacks on Black female journalists. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to ... Black women journalists,\" she added.\n\nNABJ president Ken Lemon defended the organization's choice to invite Trump, hailing it as an opportunity to hear from a former president on critical issues relevant to its members.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Lemon said.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], political journalists on the opening day of the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention & Career Fair.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump, the current Republican presidential nominee, will visit Chicago on Wednesday and attend the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention & Career Fair, the NABJ announced late Monday.\n\nTrump will participate in a conversation and question-and-answer session with political journalists \"before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" the association said in a news release.\n\nThe conversation will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in the news release. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nThe event won't be open to the public but will be livestreamed on the NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nDemocratic presidential candidate, Vice President Kamala Harris, was invited to participate as well, NABJ stated. "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://triblive.com/news/world/co-chair-of-black-journalists-convention-steps-down-after-trump-appearance-announced/", "title": "Co-chair of Black journalists' convention steps down after Trump appearance announced", "body": "Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally, Saturday, July 27, 2024, in St. Cloud, Minn.\n\nThe co-chair of the National Association of Black Journalists' 2024 convention in Chicago has resigned, following former President Donald Trump's announcement that he would attend the convention.\n\nKaren Attiah's announcement came via the social media platform X -- after Trump's announcement that he would attend the convention and participate in a Q&A session, Reuters reported.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" Karen Attiah wrote in the thread.\n\nThe session is closed to the public, according to NABJ, but it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, Reuters said.\n\nAccording to a statement from the NABJ, the session will \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" and it will be moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nFellow presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in this year's convention, the NABJ said -- and her confirmation is pending.\n\nIn the past, former presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have attended NABJ conventions either as presidents or presidential candidates, according to the NABJ.\n\nThe news of Trump's attendance at NABJ has elicited numerous mixed reactions from members of the media and the public on social media.\n\nJemele Hill, a contributing writer at The Atlantic and former ESPN host, said she didn't have a problem with the decision to host Trump under \"the right circumstances.\" She said she was unsure about this year's conditions.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" Hill wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. {"uri": "2024-07-438937336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:21:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.politico.com/news/2024/07/30/trump-invite-black-journalist-convention-backlash-00172016", "title": "Trump invite to Black journalist convention sparks a backlash", "body": "\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah said in a post on X. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nThe reaction from NABJ members underscored the divisiveness of the former president as both he and the likely Democratic nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, seek the support of Black voters with less than 100 days until the November election.\n\nThe NABJ announced Monday that the former president would take part in a special conversation to discuss \"the most pressing issues facing the Black community\" with moderators Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, a Fox News anchor; and reporter Kadia Goba of Semafor.\n\nThe organization, which has hosted presidential hopefuls in the past, does not endorse political candidates.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement announcing the Q&A.\n\nThe session would give members an opportunity \"to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" he added.\n\nTrump's campaign used the announcement to tout the Republican nominee's record, writing he's \"the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one\" and linking to polling showing Trump's popularity growing among Black men.\n\nThe chair of the NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, Femi Redwood, said on X she was \"disturbed\" to not be included in discussions about whether to invite Trump, citing \"damage he has caused Black queer and trans people.\"\n\nCarron J. Phillips, a 2019 and 2020 NABJ award winner who described the convention as \"the only safe haven\" for Black journalists, wrote on X that Trump's presence made the space unsafe and called it \"single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history.\"\n\nSome members pointed to past Trump statements about Black journalists, including April Ryan, White House Correspondent for The Grio, who the former president once called \"very nasty\" and a \"loser.\" Ryan, the 2017 NABJ Journalist of the Year, said on X that the event featuring Trump was \"a slap in the face.\"\n\nDr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the National Newspaper Publishers Association President and CEO, said in a statement he opposes Trump's scheduled appearance at the convention and urged NABJ leadership to withdraw the invitation.\n\nA Trump campaign spokesperson did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nSome Black journalists defended the invitation. Leroy Chapman Jr., editor in chief of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said on X that he was looking forward to the session and that \"we need to 'normalize'\" presidential candidates answering questions from journalists. Symone D. Sanders Townsend, a political commentator on MSNBC, echoed the sentiment: \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did.\"\n\nLemon said NABJ invites presidential candidates to the convention every year and that the organization had engaged in conversations with both Trump and President Joe Biden for over a month. Biden had planned to attend before he dropped out of the race, and Harris is unable to speak in person because of other commitments, said a person familiar with her plans who was granted anonymity to talk about scheduling matters.\n\nSeveral Chicago-based groups -- including some that marched at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee and plan to do the same at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month -- announced an emergency action to protest Trump's appearance at the convention.", "source": {"uri": "politico.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "POLITICO"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Association of Black "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Holidays/Thanksgiving", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Holidays/Thanksgiving", "wgt": "https://www.politico.com/dims4/default/f5c1dfa/2147483647/legacy_thumbnail/1200x800%3E/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fstatic.politico.com%2F30%2F67%2F7fcd4934451095a8db78e2196e3b%2Felection-2024-trump-76142.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9774346", "eventUri": "eng-9774346", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252357761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:33:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:33:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.poynter.org/commentary/2024/nabj-donald-trump-chicago-black-journalists-harris-faulkner/", "title": "Donald Trump and the major split among Black journalists - Poynter", "body": "Trump will participate in a Q&A at the National Association of Black Journalists convention today. His attendance has kicked up a hornet's nest.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists will have a special guest today at its convention in Chicago.\n\nDonald Trump.\n\nAnd just the announcement has kicked a hornet's nest of controversy.\n\nOn one hand, he is the former president of the United States and the Republican Party's nominee to be president again. Of course you should invite him, right? It's the chance to ask questions of someone who is running for president. You should want him there.\n\nThen again, this is a candidate who has openly criticized the press, has been disrespectful of Black female journalists and whose rhetoric has been accused by some of being racist. Why should -- and why would -- NABJ give him a platform?\n\nThat pretty much sums up the split going on among Black journalists from the moment it was announced Trump would sit down for a Q&A session moderated by Fox News' Harris Faulkner, Semafor's Kadia Goba and ABC News' Rachel Scott.\n\nWashington Post columnist Karen Attiah announced on social media Tuesday that she was stepping down as co-chair of NABJ. She wrote, \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nAttiah was far from alone, as social media was filled with anger and frustration over NABJ's decision to invite Trump.\n\nTheGrio's April Ryan, the NABJ journalist of the year in 2017 who covered (and often was on the receiving end of verbal attacks from) Trump when he was president, wrote on X, \"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact. To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025. I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nTiffany Walden, a co-founder and editor-in-chief of The TRiiBE, a digital platform that covers Black Chicago, told The Guardian's Adria R. Walker that NABJ's decision was \"irresponsible.\"\n\nIn a column for The TRiiBE, Tyler J. Davis wrote, \"NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated. People shouldn't be asked to choose between attending a useful session or a self-serving sideshow. They shouldn't be challenged to confront unsettling situations in an environment that is supposed to be welcoming for Black people. Uncomfortability and anxiety can be expected when the 'star' of the opening day has repeatedly belittled our profession and questioned our intentions.\"\n\nNABJ member and former Deadspin writer Carron J. Phillips tweeted, \"This is the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history. Whoever made this call is an idiot. And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nFemi Redwood, the chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, wrote on X, \"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him.\"\n\nRedwood added, \"I'm also disturbed that LGBTQ+ Task Force Leadership was not invited into conversations about hosting Trump considering the damage he has caused Black queer and trans people -- including those who are journalists and members of NABJ.\"\n\nThe Atlantic's Jemele Hill at first tweeted, \"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump,\" but later followed that up with, \"I'll say this, while I don't have a problem with Trump being at NABJ under the right circumstances because he's a presidential candidate, I don't know how 'right' these circumstances are. A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility. If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. Trump isn't worth that.\"\n\nPart of the criticism, too, was that a Fox News anchor (Faulkner) would help moderate an event involving a candidate that the network has often been sympathetic toward.\n\nThis, mind you, was just a fraction of the backlash over NABJ's decision to have Trump.\n\nYet there was a strong opposing view, too, from those who firmly believe Trump, or any presidential candidate, should be invited. After all, it's fairly common for NABJ to invite presidential candidates to its convention. Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton all attended in the past, and Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris was invited this year.\n\nRana Cash, executive editor of The Charlotte Observer, tweeted, \"It's the National Association of Black 'Journalists' -- journalists who are experts at their craft, highly qualified and critical thinkers. To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous.\"\n\nLeroy Chapman Jr., the editor-in-chief of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said in a post on X, \"Here is what we need to 'normalize' -- candidates for office standing before journalists, answering questions.\"\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, said in a statement, \"While N.A.B.J. does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nIn a video, Lemon said, \"This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground.\"\n\nMSNBC's Symone Sanders-Townsend, a former spokesperson for Kamala Harris, tweeted, \"Some of the best journalists in the country are members of NABJ. So, why wouldn't they interview Trump? He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions. NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions. That's happening Wednesday.\"\n\nNABJ conference co-chair Tia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said on social media that she helped \"make this call\" to invite Trump, and \"I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next president.\"\n\nAs I mentioned, Harris also was invited, but NABJ said her confirmation was \"pending.\" Before he had dropped out of the race, President Joe Biden had agreed to attend the conference. But Harris might not be able to attend because of a scheduling conflict with her campaign.\n\nThere will be plenty of coverage of Trump's session at today's NABJ convention. It will be livestreamed on the organization's YouTube and Facebook pages. It is scheduled for noon Central time.\n\nPoynter's PolitiFact will fact-check the event, and I'll link to that coverage later this week.\n\nA major shakeup is coming to CBS News.\n\nNorah O'Donnell will step down as anchor and managing editor of the \"CBS Evening News\" following the November election. She will remain with the network, doing big interviews and contributing to the \"CBS Evening News,\" \"60 Minutes\" and other CBS News platforms.\n\nAnd, in what might be the real stunning news here, don't expect one big name to replace her.\n\nFirst, the O'Donnell part of this. Puck's Dylan Byers broke the news, with O'Donnell telling him, \"The way our product is distributed is changing. How do we do those big interviews, that great storytelling, and share that in a different kind of way so it can reach a different kind of audience.\"\n\nByers wrote, \"Wendy McMahon, the president and C.E.O. of CBS News, told me that the network was focused on 'challenging the traditional model' in order to find ways to leverage O'Donnell across more platforms.\"\n\nStill, the anchor of the national evening news is one of the most coveted jobs in TV journalism. It's hard to imagine someone giving up that job willingly to do something else within the news division at the same network. But Variety's Brian Steinberg wrote, \"The new arrangement is understood to be part of a longer-term commitment that the anchor and CBS News are making to one another.\"\n\nByers described it as a \"Barbara Walter-ish role\" and that it came about after O'Donnell's prime-time interview with Pope Francis in May. O'Donnell told Byers that it was a \"real lightbulb moment.\" She tells Byers she already has a list of interviews she wants to do -- and they are interviews she can't necessarily do now because of her current role.\n\nO'Donnell took over as anchor and managing editor of the \"CBS Evening News\" in 2019. Before that, she was co-host of \"CBS This Morning\" for seven years.\n\nShe told Byers, \"For 12 years I've been connected to an anchor desk. It's been grueling; it's also been thrilling. But CBS is awesome for allowing me to do this.\"\n\nSo, from outward appearances, it does seem as if O'Donnell and CBS News are both good with the move. In a memo to staff, O'Donnell wrote, \"It's time to do something different.\" She added it was her decision.\n\nNow what? Who replaces O'Donnell? My initial thought would be someone such as Margaret Brennan, the superb moderator of \"Face the Nation.\" But don't count on it.\n\nByers reports McMahon will announce plans in the days ahead, adding, \"In light of the secular economic challenges facing the industry, however, O'Donnell is unlikely to be replaced by another high-paid, high-profile anchor. Indeed, the evening broadcast will likely transition to an ensemble cast with rotating anchors -- making CBS the first network to relinquish the half-century-plus format of a singular, expensive anchor in the chair, signaling another retreat from the paradigm.\"\n\nIf true, that is a seismic shift for a network whose past \"Evening News\" anchors included such legends as Walter Cronkite, Dan Rather and groundbreaking anchors such as Connie Chung and Katie Couric.\n\nO'Donnell did boost ratings for the \"Evening News,\" but the 4.4 million average viewers per newscast in the latest quarter still lagged behind ABC's \"World News Tonight\" and the \"NBC Nightly News.\" During the week of July 15-21, ABC's \"World News Tonight\" averaged 6.8 million viewers, the \"NBC Nightly News\" had 5.5 million and the \"CBS Evening News\" had 4 million, according to Nielsen.\n\nThe Academy Awards are looking for a new host.\n\nJimmy Kimmel, who has hosted four times before (and done an excellent job, if you ask me), has told the academy that he is not interested in hosting in 2025. That's also according to Puck's Dylan Byers.\n\nThe news is disappointing. As Byers wrote, \"When it comes to the Oscars, Jimmy Kimmel is well on his way to Bob Hope/Johnny Carson/Billy Crystal territory: reliable, familiar, always great, Disney-approved, and a nice balance of goodwill in the room and zingers for the home audience.\"\n\nByers reported that the Oscars then wanted John Mulaney to host, but the writer-comedian's schedule is simply too busy next March.\n\nSo it's back to the drawing board. Some of the names being thrown around just for fun: Chris Rock, Steve Martin, Martin Short and Neil Patrick Harris, although the 2015 host has said he probably wouldn't want to host again. I liked 2022 co-host Wanda Sykes, but she too said she likely wouldn't host again.\n\nHave feedback or a tip? Email Poynter senior media writer Tom Jones at tjones@poynter.org.", "source": {"uri": "poynter.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Poynter"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_jones@poynter.org", "name": "Tom {"uri": "8250777452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:56:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:56:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:56:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/presidential/3103959/trump-participate-national-association-black-journalists-convention/", "title": "Trump to participate in National Association of Black Journalists convention this week - Washington Examiner", "body": "Former President Donald Trump will attend a conference of black journalists in Chicago this week as his campaign tries to run up his gains with black voters.\n\nTrump is slated to join a question-and-answer panel session with political journalists attending the National Association of Black Journalists' annual Convention & Career Fair this week. The panel will be moderated by ABC News's Rachel Scott, Fox News's Harris Faulkner, and Semafor's Kadia Goba.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Lemon continued.\n\nOn the panel, Trump is set to discuss \"the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nThe panel will be on the convention's opening day, Wednesday, July 31, at 12 p.m. Central time. The event is not open to the public, only registered attendees, but it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic nominee, was invited to the convention, but NABJ said \"her confirmation is pending.\" NABJ said former Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama, and Bill Clinton have attended NABJ conventions in the past, either as presidential candidates or while in office.\n\nThe Washington Examiner reached out to the Harris campaign regarding her attendance.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "annabella_rosciglione@washingtonexaminer.com", "name": "Annabella Rosciglione", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Association of Black Journalists"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Fox News"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harris_Faulkner", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Harris Faulkner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_News", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "ABC News"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "African Americans"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Examiner", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Washington Examiner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamala_Harris", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Kamala Harris"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_W._Bush", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "George W. Bush"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Clinton", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Bill Clinton"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Barack Obama"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Facebook"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "YouTube"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Holidays/Thanksgiving", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Holidays/Thanksgiving", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 87}], "image": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/trump-up-close-serious.webp", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9774346", "eventUri": "eng-9774346", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-31", "textStart": 1091, "textEnd": 1098}], "sentiment": 0.1843137254901961, "wgt": 212, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-438747881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:20:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:20:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:13:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.aol.com/donald-trump-speak-black-journalists-191358688.html", "title": "Donald Trump to speak at Black journalists convention in Chicago, draws criticism", "body": "Donald Trump to speak at Black journalists convention in Chicago, draws criticism\n\nN'dea Yancey-Bragg and Kinsey Crowley, USA TODAY\n\nJuly 30, 2024 at 9:13 PM\n\nFormer president Donald Trump will speak at the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention in Chicago Wednesday, drawing criticism from people planning to attend the event.\n\nTrump will be in conversation with ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, FOX News anchor Harris Faulkner and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba, NABJ announced Monday evening.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said according to a press release.\n\nThe Trump campaign confirmed the appearance in a statement claiming he has accomplished more for the Black community than any other president. His appearance comes after June polling show Trump didn't gain much ground among Black voters before President Joe Biden dropped out, and Vice President Kamala Harris' first week as the presumptive nominee drummed up a lot of excitement among other Black organizations.\n\nFor some Black journalists, the decision to allow him to speak was \"tone deaf,\" as they say Trump has done harm for Chicago and the Black community.\n\nAgenda47 on crime: Trump proposes death-penalty for drug dealers, requiring stop and frisk\n\nVice President Kamala Harris also invited to speak at NABJ\n\nTrump has been invited to speak at the NABJ in the past. In 2016, he declined an invitation but Hillary Clinton made an appearance at the NABJ and National Association of Hispanic Journalists annual conference in Washington, D.C.\n\nHarris also received an invitation to the 2024 conference, according to the organization's release, but her participation has not yet been confirmed.\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have also appeared at NABJ conventions in the past.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" Lemon said in the release.\n\nTrump has long made Chicago a political 'punching bag'\n\nWhen Morgan Elise Johnson, publisher of The Triibe a Black-owned Chicago publication, heard the news late Monday night, questions immediately began swirling about the timing of and thought process behind the decision. She said the late night announcement made her feel like the organization was \"moving in a way that was disingenuous.\"\n\n\"I don't really know what NABJ hopes to get out of this event,\" Johnson said. \"I do not expect that what they will get is the truth out of Donald Trump's mouth.\"\n\nThough the costs of attending the convention is \"pretty astronomical,\" Johnson said she was planning on attending some NABJ events. But Monday's announcement raised safety concerns for her given that Trump was recently the target of an attempted assassination and the city's resources are already stretched thin hosting the music festival Lollapalooza and preparing for the upcoming Democratic National Convention.\n\nIn addition to the already chaotic atmosphere, she noted that Trump is not likely to be well received in the city after \"using Chicago as a punching bag in his political stump speeches.\"\n\n\"So, would I have invited Donald Trump? No...\" she said. \"I think the Black press needs to operate in the way that we always have, which is to protect Black people.\"\n\nFor Ernest Owens, president of the Philadelphia Association of Black Journalists, the announcement was unsurprising. Owens, the Philadelphia editor at Eater and editor at large for Philadelphia Magazine, has been critical of NABJ in the past for what he described as a lack of transparency, pointing to Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah's statement on X as the latest example.\n\nAttiah said Tuesday she \"was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format\" and she has decided to step down as co-chair of the convention.\n\n\"Just because you can do something don't mean you should do something, and they have just not been with the times,\" Owens said of the NABJ. \"The idea of treating and normalizing Trump like he's just a regular presidential candidate, and not recognizing how detrimental and harmful he's been to not only the Black community, but to the Black press, is just a tone deaf decision.\"\n\nOwens, who is no longer an NABJ member, was not going to attend the conference and said he doesn't plan to watch the livestream of the Trump event calling it a \"waste of time and resources.\" He recalled that past conventions were a source of joy and positivity, but Trump's presence will likely put a damper on that atmosphere.\n\n\"Trump loves to dishearten and upset Black people, whether they're journalists, whether they're athletes, whether they're activists,\" he said. \"He likes to create this kind of chaos, and he's succeeded in that.\"\n\nEvent will be livestreamed, for those who want to watch\n\nHowever, Robin Ayers, a radio host at Tavis Smiley's KBLA 1580, wasn't planning on attending the convention until she heard Trump was planning to speak. Ayers said she is not an NABJ member and this would be her first time attending the conference.\n\nThough she understands what prompted the backlash from Black journalists, she said so long as Trump is held accountable for any false statements she's \"not mad at giving him a platform.\" One way this could be achieved, she suggested, is through live fact checking.\n\n\"There's value in hearing him out on things that we care about,\" she said. \"So the fact that he's actually going to be present with Black journalists is actually a pretty big deal, if they go about this the right way.\"\n\nUSA TODAY reached out to the Trump campaign and NABJ for further comment. Trump's Q&A is scheduled for noon central time Wednesday, will be live streamed on NABJ YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Donald Trump will speak at NABJ {"uri": "8251396452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:57:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:57:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:56:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/30/nx-s1-5057623/trumps-nabj-black-journalists-convention-speech", "title": "Trump's planned address to Black journalists convention sparks backlash", "body": "Former President Donald Trump will address the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) in Chicago on Wednesday, prompting swift backlash within the journalism sphere.\n\nNABJ co-chair and Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah announced that she had stepped down from her position at the convention following the announcement, writing on X: \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck. For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City.\"\n\nShe wrote that her decision was influenced by a \"variety of factors,\" and that she was not consulted with \"in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nTrump's history both with the news media and Black people at large has come under scrutiny amid racist comments and positions.\n\nIn addition to broad attacks against the media -- including decrying coverage he views as unfavorable as \"fake news\" and encouraging rallygoers to chant anti-media rhetoric -- he has also specifically gone after Black women reporters.\n\nOn NABJ's X post announcing the panel -- which will be moderated by ABC News' Rachel Scott, Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Semafor's Kadia Goba -- commenters expressed their frustration that Trump had been invited to address the prominent journalism convention.\n\n\"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have, potentially unsafe, all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else,' when this is....idiotic at best,\" Carron Phillips, a two-time NABJ award-winning journalist, wrote on X.\n\nJim Trotter, the 2023 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote: \"This is such a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nApril Ryan -- White House correspondent for The Grio who Trump had repeatedly attacked while in office -- also expressed her frustration with the decision.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" Ryan wrote. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee.\"\n\nShe continued: \"I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nRyan was named NABJ's journalist of the year in 2017.\n\nOthers called into question the selection of Fox News' Faulkner to co-moderate the debate, noting her cozy relationship with the former president.\n\nBut Tia Mitchell, Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, defended the decision to invite the Republican presidential nominee.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" Mitchell said. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nAmid the backlash she received from the decision, Mitchell made her X account private.\n\nNABJ extends an invitation to presidential candidates to address the convention every four years, and Trump had previously declined to attend.\n\nBut facing a difficult and historic race against Vice President Harris, who would be the first Black woman elected, Trump has doubled down on his attempts to court Black voters.\n\nIn a statement announcing Trump's attendance at the journalists convention, the campaign wrote that Trump had \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\"\n\nHarris had also been invited to attend, but will not be able to due to scheduling reasons, a source familiar with the deliberations tells NPR's Asma Khalid.\n\n\"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in-person fireside chat with the VP at a later date,\" the source said, noting that Harris values the work of the organization and of Black reporters, and would keep the door {"uri": "8250863756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:51:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:51:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:50:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.thewrap.com/national-association-of-black-journalists-nabj-trump-invitation/", "title": "National Association of Black Journalists Chair Defends Decision to Invite Trump to 2024 Convention", "body": "\"It's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" Tia Mitchell posts on X\n\nFollowing a round of social media backlash, a chair member of the Political Task Force for the National Association of Black Journalists is defending the organization's decision to invite Republican nominee Donald Trump to its 2024 convention.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" Tia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, posted on X in a response to another user complaining about the decision. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nThough Trump did not attend the NABJ Conventions in 2020 or 2016, several other presidential hopefuls have over the years. Former Presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have all attended this convention as either presidents or candidates.\n\nOn Monday, the media organization confirmed that Trump would be joining the 2024 National Association of Black Journalists Convention and Career Fair in Chicago, its biggest event. Trump will participate in a conversation on Wednesday, the first day of the convention. That conversation will be moderated by senior congressional correspondent for ABC News Rachel Scott; anchor of \"The Faulkner Focus\" and co-host of \"Outnumbered\" on Fox News Harris Faulkner; and politics reporter at Semafor Kadia Goba. The event will not be open to the public but will be live-streamed via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nSoon after its announcement, the upcoming event sparked outrage. The decision to have Trump at the event has been called \"some naaaaasty work,\" \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history\" and \"extremely disappointing.\"\n\nMany journalists have been further infuriated by how the Trump campaign have advertised the event. In a press release, the Trump Vance campaign claimed that \"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\"\n\n\"College students from Texas were literally crowd-sourcing to raise money to attend THIS NABJ conference because organizational budgets for Black and POC students were eliminated due to racist, anti-DEI legislation brought forth by this former President and his cronies,\" Amber Sims, co-founder and executive director of the student-centered organization Young Leaders, Strong City, posted.\n\n\"I'm truly disgusted to see Black journalists, especially young, unemployed and queer, who spent what little they had to go to a convention be reminded that @NAJB values clout over community,\" Ernest Owens, a writer at large specializing in politics for Philadelphia Magazine's G Philly and CEO of Ernest Media Empire, wrote on X. \"It's disappointing.\"\n\nWhen NABJ first announced the Trump session on Monday, the organization's president, Ken Lemon, noted that they're looking forward to attendees hearing from Trump on \"critical issues our members and their audiences care about most.\"\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Lemon wrote at the time.\n\nThe NABJ did not immediately respond to TheWrap's request for comment.", "source": {"uri": "thewrap.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-07-438359922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:33:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:33:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T08:28:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://turnto10.com/news/nation-world/donald-trump-black-journalists-convention-questions-answers-chicago-voters-national-association-hundreds-streaming-washington-dc-women-men-children-career-of-color-hard-questions-intense-vice-president-kamala-harris", "title": "Trump to take part in Q-and-A event at national Black journalists' convention in Chicago", "body": "WASHINGTON (7News) -- Former President Donald Trump will field questions from numerous black journalists in front of a crowd of hundreds of others in Chicago Wednesday at the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) Convention, according to an NABJ statement.\n\nThe question-and-answer conversation will see the Republican nominee for president respond to tough questions on topics related to the Black community as he attempts to secure support from voters of color going into November, the statement read.\n\nThe event is expected to begin around noon on the Convention's opening day and will be closed to the public. NABJ officials said the event will be streamed on their YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nIt's not uncommon for major political candidates to speak during the convention, as Former presidents George Bush Jr., Barack Obama, and Bill Clinton have also attended while in office or as candidates, according to a statement from the NABJ.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris was also invited to speak at the convention, however, the NABJ said they are awaiting a response from her team.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon in a statement. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nThe conversation will be moderated by ABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott alongside Harris Faulker, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor's politics reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nAccording to the NABJ, their annual convention on journalism education and career networking will take place from July 31 to Aug. 4 at the Hilton Chicago.\n\nWhile poll data according to Politico shows that Trump is polling higher with voters of color compared to 2020 and 2016, his growth appears to be stunted following the announcement of Harris as the presumptive Democratic nominee. {"uri": "8251222438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:27:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:27:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:20:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-speak-black-journalists-191358925.html", "title": "Donald Trump to speak at Black journalists convention in Chicago, draws criticism", "body": "Trump will be in conversation with ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, FOX News anchor Harris Faulkner and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said according to a press release.\n\nThe Trump campaign confirmed the appearance in a statement claiming he has accomplished more for the Black community than any other president. His appearance comes after June polling show Trump didn't gain much ground among Black voters before President Joe Biden dropped out, and Vice President Kamala Harris' first week as the presumptive nominee drummed up a lot of excitement among other Black organizations.\n\nFor some Black journalists, the decision to allow him to speak was \"tone deaf,\" as they say Trump has done harm for Chicago and the Black community.\n\nAgenda47 on crime: Trump proposes death-penalty for drug dealers, requiring stop and frisk\n\nTrump has been invited to speak at the NABJ in the past. In 2016, he declined an invitation but Hillary Clinton made an appearance at the NABJ and National Association of Hispanic Journalists annual conference in Washington, D.C.\n\nHarris also received an invitation to the 2024 conference, according to the organization's release, but her participation has not yet been confirmed.\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have also appeared at NABJ conventions in the past.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" Lemon said in the release.\n\nWhen Morgan Elise Johnson, publisher of The Triibe a Black-owned Chicago publication, heard the news late Monday night, questions immediately began swirling about the timing of and thought process behind the decision. She said the late night announcement made her feel like the organization was \"moving in a way that was disingenuous.\"\n\n\"I don't really know what NABJ hopes to get out of this event,\" Johnson said. \"I do not expect that what they will get is the truth out of Donald Trump's mouth.\"\n\nThough the costs of attending the convention is \"pretty astronomical,\" Johnson said she was planning on attending some NABJ events. But Monday's announcement raised safety concerns for her given that Trump was recently the target of an attempted assassination and the city's resources are already stretched thin hosting the music festival Lollapalooza and preparing for the upcoming Democratic National Convention.\n\nIn addition to the already chaotic atmosphere, she noted that Trump is not likely to be well received in the city after \"using Chicago as a punching bag in his political stump speeches.\"\n\n\"So, would I have invited Donald Trump? No...\" she said. \"I think the Black press needs to operate in the way that we always have, which is to protect Black people.\"\n\nFor Ernest Owens, president of the Philadelphia Association of Black Journalists, the announcement was unsurprising. Owens, the Philadelphia editor at Eater and editor at large for Philadelphia Magazine, has been critical of NABJ in the past for what he described as a lack of transparency, pointing to Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah's statement on X as the latest example.\n\nAttiah said Tuesday she \"was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format\" and she has decided to step down as co-chair of the convention.\n\n\"Just because you can do something don't mean you should do something, and they have just not been with the times,\" Owens said of the NABJ. \"The idea of treating and normalizing Trump like he's just a regular presidential candidate, and not recognizing how detrimental and harmful he's been to not only the Black community, but to the Black press, is just a tone deaf decision.\"\n\nOwens, who is no longer an NABJ member, was not going to attend the conference and said he doesn't plan to watch the livestream of the Trump event calling it a \"waste of time and resources.\" He recalled that past conventions were a source of joy and positivity, but Trump's presence will likely put a damper on that atmosphere.\n\n\"Trump loves to dishearten and upset Black people, whether they're journalists, whether they're athletes, whether they're activists,\" he said. \"He likes to create this kind of chaos, and he's succeeded in that.\"\n\nHowever, Robin Ayers, a radio host at Tavis Smiley's KBLA 1580, wasn't planning on attending the convention until she heard Trump was planning to speak. Ayers said she is not an NABJ member and this would be her first time attending the conference.\n\nThough she understands what prompted the backlash from Black journalists, she said so long as Trump is held accountable for any false statements she's \"not mad at giving him a platform.\" One way this could be achieved, she suggested, is through live fact checking.\n\n\"There's value in hearing him out on things that we care about,\" she said. \"So the fact that he's actually going to be present with Black journalists is actually a pretty big deal, if they go about this the right way.\"\n\nUSA TODAY reached out to the Trump campaign and NABJ for further comment. Trump's Q&A is scheduled for noon central time Wednesday, will be live streamed on NABJ YouTube and Facebook pages.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-438899394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:04:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:04:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:09:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/30/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists/", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nTrump and NABJ also have a tense history over his treatment of Black women journalists. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump for repeatedly using words such as \"stupid,\" \"loser\" and \"nasty\" to describe Black women journalists including several Black journalists such as Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News; Abby Phillip of CNN; and April Ryan of The Grio.\n\n\"The most powerful man in the free world is verbally abusing journalists,\" said then-NABJ President Sarah Glover. \"His dismissive comments toward journalists April Ryan, Abby Phillip and Yamiche Alcindor are appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nWhen Trump told Alcindor \"don't be threatening\" during a 2020 press conference, then-NABJ President Dorothy Tucker condemned the remarks as \"not only unnecessary but demeaning and inappropriate.\"\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have all attended NABJ. President Biden attended a virtual NABJ panel during his 2020 run for president where he received criticism for saying: \"Unlike the African American community, with notable exceptions, the Latino community is an incredibly diverse community.\"\n\nBut for many NABJ members, the decision to host Trump polarizes the organization and threatens the convention's ethos, which aspires to safeguard and advance Black journalists.\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nYet, Lemon and other leaders at NABJ have faced internal backlash and calls to resign since Trump's appearance was announced.\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The "body": "Trump to attend National Association of Black Journalists convention\n\nJuly 30, 2024 at 5:09 AM\n\n(Reuters) - Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign on Monday said he would attend a question-and-answer session at the National Association of Black Journalists annual convention this week in Chicago.\n\nFormer US President Trump, who has been courting Black voters and whose campaign has been encouraged by some polling showing he may be gaining ground with that group of the electorate, will speak with political journalists before an audience of registered attendees on Wednesday.\n\nThe event is closed to the public, but it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, NABJ said in a statement.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ president Ken Lemon.\n\nLemon went on to say that the Trump event would allow Black journalists in attendance \"to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump's campaign said in a written statement that the event \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nThe NABJ said in its statement that fellow presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in this year's convention, but that her confirmation is pending.\n\n(Reporting by Brad Brooks in Longmont, Colorado; Editing by Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": The discussion will focus on the most pressing issues facing the black community, the Trump campaign and the NABJ said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTRUMP WILL DEBATE DEMOCRATIC PARTY'S 'ULTIMATE NOMINEE,' SAYS CAMPAIGN ADVISER\n\nThe event will be moderated by anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News Harris Faulkner, ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba.\n\n\"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history by implementing America First policies on the economy, immigration, energy, law and order, and foreign policy,\" the Trump campaign claimed in a press release.\n\n\"Historic rates of Black voters now support President Trump, and the reason is simple: Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has, including landmark unemployment rates for Black Americans, increased median income for Black households, historic permanent funding for HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), comprehensive bipartisan criminal justice reform, and nearly $50 billion in funds to revitalize Opportunity Zones,\" his campaign continued.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic Party's presumptive presidential nominee, was also invited to participate in the convention, but she has not confirmed her attendance.\n\nFormer Presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton attended NABJ conventions in the past, either as presidents or presidential candidates.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public and will be
