{"uri": "8251481512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:39:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:39:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:38:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jul/30/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-m/", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists", "body": "Alex Brandon / AP, file\n\nRepublican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally, Saturday, July 27, 2024, in St. Cloud, Minn.\n\nBy Matt Brown, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, July 30, 2024 | 4:35 p.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nTrump and NABJ also have a tense history over his treatment of Black women journalists. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump for repeatedly using words such as \"stupid,\" \"loser\" and \"nasty\" to describe Black women journalists including several Black journalists such as Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News; Abby Phillip of CNN; and April Ryan of The Grio.\n\n\"The most powerful man in the free world is verbally abusing journalists,\" said then-NABJ President Sarah Glover. \"His dismissive comments toward journalists April Ryan, Abby Phillip and Yamiche Alcindor are appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nWhen Trump told Alcindor \"don't be threatening\" during a 2020 press conference, then-NABJ President Dorothy Tucker condemned the remarks as \"not only unnecessary but demeaning and inappropriate.\"\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have all attended NABJ. President Biden attended a virtual NABJ panel during his 2020 run for president where he received criticism for saying: \"Unlike the African American community, with notable exceptions, the Latino community is an incredibly diverse community.\"\n\nBut for many NABJ members, the decision to host Trump polarizes the organization and threatens the convention's ethos, which aspires to safeguard and advance Black journalists.\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nYet, Lemon and other leaders at NABJ have faced internal backlash and calls to resign since Trump's appearance was announced.\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas {"uri": "2024-07-438864463", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:47:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:47:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:29:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/wire/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists/article_93add613-7ae5-53a6-bd46-981447bff62e.html", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists", "body": "Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nTrump and NABJ also have a tense history over his treatment of Black women journalists. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump for repeatedly using words such as \"stupid,\" \"loser\" and \"nasty\" to describe Black women journalists including several Black journalists such as Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News; Abby Phillip of CNN; and April Ryan of The Grio.\n\n\"The most powerful man in the free world is verbally abusing journalists,\" said then-NABJ President Sarah Glover. \"His dismissive comments toward journalists April Ryan, Abby Phillip and Yamiche Alcindor are appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nWhen Trump told Alcindor \"don't be threatening\" during a 2020 press conference, then-NABJ President Dorothy Tucker condemned the remarks as \"not only unnecessary but demeaning and inappropriate.\"\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have all attended NABJ. President Biden attended a virtual NABJ panel during his 2020 run for president where he received criticism for saying: \"Unlike the African American community, with notable exceptions, the Latino community is an incredibly diverse community.\"\n\nBut for many NABJ members, the decision to host Trump polarizes the organization and threatens the convention's ethos, which aspires to safeguard and advance Black journalists.\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nYet, Lemon and other leaders at NABJ have faced internal backlash and calls to resign since Trump's appearance was announced.\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "maryvilleforum.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Maryville {"uri": "8251063451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:10:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.al.com/news/2024/07/trump-addressing-black-journalists-in-chicago-sparks-outrage-this-is-such-a-poor-decision.html", "title": "Trump addressing Black journalists in Chicago sparks outrage: 'This is such a poor decision'", "body": "Former President Donald Trump is scheduled to attend a panel discussion Wednesday at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Chicago.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement.\n\nTrump's first publicly announced visit to Chicago in years would come just a few weeks before the full force of the Democratic Party descends on the city for its national convention. The party is expected to celebrate the historic presidential nomination of Vice President Kamala Harris, who would be the first Black woman to lead a presidential ticket.\n\nThe NABJ also invited Harris to participate in the convention and \"her confirmation is pending,\" the organization said in a statement late Monday. Other former chief executives, including former President Barack Obama, have participated in NABJ conventions either as presidents or candidates, the statement noted.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson issued a statement on social media saying the city is prepared for Trump's visit.\n\n\"My administration's values and practice are in complete opposition to former President Donald Trump's agenda, but I want the people of Chicago to know that City departments and agencies are fully prepared to uphold safety during his scheduled visit,\" Johnson wrote on X.\n\nTrump's campaign confirmed the appearance late Monday night, saying in an emailed statement that he was \"participate in a conversation with journalists\" at the NABJ event. It will be held on noon on Wednesday.\n\n\"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has,\" the Trump campaign said in the statement.\n\nThe Q&A will be moderated by Rachel Scott of ABC News, Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Kadia Goba of the digital publication Semafor. It will be livestreamed and open to convention attendees but not open to the general public.\n\nTrump has said he wants to court Black voters for the November election, particularly with his economic policies. But his campaign agenda also has called for expanding police practices such as stop and frisk that have disproportionately affected Black Americans.\n\nDuring Trump's first visit to Chicago as president in 2019, he was met by hundreds of protesters and lobbed criticism at the city's then-police superintendent and other city leaders.\n\nAs a candidate for president in 2016, Trump was forced to cancel a rally at the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion amid security concerns as thousands of protesters demonstrated in the area.\n\nReaction on social media immediately after the NABJ's announcement was mixed.\n\n\"This is such a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words,\" Jim Trotter, a sports journalist and NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year, wrote on X.\n\n\"[L]ike many people said, this is where you go to get away from the hostility of your newsroom. It's supposed to be your safe space,\" Chicago-based journalist and author Arionne Nettles wrote of the convention, which serves as a gathering and networking space for Black journalists.\n\nTia Mitchell, a Washington-based correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said she helped make the decision to host Trump and in social media posts Monday night said she stood by the decision to invite Trump.\n\n\"Members can disagree. No one is forcing them to attend. But there is precedent of such invitations and great care taken with this particular one,\" Mitchell wrote.", "source": {"uri": "al.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "al"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-438865764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:49:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:49:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:29:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists/article_09ae03ca-8038-5fda-82e5-d9beaedec04d.html", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists", "body": "Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nTrump and NABJ also have a tense history over his treatment of Black women journalists. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump for repeatedly using words such as \"stupid,\" \"loser\" and \"nasty\" to describe Black women journalists including several Black journalists such as Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News; Abby Phillip of CNN; and April Ryan of The Grio.\n\n\"The most powerful man in the free world is verbally abusing journalists,\" said then-NABJ President Sarah Glover. \"His dismissive comments toward journalists April Ryan, Abby Phillip and Yamiche Alcindor are appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nWhen Trump told Alcindor \"don't be threatening\" during a 2020 press conference, then-NABJ President Dorothy Tucker condemned the remarks as \"not only unnecessary but demeaning and inappropriate.\"\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have all attended NABJ. President Biden attended a virtual NABJ panel during his 2020 run for president where he received criticism for saying: \"Unlike the African American community, with notable exceptions, the Latino community is an incredibly diverse community.\"\n\nBut for many NABJ members, the decision to host Trump polarizes the organization and threatens the convention's ethos, which aspires to safeguard and advance Black journalists.\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nYet, Lemon and other leaders at NABJ have faced internal backlash and calls to resign since Trump's appearance was announced.\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nPIC's WooSOS Plugin Streamlines Ecommerce Through WooCommerce and SOS Inventory Integration\n\nBlack Chamber of Arizona New Member Orientation Presented by BMO a Resounding Success!\n\nInvestigation finds at least 973 Native American children died in US government boarding schools", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-438675277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:44:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:44:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:11:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/30/black-journalists-object-to-their-association-invi/", "title": "Black journalists object to their association inviting Trump to annual convention", "body": "Some Black journalists are furious with their professional organization for inviting former President Donald Trump to participate in an event on stage Wednesday during the group's annual convention in Chicago.\n\nMr. Trump's scheduled appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention and Career Fair has provoked irate opposition from some of the group's members, one of whom called it \"a slap in the face\" to Black women journalists. The GOP presidential nominee is set to take questions from a panel of three journalists.\n\nAmid the furor, the convention's co-chair, Karen Attiah, announced Tuesday that she was stepping down from her role as an organizer of the meeting.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Ms. Attiah, a longtime Washington Post columnist, said on X. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nJournalist April Ryan, whom Mr. Trump called a \"loser\" when she covered his presidency, said, \"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact.\" The NABJ named her its journalist of the year in 2017, Mr. Trump's first year in office.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025,\" she said on X. \"I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nProject 2025 is a policy document authored by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington think tank. Mr. Trump has said it is not part of his platform but Democrats have presented it as his agenda.\n\nMr. Trump's event will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Fox News' Harris Faulkner and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor. His campaign said he will answer questions \"that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon said they're looking forward to \"attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most.\"\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Mr. Lemon said.\n\nMs. Ryan became the longest-serving Black female White House correspondent in 2022. In 2018, while she was the White House correspondent and Washington bureau chief for American Urban Radio Networks, she had an encounter with Mr. Trump in which he wound up calling her a \"loser\" and \"nasty.\" He also repeatedly told her to \"sit down.\"\n\n\"[It] was one of the ugliest moments I have ever seen or felt in my life,\" she told \"Morning Joe\" hosts Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski in 2022.\n\nOn X, Jim Trotter, the 2023 NABJ journalist of the year, called the invitation of Mr. Trump \"a poor decision,\" so much so that \"it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nPublicist Lauren Paige called it a \"horrible choice,\" in her statement on X.\n\n\"NABJ, I understand being unbiased but having the man who has and continues to actively disrespect media and Black media like did we forget how he treated April Ryan and other journalists?\" she wrote.\n\nMr. Trump has touted that he has done more for Black Americans during his time in office than other presidents, with a \"possible exception\" of former President Abraham Lincoln, who signed the Emancipation Proclamation. Polls taken before President Biden dropped out of the race earlier this month showed Mr. Trump making significant gains among Black voters compared with the 2020 election.\n\n\"Historic rates of Black voters now support President Trump, and the reason is simple: Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has,\" the campaign said in a statement.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in the convention, according to the association, but her confirmation is pending.\n\nThe Washington Times has reached out to NABJ and Ms. Harris for comment.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250773610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:59:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:59:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:53:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/former-president-donald-trump-attend-134900122.html", "title": "Former President Donald Trump to attend Black journalists convention in Chicago", "body": "Former President Donald Trump is scheduled to attend a panel discussion Wednesday at the National Association of Black Journalists convention, which is being held in Chicago.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement.\n\nTrump's first publicly announced visit to Chicago in years is expected just a few weeks before the full force of the Democratic Party descends on the city for its national convention, with the party expected to celebrate the historic presidential nomination of Vice President Kamala Harris. Harris is expected to become the first woman of color to lead a presidential ticket.\n\nThe NABJ also invited Harris to participate in the convention and \"her confirmation is pending,\" the organization said in a statement late Monday. Other former chief executives, including former President Barack Obama, have participated in NABJ conventions either as presidents or candidates, the statement noted.\n\nTrump's campaign confirmed the appearance late Monday night, saying in an emailed statement that he was \"participate in a conversation with journalists\" at the NABJ event. It will be held on noon on Wednesday.\n\n\"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has,\" the Trump campaign said in the statement.\n\nThe Q&A will be moderated by Rachel Scott of ABC News, Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Kadia Goba of the digital publication Semafor. It will be livestreamed and open to convention attendees but not open to the general public.\n\nTrump has said he wants to court Black voters for the November election, particularly with his economic policies. He also has called to expand practices including stop and frisk that have disproportionately negatively affected Black Americans.\n\nDuring Trump's first visit to Chicago as president in 2019, he was met by hundreds of protesters and lobbed criticism at the city's then-police superintendent and other city leaders.\n\nAs a candidate for president in 2016, Trump was forced to cancel a rally at the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion amid security concerns as thousands of protesters demonstrated in the area.\n\nReaction on social media immediately after the NABJ's announcement was mixed.\n\n\"This is such a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words,\" Jim Trotter, a sports journalist and NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year, wrote on X.\n\n\"[L]ike many people said, this is where you go to get away from the hostility of your newsroom. It's supposed to be your safe space,\" Chicago-based journalist and author Arionne Nettles wrote of the convention, which serves as a gathering and networking space for Black journalists.\n\nTia Mitchell, a Washington-based correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said she helped make the decision to host Trump and in social media posts Monday night said she stood by the decision to invite Trump.\n\n\"Members can disagree. No one is forcing them to attend. But there is precedent of such invitations and great care taken with this particular one,\" Mitchell wrote.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8252180554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:52:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:52:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:51:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/31/nation/speaking-invitation-donald-trump-splits-most-prominent-american-group-black-journalists/", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists - The Boston Globe", "body": "Trump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nTrump and NABJ also have a tense history over his treatment of Black women journalists. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump for repeatedly using words such as \"stupid,\" \"loser\" and \"nasty\" to describe Black women journalists including several Black journalists such as Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News; Abby Phillip of CNN; and April Ryan of The Grio.\n\n\"The most powerful man in the free world is verbally abusing journalists,\" said then-NABJ President Sarah Glover. \"His dismissive comments toward journalists April Ryan, Abby Phillip and Yamiche Alcindor are appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nWhen Trump told Alcindor \"don't be threatening\" during a 2020 press conference, then-NABJ President Dorothy Tucker condemned the remarks as \"not only unnecessary but demeaning and inappropriate.\"\n\nFormer presidents George W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have all attended NABJ. President Biden attended a virtual NABJ panel during his 2020 run for president where he received criticism for saying: \"Unlike the African American community, with notable exceptions, the Latino community is an incredibly diverse community.\"\n\nBut for many NABJ members, the decision to host Trump polarizes the organization and threatens the convention's ethos, which aspires to safeguard and advance Black journalists.\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nYet, Lemon and other leaders at NABJ have faced internal backlash and calls to resign since Trump's appearance was announced.\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251416273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:19:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:19:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:18:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-invitation-black-journalists-215100098.html", "title": "Donald Trump's invitation to Black journalists Chicago convention divides membership", "body": "CHICAGO -- Former President Donald Trump's scheduled appearance Wednesday at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Chicago roiled the organization as many members questioned the decision to provide a platform for the divisive Republican nominee.\n\n\"This is such a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words,\" Jim Trotter, a sports journalist and NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year, wrote on X, one of hundreds reactions to Trump's appearance on the social media platform.\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said on Tuesday she was stepping down as co-chair for the NABJ convention.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" Attiah wrote on X. She didn't immediately respond to an emailed request for additional comment Tuesday.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon backed the decision to have Trump appear at the convention.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Lemon said in a statement.\n\nThe NABJ also invited Vice President and presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris to participate in the convention and \"her confirmation is pending,\" the organization said in a statement late Monday. Other former chief executives, including former President Barack Obama, have participated in NABJ conventions either as while in office or as candidates, the statement noted.\n\nThe convention is being held at the Hilton Chicago on South Michigan Avenue. Trump is scheduled to take questions at noon from a panel of three reporters, Rachel Scott of ABC News, Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Kadia Goba of the digital publication Semafor. The discussion will be open to convention attendees and livestreamed, but not open to the public.\n\nTrump's first publicly announced visit to Chicago in years would come just a few weeks before the full force of the Democratic Party descends on the city for its national convention. The party is expected to celebrate the historic presidential nomination of Vice President Kamala Harris, who would be the first Black woman to lead a presidential ticket.\n\nWhile supporters of the NABJ's decision pointed to journalists' responsibility to ask questions of people in power, others said that the industry convention was not the proper venue for Trump, who in the past has made offensive statements at the expense of people of color and the city of Chicago.\n\n\"And like many people said, this is where you go to get away from the hostility of your newsroom. It's supposed to be your safe space,\" Chicago-based journalist and author Arionne Nettles wrote of the convention, which serves as a gathering and networking space for Black journalists.\n\nTia Mitchell, a Washington-based correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said she helped make the decision to host Trump and in a social media post nodded to the organization's history of interviewing politicians and presidential candidates.\n\n\"Members can disagree. No one is forcing them to attend. But there is precedent of such invitations and great care taken with this particular one,\" Mitchell wrote.\n\nReached by phone, NABJ Executive Director Drew Berry declined to comment on the decision to host Trump and redirected the question to the organization's press office, which did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson issued a statement on social media saying the city is prepared for Trump's visit.\n\n\"My administration's values and practice are in complete opposition to former President Donald Trump's agenda, but I want the people of Chicago to know that city departments and agencies are fully prepared to uphold safety during his scheduled visit,\" Johnson wrote on X.\n\nTrump's campaign confirmed the appearance late Monday night, saying in an emailed statement that he was to \"participate in a conversation with journalists.\"\n\n\"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has,\" the Trump campaign said in the statement.\n\nTrump and Republicans have courted Black voters ahead of the November election, particularly by touting the former president's economic policies. But his campaign agenda also has called for expanding police practices such as stop and frisk that have disproportionately affected Black Americans.\n\nDuring Trump's first visit to Chicago as president in 2019, he was met by hundreds of protesters and lobbed criticism at the city's then-police superintendent and other city leaders.\n\nAs a candidate for president in 2016, Trump was forced to cancel a rally at the University of Illinois Chicago Pavilion amid security concerns as thousands of protesters demonstrated in the area.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8251479279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:36:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:36:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:35:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://abc7chicago.com/post/donald-trump-visiting-chicago-nabj-2024-convention-chair-karen-attiah-steps-down-day-after-announcement/15123923/", "title": "Black journalists convention co-chair steps down 1 day after announcement that Trump will speak", "body": "CHICAGO (WLS) -- The co-chair of the National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down one day after the announcement that former President Donald Trump will speak to the group in Chicago.\n\nTrump is taking part in a panel discussion at the NABJ convention Wednesday. On Tuesday, convention co-chair Karen Attiah said she will step down.\n\nAttiah wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, that \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson also spoke about the former president's visit on Tuesday.\n\nThe convention runs from July 31 to Aug. 4 at the Hilton Chicago, located at 720 South Michigan Avenue in the South Loop. The NABJ's website says the event is a conference for journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\nTrump's campaign and NABJ said he will participate in a Q&A with political journalists in front of an audience of convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community. It will happen at noon Wednesday.\n\nABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott will moderate the event with The Faulkner Focus Anchor Harris Faulkner, who is also a co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor Political Reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public, but it will be live-streamed via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the organization said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump will then head to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania for a rally.\n\nLast week, Trump also revealed plans to return to Butler, Pennsylvania for the first time since his attempted assassination. The date of that rally has not been announced.", "source": {"uri": "abc7chicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7 Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251261197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:55:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:55:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:54:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/puts-everyone-really-bad-position-191534384.html", "title": "'It puts everyone in a really bad position': Black journalists react to Trump joining NABJ panel", "body": "On Monday night, the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) announced that Donald Trump will participate in a panel discussion at the organization's annual convention in Chicago, which starts on Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement, which said that the Q&A would \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community\", was met with swift online backlash from some Black journalists. They decried the decision to invite a presidential candidate who has lambasted Black journalists, led a movement to squash diversity, equity and inclusion efforts and who is responsible for increased anti-journalistic sentiment, including the popularization of the term \"fake news\" to describe factual, but potentially unflattering, reporting.\n\nTiffany Walden, a co-founder and editor-in-chief of The TRiiBE, a digital platform that focuses on Black Chicago, told the Guardian that NABJ's decision was \"irresponsible\".\n\n\"We've watched Trump threaten to send the feds here when he was in office,\" Walden said. \"We've watched him use Chicago as a dog whistle in all of his campaign's materials during his first run for office. He talked about Chicago having top gang thugs. So this puts the city of Chicago and its residents in a very vulnerable position. It also puts Black journalists in a very vulnerable position at a convention that's supposed to be a safe space for them.\"\n\nAmeshia Cross, a political analyst, echoed this sentiment on X: \"The same Trump that attacked Black journalists from the stump. The same Trump who is attacking DEI, can't get ahead of his own racism and sexism. And the guy who wants to dissolve journalism as we know it, that's who is speaking at #NABJ24 w/ record attendance. C'mon yall.\"\n\nAnother journalist, Carron J Phillips, called the move \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history\".\n\nThe outcry led to the NABJ president, Ken Lemon, and others defending the decision, saying that Black reporters should have the opportunity to question a political candidate.\n\n\"Every year, every presidential election cycle, we invite the presidential candidates to come,\" Lemon said to NABJ student journalists on Tuesday. \"We extend that to anyone who is a nominee and in this case we have two presumptive nominees. We invited both of them ... This is an important hour. We have people whose lives are depending on what happens in November ... This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground.\"\n\nKamala Harris is scheduled to speak elsewhere on Wednesday, when Trump will be at NABJ, but her confirmation to attend this year's convention, which lasts through Sunday, is \"pending\", according to NABJ.\n\nTia Mitchell, the chair of NABJ's political journalism taskforce and a Washington correspondent at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X: \"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades. But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\" (Mitchell, NABJ and NABJ's Chicago chapter did not respond to requests for comment.)\n\nWednesday's panel will be moderated by Rachel Scott, a senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, who anchors The Faulkner Focus and Outnumbered for Fox News; and Kadia Goba, a politics reporter for Semafor.\n\n\"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump,\" Jemele Hill, a contributing reporter for the Atlantic, wrote on X. \"The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such. Being questioned by journalists is part of the job, and especially important in the company of Black journalists. Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nBut the journalist Matthew Wright pushed back on the notion that there was anything productive in questioning Trump.\n\n\"What does that serve?\" Wright said to the Guardian. \"We literally just watched him talk to Laura Ingraham [who] was trying to get him to answer different questions, but he practically played evasive of action even then. If a super conservative white woman can't get straight answers out of him, what makes you think that three black women are going to get them?\"\n\nIn a statement about the NABJ appearance, Trump's campaign wrote: \"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\" Some journalists used this statement as evidence that NABJ's decision to platform the former president was harmful, and would lead to further perpetuation of falsehoods.\n\n\"This is the way 45 is touting his appearance before @nabj this week. Was this what you wanted [Tia Mitchell]? He is already lying and he isn't even in Chicago yet. This is your legacy,\" April Reign, a media strategist, wrote on X.\n\nThe timing of the panel announcement - less than 48 hours before the convention's start - also drew concern from NABJ members.\n\nShamira Ibrahim, a culture writer, told the Guardian that she was shocked by the decision.\n\n\"It puts everyone in a really bad position,\" Ibrahim said. \"You already paid your convention fees, you already paid for a hotel that's likely not refundable at this point, flights are likely difficult to get replaced. Even if you have a moral opposition to it or an ethical opposition to it, you're kind of already stuck in whatever plan you made.\"\n\nNABJ's annual convention has allowed Black journalists a space to fellowship and gather safely since the organization's founding in 1975, with some reporters likening it to a family reunion. Inviting Trump, Ibrahim said, undermined that sense of community.\n\n\"NABJ is primarily not just a place for journalists to get opportunities to interview politicians, but also a place for Black journalists to network, to have open conversations about things that are happening in the industry, to attend panels, and really get a sense of how to shift in a very, very volatile, fragile space,\" she continued.\n\n\"Inviting someone who, one, has made targeted attacks on Black journalists, two, has actively been responsible in defunding programs that help build Black journalists, and three, has publicly attacked the Black press flies in the face of any sort of fidelity convention.\"\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, a coalition of organizations, including Chicago Alliance Against Racist & Political Repression and Anti-War Committee Chicago, announced plans to rally outside the convention to \"tell Trump he's not welcome in Chicago\".", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8251195199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:58:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:58:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:57:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.fox4news.com/news/trump-chicago-national-association-black-journalists-convention", "title": "Trump in Chicago: Former president to attend National Association of Black Journalists Convention", "body": "CHICAGO - Former President Donald Trump is set to attend the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) annual Convention & Career Fair in Chicago on Wednesday.\n\nAccording to his campaign, Trump will engage in a Q&A session with political journalists, focusing on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\n\nThe event, scheduled for noon, will feature an audience of registered convention attendees and will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of \"The Faulkner Focus\" and co-host of \"Outnumbered\" on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nThe session will not be open to the general public but will be live-streamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages. Vice President Kamala Harris, a fellow presidential candidate, has also been invited to participate, with her confirmation pending.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson denounced Trump's agenda on X but said safety measures will be in place for his visit.\n\n\"My administration's values and practice are in complete opposition to former President Donald Trump's agenda, but I want the people of Chicago to know that City departments and agencies are fully prepared to uphold safety during his scheduled visit on Wednesday,\" the tweet read.\n\nTrump's campaign has spent months scheduling appearances in areas outside his traditional strongholds of support, including when he attended -- and was roundly booed at -- the Libertarian Party convention in Washington earlier this year.\n\nIn its announcement, the campaign trumpeted Trump policies that it argued benefited Black Americans during his first term.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has seen his favorability rate among Black voters fall dramatically since he took office in 2021. But the race against Trump has been shaken up since the president stepped aside and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris -- who would be the first Black woman and the first South Asian American to be elected president if she wins in November.\n\nDuring a visit to Chicago in 2016, Trump was set to hold a campaign rally at the University of Illinois at Chicago. {"uri": "2024-07-438895120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:56:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:56:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:37:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/karen-attiah-resigns-as-co-chair-of-the-nabj-2024-convention-following-news-of-donald-trumps-visit-to-chicago/", "title": "Karen Attiah resigns as co-chair of the NABJ 2024 convention following news of Donald Trump's visit to Chicago. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "CHICAGO (WLS) -- The co-chair of the National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down one day after the announcement that former President Donald Trump will speak to the group in Chicago.\n\nTrump is taking part in a panel discussion at the NABJ convention Wednesday. On Tuesday, convention co-chair Karen Attiah said she will step down.\n\nABC7 Chicago is now streaming 24/7. Click here to watch\n\nAttiah wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, that \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson also spoke about the former president's visit on Tuesday.\n\nThe convention runs from July 31 to Aug. 4 at the Hilton Chicago, located at 720 South Michigan Avenue in the South Loop. The NABJ's website says the event is a conference for journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\nTrump's campaign and NABJ said he will participate in a Q&A with political journalists in front of an audience of convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community. It will happen at noon Wednesday.\n\nABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott will moderate the event with The Faulkner Focus Anchor Harris Faulkner, who is also a co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor Political Reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public, but it will be live-streamed via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the organization said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump will then head to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania for a rally.\n\nLast week, Trump also revealed plans to return to Butler, Pennsylvania for the first time since his attempted assassination. {"uri": "8251296869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:25:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:25:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:24:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://sg.news.yahoo.com/trump-attend-black-journalists-convention-195554596.html", "title": "Trump To Attend Black Journalists Convention In Chicago Amid Backlash", "body": "Former President Donald Trump is expected to appear at the National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Chicago on Wednesday, despite protests from many of the Black journalists attending.\n\n\"President Trump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" a statement released Monday from the Trump campaign said.\n\nThe Wednesday forum with Trump -- which won't be open to the public, but will be livestreamed on the NABJ's YouTube page -- is set to feature Rachel Scott, a senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, as the moderator.\n\nThe NABJ, founded in 1975, is a nonprofit organization with more than 4,000 members that \"advocates on behalf of Black journalists and media professionals in the U.S. and worldwide,\" according to its website. The group gives out more than $100,000 in scholarships every year. HuffPost journalists often attend the NABJ's annual conferences.\n\nThe group's decision to platform Trump has been met with widespread criticism. Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah said Tuesday she will step down from her role as a co-chair for this year's NABJ gathering.\n\n\"I have decided to step down as co-chair from this year's #NABJ24 convention in Chicago,\" Attiah posted on X, the former Twitter. \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck.\"\n\nSports writer Carron Phillips, who said he is attending the convention, called Trump's scheduled appearance \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history.\"\n\n\"Whoever made this call is an idiot,\" Phillips wrote on X. \"And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nJason Ingram, a sports producer, made similar remarks.\n\n\"As a member of NABJ for over 20 years, this is the worst decision they have ever made,\" Ingram said on X. \"I am truly disappointed in everyone involved with this decision. Dude doesn't care about black people!!!!\"\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement that interviewing Trump will give Black journalists the \"opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign praised the former president's supposed accomplishments for Black Americans under his term.\n\n\"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history by implementing America First policies on the economy, immigration, energy, law and order, and foreign policy,\" the statement said.\n\nIn the past, Trump -- who is now the 2024 Republican nominee for president -- questioned President Barack Obama's U.S. citizenship, and in 2020 promoted the false claim that Vice President Kamala Harris also might not be a U.S. citizen. (Obama was born in Hawaii, while Harris was born in California.) Earlier this year, Trump lobbed a similar lie at Nikki Haley, who competed against him in the 2024 primary. Haley was born in South Carolina and served as Republican governor of the state from 2011 to 2017.\n\nTrump also called for the Central Park Five -- a group of Black and Latino teens wrongly accused of raping a white woman -- to be executed in a full-page newspaper ad in 1989. Trump has never apologized for his calls to kill the teens, who today, as adults, are known as the Exonerated Five.\n\nHarris, the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, has also been invited to the NABJ convention. The NABJ said in a statement that her confirmation is still pending.", "source": {"uri": "sg.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-439275052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:08:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:08:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:08:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/trump-to-speak-at-black-journalists-convention-as-harris-erases-his-lead-in-polls/5652027/", "title": "Trump to speak at Black journalists convention, as Harris erases his lead in polls", "body": "Donald Trump is set to field reporters' questions at the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention in Chicago on Wednesday, as he re-tools his presidential campaign to combat his likely rival, Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe Republican nominee's Q&A before a live convention audience is expected to focus on the biggest issues facing the Black community, NABJ said.\n\nTrump will be speaking with Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott and politics reporter Kadia Goba of Semafor. It will be livestreamed at 1 p.m. ET on the group's Facebook and YouTube pages.\n\nThe event gives Trump, who won just 12% of Black voters in his 2020 election loss to President Joe Biden, an opportunity to directly appeal to voters of color.\n\nBut he may have more trouble courting these voters in a competition against Harris, who is the first Black person, first woman and first person of South Asian descent to serve as vice president.\n\nSome polls already show that Harris has more support among Black, Latino and young voters than Biden did before she replaced him as the de facto Democratic nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, a new Bloomberg/Morning Consult survey of battleground states found that Harris has effectively eliminated Trump's lead in the seven battleground states likely to determine which candidate wins the Electoral College.\n\nThe Trump campaign, in a press release Monday night announcing his NABJ appearance, claimed that he \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\"\n\nThe decision by NABJ, the nation's largest association of journalists of color, to host Trump quickly spurred a backlash both inside and outside the group.\n\nConvention co-chair Karen Attiah resigned her position on the eve of the event, writing in a social media post, \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck.\"\n\nShe added in follow-up post, \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon, responding to the Trump event, wrote on X that the group understands \"the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTia Mitchell, an Atlanta Journal-Constitution correspondent and NABJ program co-chair, defended the move, saying it is \"in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades.\"\n\nHarris, however, will not be at the convention.\n\nWhile then-candidate Biden had planned to attend the event, a person familiar with Harris' plans told NBC News that the vice president could not fit a convention appearance into her schedule this week. Harris' overlapping plans include attending the funeral of late Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, and the ongoing process of selecting a running mate.\n\nThat person said NABJ had declined a request by Harris' team to let the vice president appear for a virtual fireside chat, or to schedule an in-person event with the group at a later date.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnewyork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC New York"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251016862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:35:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:35:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:35:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2807866/", "title": "Trump to Address National Association of Black Journalists Convention - ExBulletin", "body": "Trump to Address National Association of Black Journalists Convention\n\nDonald Trump is scheduled to participate in a Q&A with black political journalists as part of the 2024 National Association of Black Journalists convention and career fair in Chicago. The news has sparked a backlash on social media, with a number of prominent black journalists denouncing the decision.\n\nOn July 31, the convention's opening day, the former president will meet with three prominent Black female political journalists to discuss issues facing the Black community today. The discussion will be moderated by Rachel Scott, ABC News' senior congressional correspondent; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on Fox News; and Kadia Goba, a political reporter at Semafor.\n\nThe event will not be open to the public but will be streamed live on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook channels.\n\nNABJ reports that Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, was also invited to the convention, but the vice president's attendance was pending.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues that matter most to our members and their audiences,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement on the group's website. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work our members do and welcome the opportunity to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nNews of Trump's appearance at the convention sparked a backlash on social media Monday night, with a number of prominent black journalists and NABJ members publicly criticizing the organization for inviting the former president.\n\nJim Trotter, sportswriter for The Athletic and the 2023 NABJ Journalist of the Year, tweeted: \"This is such a bad decision by @NABJ it's hard to put into words. \ud83e\udd26\ud83c\udffe\u2642\ufe0f\"\n\n\"Extremely disappointing on the part [the] \"@NABJ,\" CBS Sports analyst Ashley Nicole Moss tweeted. \"This is supposed to be a safe place for Black journalists to connect/network. This is a space to encourage current and future journalists. To remind each other that we belong. He has absolutely NO business being in a room like this.\"\n\n\"Why on earth would @NABJ engage with a man who repeatedly vilifies and degrades the free press? It boggles the mind,\" tweeted journalist-turned-publicist Dave Jordan.\n\nApril Reign, the media strategist behind the #OscarsSoWhite movement, tweeted directly at NABJ President Tia Mitchell: \"This is how 45 is touting his appearance on @nabj this week. Is this what you wanted?\" [Tia Mitchell]\"He's already lying and he's not even in Chicago yet. This is your legacy.\"\n\n\"This is the dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history,\" tweeted sportswriter Carron J. Phillips. \"Whoever made this decision is an idiot. And I will tell them so to their face this week.\"\n\nAmeshia Cross, a Democratic strategist and political pundit, tweeted: \"The same Trump who attacked Black journalists from his podium. The same Trump who attacks DEI, can't get past his own racism and sexism. And the guy who wants to dissolve journalism as we know it, is the one speaking at #NABJ24 with record turnout. Come on, everyone!\"\n\n\"As a member of NABJ for over 20 years, this is the worst decision they have ever made,\" tweeted sports producer Jason Ingram. \"I am truly disappointed in everyone involved in this decision. This dude does not care about black people!!!\"\n\nJemele Hill, a reporter for The Atlantic, attempted to defend the NABJ for inviting Trump. \"As journalists, we can never be afraid to take on someone like Trump. The reality is he is running for president and should be treated as such,\" Hill tweeted.\n\nHill added: \"Being interviewed by journalists is part of the job, and it's especially important when there are black journalists. The mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he's actually gaining support among black people. Let's see if that's true.\"\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8250897047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:12:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:12:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:11:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://newsone.com/5444594/nabj-defends-trump-invite-convention-chicago/", "title": "NABJ Leader Defends Inviting Trump To Black Journalists Convention Ami", "body": "NewsOne Featured Video CLOSE\n\nDonald Trump speaks during a rally at Herb Brooks National Hockey Center on July 27, 2024, in St Cloud, Minnesota. | Source: Stephen Maturen / Getty\n\nA reporter and leader with the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) is defending the organization's decision to invite Donald Trump to appear at its annual convention in the face of growing outrage from members.\n\nNABJ announced late Monday night in a press release that it would host Trump on its convention's opening day on Wednesday in Chicago.\n\n\"Trump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" the press release said in part.\n\nTrump's appearance is set to be moderated by ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba and, controversially, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner.\n\nThe outrage was swift and spread quickly, particularly among some of its more influential dues-paying members who said on social media in no uncertain terms that the decision to provide Trump with a platform to speak directly to Black journalists - a group he has long maligned - was not a good idea.\n\nThat is nothing to speak for the open disdain Trump has generally demonstrated toward Black women for years.\n\nJournalist Carron J. Phillips notably called out NABJ as being \"idiotic\" in a series of social media posts.\n\n\"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have, potentially unsafe, all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else,' when this is....idiotic at best,\" Phillips posted on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nThat post followed another from Phillips in which he claimed inviting Trump is \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history. Whoever made this call is an idiot. And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and the chairperson of NABJ's Political Task Force, responded to Phillips' first post by identifying herself as someone who \"helped make this call.\"\n\nMitchell went on to defend the decision to invite Trump to address Black journalists as a standing precedent that is \"in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades.\"\n\nNABJ's invitation to Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, is still pending, the group said.\n\nMitchell, who also addressed other posts critical of NABJ's decision to host Trump, vowed to \"continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next president.\"\n\nThat was likely no solace for Jim Trotter, NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year who called it such \"a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nThe Grio's April Ryan, who was named NABJ's 2017 Journalist of the Year, fully condemned the group hosting Trump.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025,\" Ryan wrote Tuesday in a statement posted to X, formerly Twitter. \"I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nRoland Martin, a former winner of NABJ's coveted Journalist of the Year Award who has been active within the organization for years, called out the organization for not choosing a Black male journalist to help moderate the event; what with the myriad reports suggesting Trump has made notable inroads with Black male voters.\n\nIt also can't be ignored that NABJ decided against any Black-owned and operated media participating in the event.\n\nAn email seeking comment from NABJ was not immediately returned.\n\nAdding to the outrage was NABJ President Ken Lemon's statement that predicted Trump -- a proven and habitual unabashed liar -- \"will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nMitchell and Lemon were not alone in their defense of NABJ.\n\nJemele Hill, NABJ's 2018 Journalist of the Year, suggested she understood NABJ's invitation to Trump - with whom she clashed in 2017 about the topic of white supremacy - and said she's \"not mad about him being there. If there is any room I'd want to see how he operates in, it's in the company of 3,000 Black journalists.\"\n\nHill suggested there could be a reaction similar to when NABJ hosted then-Trump aide Omarosa Manigault-Newman at its convention in New Orleans in 2017.\n\nThat was when several activists and journalists turned their backs on Manigault-Newman as she spoke during a panel discussion moderated by journalist Ed Gordon. The panel ended when Manigault-Newman walked off of the stage as then-NABJ President Sarah Glover explained why she was invited to speak.\n\nMeanwhile, Trump's campaign has already seized on the opportunity of the optics of him being surrounded by Black professionals by boasting about the NABJ invitation in a late-night email on Monday that was -- surprise! -- replete with lies.\n\n\"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history,\" a campaign press release says in part without substantiating such a claim with any quantifiable data. Instead, the press release goes on to state without proof that \"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has, including landmark unemployment rates for Black Americans, increased median income for Black households, historic permanent funding for HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), comprehensive bipartisan criminal justice reform, and nearly $50 billion in funds to revitalize Opportunity Zones.\"\n\n(To be sure, President Joe Biden has delivered the lowest Black unemployment rate on record; the Associated Press reported that \"Trump is exaggerating economic gains for African Americans during his administration;\" records show that Trump never requested increased funding for HBCUs during his presidency; the so-called First Step Act criminal justice reform bill signed by Trump \"never produced the spike in support from Black voters that he expected,\" Politico reported; and Trump's 2017 tax plan that created Opportunity Zones -- efforts meant to revitalize urban neighborhoods -- never achieved the desired economic growth in low-income communities and were exploited by investors, PBS reported.)\n\nBut as Trump has repeatedly demonstrated, facts don't matter when it comes to his rhetoric, which is in direct conflict with the foundation of journalism and its mission to report the truth.\n\nConsidering that coming collision of circumstances in Chicago, something's likely got to give on Wednesday.\n\nWhite Editor Goes Viral For Twitter Thread About Media Racism Black Journalists Face\n\nBlack Journalists Association Says CBS Must Change 'Toxic Culture'\n\nA Timeline Of Trump's Unprovoked Attacks On Black Women 12 photos", "source": {"uri": "newsone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News One"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bruce_c_t_wright@newsone.com", "name": "Bruce C.T.
