{"uri": "8251221969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:19:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jul/30/black-journalists-trump-nabj-panel", "title": "Journalists react to Trump joining NABJ panel: 'irresponsible' and 'vulnerable'", "body": "Many criticize the decision as threatening what's supposed to be a safe space for Black journalists\n\nOn Monday night, the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) announced that Donald Trump will participate in a panel discussion at the organization's annual convention in Chicago, which starts Wednesday.\n\nThe announcement, which said that the Q&A will \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community\", was met with swift online backlash from some Black journalists. They decried the decision to invite a presidential candidate who has lambasted Black journalists, led a movement to squash diversity, equity and inclusion efforts and who is responsible for increased anti-journalistic sentiment, including the popularization of the term \"fake news\" to describe factual, but potentially unflattering, reporting.\n\nTiffany Walden, a co-founder and editor-in-chief of The TriiBE, a digital platform that focuses on Black Chicago, told the Guardian that NABJ's decision was \"irresponsible\".\n\n\"We've watched Trump threaten to send the feds here when he was in office,\" Walden said. \"We've watched him use Chicago as a dog whistle in all of his campaign's materials during his first run for office. He talked about Chicago having top gang thugs. So this puts the city of Chicago and its residents in a very vulnerable position. It also puts Black journalists in a very vulnerable position at a convention that's supposed to be a safe space for them.\"\n\nAmeshia Cross, a political analyst, echoed this sentiment on X: \"The same Trump that attacked Black journalists from the stump. The same Trump who is attacking DEI, can't get ahead of his own racism and sexism. And the guy who wants to dissolve journalism as we know it, that's who is speaking at #NABJ24 w/ record attendance. C'mon yall.\"\n\nAnother journalist, Carron J Phillips, called the move \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history\".\n\nThe outcry led to NABJ president Ken Lemon and others defending the decision, saying that Black reporters should have the opportunity to question a political candidate.\n\n\"Every year, every presidential election cycle, we invite the presidential candidates to come,\" Lemon said to NABJ student journalists on Tuesday. \"We extend that to anyone who is a nominee and in this case we have two presumptive nominees. We invited both of them ... This is an important hour. We have people whose lives are depending on what happens in November ... This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground.\"\n\nKamala Harris is scheduled to speak elsewhere on Wednesday, when Trump will be at NABJ, but her confirmation to attend this year's convention, which lasts through Sunday, is \"pending\", according to NABJ.\n\nTia Mitchell, the chair of NABJ's political journalism task force and a Washington correspondent at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X: \"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades. But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\" (Mitchell, NABJ and NABJ's Chicago chapter did not respond to requests for comment.)\n\nWednesday's panel will be moderated by Rachel Scott, a senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, who anchors \"The Faulkner Focus\" and \"Outnumbered\" for FOX News; and Kadia Goba, a politics reporter for Semafor.\n\n\"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump,\" Jemele Hill, a contributing reporter for the Atlantic, wrote on X. \"The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such. Being questioned by journalists is part of the job, and especially important in the company of Black journalists. Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nBut the journalist Matthew Wright pushed back on the notion that there is anything productive in questioning Trump.\n\n\"What does that serve?\" Wright said to the Guardian. \"We literally just watched him talk to Laura Ingraham [who] was trying to get him to answer different questions, but he practically played evasive of action even then. If a super conservative white woman can't get straight answers out of him, what makes you think that three black women are going to get them?\"\n\nIn a statement about the NABJ appearance, Trump's campaign wrote: \"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\" Some journalists used this statement as evidence that NABJ's decision to platform the former president was harmful, and would lead to further perpetuation of falsehoods.\n\n\"This is the way 45 is touting his appearance before @nabj this week. Was this what you wanted [Tia Mitchell]? He is already lying and he isn't even in Chicago yet. This is your legacy,\" April Reign, a media strategist, wrote on X.\n\nThe timing of the panel announcement - less than 48 hours before the convention's start - also drew concern from NABJ members.\n\nShamira Ibrahim, a culture writer, told the Guardian that she was shocked by the decision.\n\n\"It puts everyone in a really bad position,\" Ibrahim said. \"You already paid your convention fees, you already paid for a hotel that's likely not refundable at this point, flights are likely difficult to get replaced. Even if you have a moral opposition to it or an ethical opposition to it, you're kind of already stuck in whatever plan you made.\"\n\nNABJ's annual convention has allowed Black journalists a space to fellowship and gather safely since the organization's founding in 1975, with some reporters likening it to a family reunion. Inviting Trump, Ibrahim said, undermines that sense of community.\n\n\"NABJ is primarily not just a place for journalists to get opportunities to interview politicians, but also a place for black journalists to network, to have open conversations about things that are happening in the industry, to attend panels, and really get a sense of how to shift in a very, very volatile, fragile space,\" she continued.\n\n\"Inviting someone who, one, has made targeted attacks on black journalists, two, has actively been responsible in defunding programs that help build Black journalists, and three, has publicly attacked the Black press flies in the face of any sort of fidelity convention.\"\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, a coalition of organizations, including Chicago Alliance Against Racist & Political Repression and Anti-War Committee Chicago, announced plans to rally outside the convention to \"tell Trump he's not welcome in Chicago\".", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-07-438912513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:33:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:33:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:19:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.wsiltv.com/news/consumer/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_8b79ff09-6e0d-5897-8baf-de1cad423e34.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "New York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8251160871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:29:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:29:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:28:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://baynews9.com/fl/tampa/news/2024/07/30/trump-black-journalists--convention-chicago", "title": "Trump attending Black journalists' convention in Chicago", "body": "Former President Donald Trump is planning to attend the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention in Chicago on Wednesday.\n\nIn a statement released Monday night, the Trump campaign said the Republican presidential nominee would participate in a question and answer session \"that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\" The session will be moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba, per the NABJ.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ president Ken Lemon wrote on social media.\n\nTrump's campaign has spent months scheduling appearances in areas outside his traditional strongholds of support, including when he attended -- and was roundly booed at -- the Libertarian Party convention in Washington earlier this year.\n\nIn its announcement, the campaign trumpeted Trump policies that it argued benefited Black Americans during his first term.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has seen his favorability rate among Black voters fall dramatically since he took office in 2021. But the race against Trump has been shaken up since the president stepped aside and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris -- who would be the first Black woman and the first South Asian American to be elected president if she wins in November.\n\nThe announcement sparked backlash, with a co-chair of this year's convention announcing they were stepping down on Tuesday.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah wrote on social media, adding: \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved At the convention, he plans to engage in a question-and-answer question with political journalists in front of an audience.\n\nThe topic: concentrate on the \"most pressing issues facing the Black community.\" The event will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of \"Outnumbered\" on Fox News, and Kadia Goba, politics reporter for Semafor.\n\nRead also: Kamala Harris vows to debate Trump's empty podium if he skips September debate\n\nThe news raised eyebrows on the social media app X.\n\n\"As someone who's been at NABJ when Omarosa [Manigault] was interviewed, I'm going to guess this won't go well for Trump,\" wrote Adrian Carrasquillo on X.\n\nHe was referring to the former White House aide's chilly reception, including being asked how she could \"sit in a White House\" while the former president appeared to support police brutality.\n\n\"Are you suggesting that I just walk away?\" Manigault asked at the time.\n\nShe continued, \"I'm not going to stand here and defend every single word and decision. I still have my story - you're dismissing my family story.\"\n\n\"Can't wait for him to implode in contradictions, incoherence and 'I don't know anything about it, but I like it,'\" chided {"uri": "8251123070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:57:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:57:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:56:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://redstate.com/jenniferoo/2024/07/30/more-blacks-resisting-the-narrative-national-assoc-of-black-journalists-hosts-conversation-with-trump-n2177533", "title": "More Blacks Resisting the Narrative: National Assoc. of Black Journalists Hosts Conversation With Trump", "body": "The opinions expressed by contributors are their own and do not necessarily represent the views of RedState.com.\n\nAs I covered extensively on Saturday, the dam is breaking in terms of Blacks and their presumed lockstep support of the Democrat Party. This is particularly prescient among Black men, who have become quite vocal about no longer supporting the party and its aims, which are counter to their concerns and issues. Fox Digital interviewed attendees at a July 27 Grand Rapids, MI, Trump Rally, and they sounded off about what the Democrat Party gets wrong about them.\n\nWATCH:\n\nSomething else is causing a stir among the Black intelligentsia. Some are highly upset that the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) plans to have a conversation with former President and GOP nominee Donald Trump at their annual Convention & Career Fair in Chicago.\n\nNABJ president Ken Lemon made it clear that this is nothing out of the norm -- for decades, the NABJ has invited presidential candidates from both sides of the aisle to attend. Some have chosen to attend, while others have not. Vice President and selected Democrat nominee for president Kamala Harris was also invited. The NAJB said in their announcement that her confirmation is \"pending.\" So, this conversation is not an endorsement of Trump or any other candidate, but an opportunity for a group of small outlet and large outlet journalists to dig into facts and information on issues that matter to Black Americans and present those to their readers and followers, as opposed to relying on the major newsfeeds like AP and Reuters.\n\nWhile NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\n\nThe NABJ convention opens on Wednesday, July 31, and they will host the Trump conversation at 12:00 p.m. Central Time.\n\nFormer U.S. President Donald J. Trump will participate in a conversation with journalists at the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) Annual Convention & Career Fair during its opening day in Chicago on Wednesday, July 31, at noon CST.\n\nTrump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\n\nThe event will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor.\n\nThe three Black female journalists moderating the discussion represent Left, Right, and independent or centrist journalism. So, where's the problem? Well, the fact that Fox News senior correspondent and Faulkner Focus host Harris Faulkner isn't considered a serious journalist by certain members of the NABJ. And even though the announcement clearly states there will be a Q&A for other journalists to submit their questions, the hue and cry of \"Trump lies,\" \"Trump is evil,\" ad infinitum has populated the comments and replies on the NABJ Headquarters X announcement. The event hasn't even happened yet, and the gatekeepers of Democrat orthodoxy are eliciting their displeasure. How dare the NABJ have a sit down with a convicted felon and insurrectionist?\n\nBringing Trump's evil into a Black safe space? Clutch the pearls!\n\nThis Auntie is all types of confused over this move, not to mention appalled.\n\nThe last time I checked, that used to be what journalists did: amplify the news on presidential candidates so that every voter, no matter what their political leanings, is informed. \"Pulitzer nominee\" Carron J. Phillips really let it be known that whoever organized this lacks intellectual muster.\n\nAtlanta Journal-Constitution Washington Correspondent Tia Mitchell was a co-organizer and clapped back at Phillips.\n\nI helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades. But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\n\nAs she should, because this is called responsible journalism. But some people refuse to be placated and are entrenched in their indoctrination.\n\nI understand the concerns about Trump. Which is why we selected a group of badass journalists to ask him questions, creating a rare opportunity to dig into his vision for America and ask Qs. We cannot ignore someone who could be the next leader of the free world.\n\nIt is telling that after the announcement went out on Monday and the kerfuffle that followed, Mitchell has locked down her account.\n\nDr. Nikki Johnson called it as she saw it. The elites, Black or otherwise, are not happy about Black people being informed.\n\nMost surprising, the editor-in-chief of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution had Mitchell's back. It should not be a point of controversy and debate that a leading presidential candidate is allowed a platform where journalists get to ask him questions and he answers them. It should be the norm. When did we lose sight of that?\n\nThe event will not be open to the public but will be live-streamed on the National Association of Black Journalist's YouTube channel and Facebook page.\n\nThe other recent development comes from Black Twitter and a more vocal contingent of Black male conservatives who were appalled by the White Dudes for Kamala Harris call on Monday night. So, they decided to mount their own ZOOM call on Tuesday night titled: \"Black People Against Kamala Harris.\"\n\nAllegedly Over 50,000 people joined the White Dudes For Kamala Zoom from all across the country. We are fighting this propaganda to show them what real support is. We encourage you to join the influential Black Women and Men in this call to prove that majority of America is against Kamala Harris.\n\nExpected to join the call are Judge Joe Brown, actor and activist Isaiah Washington, founder of the X School for Boys King Randall, Veteran and activist Billy Ray Todd, FL District 24 candidate Lavern Spicer, Veteran and podcaster Rob Smith, and a number of other prominent and lesser-known Black conservative voices.\n\nWe are honored to have you join us in securing this election, they have the LIES but we have the NUMBERS.\n\nOnly time will tell whether the outcry matches the number of actual voters and which candidate will benefit from this engagement. But know this: it is no longer business as usual for Blacks in the political space.", "source": {"uri": "redstate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Redstate"}, "authors": [{"uri": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.islandpacket.com/news/politics-government/article290572929.html", "title": "Black journalists association defends decision to invite Trump to speak at conference", "body": "The National Association of Black Journalists is defending its decision to invite former President Donald Trump to speak at their annual conference this Wednesday in Chicago in spite of criticism from several prominent Black journalists.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon called the event an opportunity to hear \"former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most.\"\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization,\" Lemon said in a statement, \"we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nModerated by ABC News' Rachel Scott, Fox News' Harris Faulkner and Semafor's Kadia Goba, the event will kick off 12 p.m. CST on the opening day of the conference, which runs July 31 to Aug. 4.\n\nThe announcement has caused controversy down to the selection of the moderators.\n\n\"Not a single Black media organization is on the panel,\" university lecturer and culture journalist Arionne Nettles wrote on X, later adding \"please don't claim to give 'opportunities' to anyone but those who would already have them.\"\n\nWednesday's event won't be open to the public, though registered attendees can go and also have the opportunity to ask Trump questions.\n\nSeveral Black journalists took to X, the app formerly known as Twitter, after NABJ made the announcement on Monday evening.\n\n\"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have potentially unsafe all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else' when this is idiotic at best,\" award-winning sports journalist Carron J. Phillips wrote, calling Trump's appearance \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history.\"\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" 2017 NABJ journalist of the year April Ryan wrote. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee.\"\n\nWhile many journalists have voiced criticism, others, like the Atlanta Journal Constitution's Tia Mitchell and Jemele Hill, pointed to the precedence. As NABJ noted in its press release, Presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama, and Bill Clinton have all attended previous conferences.\n\n\"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump,\" Hill wrote on X. \"The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such. Being questioned by journalists is part of the job, and especially important in the company of Black journalists. Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nAdded Mitchell: \"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades. But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nIn the Trump campaign's announcement about the NABJ event, it noted how he \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history by implementing America First policies on the economy, immigration, energy, law and order, and foreign policy.\" It's a claim that Trump has touted since his 2020 campaign, though a Washington Post fact check called these assertions unfounded.\n\n\"The claim that Trump has exceeded every other president since Lincoln earned only derision from prominent historians,\" Washington Post reporter Glenn Kessler wrote in 2020. \"Instead, they said Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed into law the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, is clearly the president who had the most lasting impact on the lives of African Americans.\"\n\nIt's unclear whether Vice President and presumptive Democratic nominee Kamala Harris will also attend the conference, however, the chatter on X seems to indicate that an invite has been extended.", {"uri": "8251418612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:20:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13690825/A-speaking-invitation-Donald-Trump-splits-prominent-American-group-Black-journalists.html", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we\u00b4re doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn\u00b4t a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It\u00b4s a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nRepublican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally, Saturday, July 27, 2024, in St. Cloud, Minn. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization\u00b4s constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on National Association of Black Journalists Convention", "body": "(Reuters) - Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign on Monday said he would attend a question-and-answer session at the National Association of Black Journalists annual convention this week in Chicago.\n\nFormer US President Trump, who has been courting Black voters and whose campaign has been encouraged by some polling showing he may be gaining ground with that group of the electorate, will speak with political journalists before an audience of registered attendees on Wednesday.\n\nThe event is closed to the public, but it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, NABJ said in a statement.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ president Ken Lemon.\n\nLemon went on to say that the Trump event would allow Black journalists in attendance \"to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nTrump's campaign said in a written statement that the event \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nThe NABJ said in its statement that fellow presidential candidate Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate in this year's convention, but that her confirmation is pending.\n\n(Reporting by Brad Brooks in Longmont, Colorado; Editing by Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, {"uri": "8251351742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:10:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:10:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:09:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://hiphopwired.com/playlist/nabj-national-convention-donald-trump-reactions/", "title": "NABJ Under Fire After Inviting Donald Trump To Annual Convention, Xitt", "body": "The National Association of Black Journalists, widely known as the NABJ, is having its annual convention in Chicago this week but the longstanding organization is contending with a larger matter at the moment. After it was announced that Republican Party presidential nominee Donald Trump would be in attendance for a Q&A session with Black journalists, observers on X lashed out at the NABJ in outrage.\n\nOn Monday (July 29), NABJ officials confirmed that Donald Trump would be attending the opening day of the convention and job fair event, which will not be open to the public but will air online via streaming. Trump did not attend the convention during his four years as president so his inclusion this year raised concerns among some.\n\nThe decision to give Trump a platform for his policy messaging ahead of the November elections was seen as an affront to Black women journalists and Black people in general considering Trump's public record of pointed attacks at Black members of the press.\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and member of the NABJ's Political Task Force, defended the inclusion of Trump via X after the organization received heavy pushback.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades, Mitchell wrote in response to one user decrying the Trump session. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nMitchell has since made her X account private after a deluge of comments under her reply.\n\nThe issue has developed into a public relations disaster for the association, but NABJ President Ken Lemon did clear up any confusion surrounding chatter that Vice President Kamala Harris was not invited.\n\nYes we did ask both candidates. Every presidential election year we ask the nominees to attend, Lemon wrote to someone asking a question on X, pinning the reply at the top of his feed.\n\nPart of the fallout includes journalist Karen Attiah resigning as co-chair of NABJ, though still plans to attend.\n\nOn X, the decision to give Donald Trump a political platform is being widely discussed. {"uri": "8251174999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:40:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:40:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:40:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/style/media/2024/07/30/black-journalists-group-announces-trump-interview-sparking-backlash/", "title": "Black journalists' group announces Trump interview, sparking backlash", "body": "The former president and 2024 Republican presidential nominee will be interviewed Wednesday by three journalists -- ABC senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba and Fox News host Harris Faulkner -- \"on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" NABJ said in a news release late Monday.\n\nThe organization said it also invited Vice President Harris but \"her confirmation is pending.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, the 2019 NABJ journalist of the year, announced Tuesday she would step down as convention co-chair.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she wrote on social media. (Attiah is a Washington Post columnist who works for the Opinions division of The Post, which operates separately from its news coverage.)\n\nOther journalists raised objections as well. The Grio's April Ryan -- who clashed repeatedly with the then-president during her time as a White House correspondent -- wrote that the invitation was \"a slap in the face to the Black women journalists\" who were verbally attacked by Trump.\n\nNABJ is the most prominent association representing Black journalists; the nonprofit says it has more than 4,000 members.\n\nSome criticized what they portrayed as NABJ's \"normalizing\" of Trump by hosting him or the fact that the group did not make the announcement earlier. The choice of Faulkner, who has previously conducted interviews with Trump for Fox News that critics saw as soft and less than challenging, also drew complaints.\n\nThe Trump campaign used the invitation to boast about its purported support among Black voters. Recent national polls found between 15 and 19 percent of Black voters supported Trump against Harris.\n\nOthers, though, defended the event as part of the group's mission in journalism.\n\n\"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did,\" Symone Sanders-Townsend, an MSNBC host who is a former Harris spokeswoman, wrote on social media.\n\n\"Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nRepresentatives for NABJ and Harris did not immediately respond to The Posts's inquiries.\n\nNABJ invites major party presidential candidates during every election year, president Ken Lemon said in a video shared by NABJ Monitor. He said conversations began with both party's then-presumptive candidates more than a month ago.\n\nLemon said the Trump invitation did not amount to an endorsement and called it a \"great opportunity to vet the candidate right here on our ground.\" He added that they expect panelists to fact-check Trump in real time, noting the convention theme is \"Winds of Change: Journalism Over Disinformation.\"\n\n\"It is our jobs as journalist to have those uncomfortable conversations so that the people who count on us to inform them get information from the source,\" he said. \"It is our job also to offer that opportunity for those candidates to be here, and not doing that would not be the right thing.\"\n\nAccording to NABJ, former presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have previously attended NABJ conventions.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438793650", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:28:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:28:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2024-07-30/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists", "title": "A Speaking Invitation to Donald Trump Splits the Most Prominent American Group for Black Journalists", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8251729984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:30:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:30:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:29:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/trumps-nabj-invitation-splits-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists/articleshow/112154125.cms", "title": "Trump's NABJ invitation splits most prominent American group for Black journalists - Times of India", "body": "Donald Trump's upcoming appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) convention has ignited a storm of controversy within the organization and across social media platforms. The decision to invite Trump, who will be interviewed in Chicago on Wednesday by Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News, and Harris Faulkner of Fox News, has created a rift among NABJ members and raised questions about the association's role and priorities.\n\nNABJ's tradition of inviting presidential candidates to address its summer convention during election years is intended to offer its members an opportunity to engage with key figures in the political landscape.However, Trump's acceptance of the invitation has provoked a significant backlash, leading to the resignation of high-profile members and a heated debate about the organization's values and objectives.\n\nTrump's relationship with NABJ has been fraught with tension. The former president has a history of disparaging Black journalists, including Yamiche Alcindor of NBC News, Abby Phillip of CNN, and April Ryan of The Grio. In 2018, NABJ condemned Trump's derogatory comments about these journalists, with then-President Sarah Glover calling his remarks \"appalling, irresponsible, and should be denounced.\"\n\nIn response to Trump's planned appearance, Karen Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, resigned as a co-chair of the 2024 NABJ convention. Attiah expressed her dissatisfaction on social media, stating that she was not consulted about the decision to include Trump and criticized the move as undermining the organization's mission. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" Attiah wrote.\n\nThe invitation has also sparked debate about whether hosting Trump might lend him undue credibility or be interpreted as an endorsement. NABJ President Ken Lemon has defended the decision, asserting that the event is not an endorsement but an opportunity to hold a significant figure accountable. \"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case, this is an important hour.\"\n\nCritics within the organization argue that allowing Trump to speak at the convention could compromise the space NABJ has cultivated as a supportive and safe environment for Black journalists. Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member, expressed concerns in The TRiiBE, writing, \"NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated.\"\n\nOn the other hand, some industry leaders and NABJ members believe that engaging with presidential candidates, even controversial ones, is a crucial part of journalism's role in holding powerful figures accountable. Rana Cash, executive editor of the Charlotte Observer, defended the decision, stating, \"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous.\"\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. 29, 2024 11:09 PM EDT Updated 10 hours ago\n\nJuly 29 (Reuters) - Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's campaign on Monday said he would attend a question-and-answer session at the National Association of Black Journalists annual convention this week in Chicago.\n\nFormer US President Trump, who has been courting Black voters and whose campaign has been encouraged by some polling showing he may be gaining ground with that group of the electorate, will speak with political journalists before an audience of registered attendees on Wednesday.\n\nThe event is closed to the public, but it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, NABJ said in a statement.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" said NABJ president Ken Lemon.\n\nLemon went on to say that the Trump event would allow Black journalists in attendance \"to ask the tough questions that will {"uri": "2024-07-438830593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:33:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:33:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:26:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://wgntv.com/news/chicago-news/trump-nabj-convention-chicago/", "title": "NABJ convention in Chicago: Trump's visit stirs controversy and debate", "body": "CHICAGO - Former President and Republican Presidential Nominee Donald Trump will attend the National Association of Black Journalists convention Wednesday in Chicago, where he will participate in a conversation with journalists and engage in a Q&A with political journalists.\n\nTrump's visit has raised eyebrows and divided NABJ members, while renewing scrutiny of his treatment of the press, particularly journalists of color.\n\nDuring his presidency, Trump famously bashed CNN's Abby Phillip for asking \"stupid questions\" and accused NBC's Yamiche Alcindor of asking a \"racist\" question. He also called New York Times reporter April Ryan \"a loser.\"\n\n\"Sometimes there is no two sides. There's the truth and there's lies,\" said Maudelyn Ihejirika, a retired columnist for the Chicago Sun-Times and a former president of NABJ Chicago.\n\nIhejirika called Trump's invite a shock to the system.\n\n\"He draws a white supremist audience and following, and this is the type of following that inviting him could infiltrate, be welcomed by this particular candidate to a Black journalist convention,\" Ihejirika said.\n\nInfluential journalists posted some blunt takes on social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\n\"I would like to unwelcome @NABJ for surprising Chicago with this Trump news, a man who has threatened Chicago with state violence in his stump speeches -- and attracts a white supremacist following to a Black affinity space,\" wrote Morgan Elise Johnson of The Tribe.\n\nFrom April Ryan: \"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact. To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025. I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nOne of the convention co-chairs, Karen Attiah, even announced Tuesday she was stepping down.\n\nHowever, many see value in Trump's appearance at the convention.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon posted: \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nAhead of the former president's visit, city officials are stepping up security.\n\n\"We're going to be prepared as a city if he decides to actually arrive in Chicago, to make sure that the nastiness and the iniquitousness formation that he brings that that doesn't stain the soul of Chicago,\" Mayor Brandon Johnson said.\n\nOn the eve of Trump's visit, his campaign distanced itself from Project 2025, a Heritage Foundation document laying out plans for the next conservative administration.\n\nSaid the campaign, \"Reports of Project 2025's demise would be greatly welcomed and should serve as notice to anyone or any group trying to misrepresent their influence with President Trump and his campaign -- it will not end well for you.\"\n\nChicago organizers have announced a protest against Trump outside the NABJ convention. In 2016, demonstrators forced him to cancel a rally at the University of Illinois Chicago.\n\nMeanwhile on the Democratic side, likely nominee Kamala Harris so far has not accepted an invitation to address NABJ. She is, however, reportedly close to naming a running mate.\n\nAccording to Reuters, Harris and her pick for vice president will hit the campaign trail next week.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", {"uri": "8251917167", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:06:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:06:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2808378/", "title": "Donald Trump to visit Chicago: 2024 NABJ convention co-chair Karen Attiah resigns after Trump speech announced - ExBulletin", "body": "CHICAGO (WLS) -- The co-chair of the National Association of Black Journalists convention has resigned a day after it was announced that former President Donald Trump would address the group in Chicago.\n\nTrump will participate in a panel discussion at the NABJ convention on Wednesday. On Tuesday, convention co-chair Karen Attiah announced she would resign.\n\nABC7 Chicago is now available to stream 24/7. Click here to watch\n\nAttiah wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, that \"while my decision was influenced by various factors, I was not involved or consulted in any way in the decision to present Trump in such a format.\"\n\nThe convention will run from July 31 to Aug. 4 at the Hilton Chicago, located at 720 South Michigan Avenue in the South Loop. The NABJ website says the event is a conference on journalism education, career development, networking and innovation.\n\nTrump's campaign and the NABJ announced that he will participate in a question-and-answer session with political journalists in front of an audience of convention attendees that will focus on the most pressing issues facing the black community. It will take place Wednesday at noon.\n\nABC News Senior Congressional Correspondent Rachel Scott will moderate the event with The Faulkner Focus anchor Harris Faulkner, who is also co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News, and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nThe event will not be open to the general public, but will be streamed live via NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the organization said.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing former President Trump speak on the critical issues that matter most to our members and their audiences,\" said NABJ President Ken Lemon. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work our members do and welcome the opportunity to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nIllinois Gov. JB Pritzker released a statement on Trump's visit, saying, \"Every time Donald Trump visits the Midwest, he tells us how much he hates the region. He's called Milwaukee horrible. He's called Detroit corrupt. He's trashed the Chicago police. His visit to Chicago tomorrow will undoubtedly be another attempt to distract from his struggling campaign, with as many lies as there are vacancies at Trump Tower.\"\n\nTrump will then travel to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, for a rally.\n\nLast week, Trump also revealed plans to return to Butler, Pennsylvania, for the first time since his assassination attempt. A date for that rally has not been announced.\n\nCopyright 2024 WLS-TV. {"uri": "8251244612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:40:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:40:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:39:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2024/07/30/donald-trump-chicago-visit-national-association-of-black-journalists-backlash", "title": "Trump Chicago visit sparks internal and external backlash from Black journalist group", "body": "The National Association of Black Journalists is enduring internal and external backlash over its last minute announcement that it would host former President Donald Trump at their annual conference on Wednesday in Chicago.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday night announced he would participate in a question-and-answer session with political journalists at the conference at the Hilton Chicago. The campaign said it will \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon wrote on social media, \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nBy Tuesday morning, the conference's co-chair, Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah, announced on X that she was stepping down from her role.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote.\n\nSome NABJ members and members of the media say Trump's treatment towards Black reporters during his presidential term should disqualify him from participating. Others are upset about the timing of the announcement -- two days before the five-day convention began, and as many members were already traveling to Chicago for the event.\n\nInvestigative journalist Taylor Moore wrote on X, \"Really cynical for someone to say 'no one is forcing you to go' when the announcement was made two days before the convention....Feeling really bad for all the journalists flying in who didn't consent to PAY to be in the same room as him.\"\n\nMorgan Elise Johnson, co-founder of the Triibe, wrote, \"I would like to unwelcome @NABJ for surprising Chicago with this Trump news, a man who has threatened Chicago with state violence in his stump speeches--and attracts a white supremacist following to a Black affinity space.\"\n\nThe event will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Harris Faulkner of FOX News and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor. Goba interviewed Trump earlier this year, and Faulkner sat down with Trump earlier this month.\n\nIn a statement, Semafor defended Goba's participation: \"As a politics reporter, Kadia has conducted tough, fair interviews with high-ranking figures across the political spectrum, including the former president. We look forward to hearing his answers tomorrow.\"\n\nOthers also defended the event, including Symone Sanders-Townsend, former senior adviser to Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\n\"Some of the best journalists in the country are members of NABJ. So, why wouldn't they interview Trump? He is the Republican nominee,\" Sanders-Townsend wrote on X. \"Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions.\"\n\nThe association routinely invites candidates of both parties during election years. Vice President Kamala Harris was invited after it became clear she would likely become the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, Lemon said. There was no indication yet that Harris would accept the invitation.\n\nSpeaking on WBEZ's \"Reset\" with Sasha-Ann Simons, WBEZ's race, class and communities editor Natalie Moore called Trump's appearance a \"surprise.\"\n\n\"I know it was a shock for me and then immediately -- what does this mean for the organization?\" Moore said. \"What does it mean for the members for him to come?\"\n\nMoore also questioned how the Trump footage might be used for his campaign, and why reporters from Black-owned media weren't asked to participate.\n\n\"I think that members want some answers from NABJ leadership,\" Moore said. \"Yes, we know the invite went out, but how did this panel come about? And again, my question is, were there any negotiations with Trump?\"\n\nAlso on WBEZ, Tiffany Walden, another co-founder of The Triibe, said, \"the city itself has ran Trump out of the city in 2016.\" Trump canceled a Chicago rally during his campaign in 2016 after scuffles broke out in the UIC Pavilion. In 2019, Trump came to Chicago for his first presidential visit and disparaged the city, calling it \"embarrassing to us as a nation,\" at a police conference. Later, he was met by thousands of protesters outside Trump Tower during a fundraiser he hosted.\n\n\"It's very clear that he is not a person that is welcome here. So as Black journalists, to be the organization to roll out the red carpet... It's a different situation. I know that they invited presidential candidates before, including Republicans, but in this case, Trump is not a Republican,\" Walden said. \"He's not the average candidate. He's spewing harmful misinformation, disinformation and dog whistles about Black communities -- about some of the people that will be in that room.\"\n\nSpeaking at a Chicago Police Department graduation ceremony on Tuesday, Mayor Brandon Johnson also criticized Trump's visit and his previous behavior towards Black journalists. The mayor said the city, however, will be prepared for his visit.\n\n\"....The Black press has played an integral role in the transformation of our city here in Chicago but as well as our country and our world,\" Johnson said. \"We're gonna be prepared as a city if he decides to actually arrive in Chicago to make sure that the nastiness and the ... formation that he brings doesn't stain the soul of Chicago.\"\n\nThe Sun-Times contacted several NABJ members. All declined to comment. Representatives for ABC and Fox did not immediately respond to requests for comment.", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Sun-Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251464339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:16:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:16:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:15:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "http://blockclubchicago.org/2024/07/30/trump-at-black-journalism-conference-makes-members-feel-unsafe-some-nabj-attendees-say/", "title": "Trump At Black Journalism Conference 'Makes Members Feel Unsafe,' Some NABJ Attendees Say", "body": "CHICAGO -- Former President Donald Trump is set to attend Wednesday's kick-off celebration for the annual convention for Black journalists, sparking a firestorm from reporters questioning who decided to give the controversial candidate a platform and how the move aligns with the vision for the conference.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) Convention and Career Fair runs Wednesday-Sunday at the Hilton Chicago, 720 S. Michigan Ave. The annual event gives space for Black journalists from across the nation to network, convene and learn at themed panel discussions.\n\nNABJ leaders emailed members Monday evening to announce a Q&A event with Trump scheduled for Wednesday afternoon. The Republican presidential candidate will answer questions about \"the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" according to the announcement.\n\nRachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor, will moderate the discussion. Local publications were noticeably excluded from the bill.\n\nNational and local reporters blasted the decision on social media and questioned the timing of the announcement so close to the convention's start. A convention dedicated to uplifting Black media members will now potentially draw a national crowd and protestors in an already jam-packed weekend in the city while spotlighting a figure who helped coin the phrase \"fake news,\" they said.\n\nThe convention's theme this year is \"Winds of Change: Journalism Over Disinformation.\"\n\nNABJ leaders defended the decision, saying they typically invite presidential nominees from both major parties in an election year. Vice President and presumptive Democratic nominee Kamala Harris was invited, but reporter April Ryan reported Wednesday that NABJ leaders denied Harris' request for a virtual fireside chat during the convention.\n\nWashington Post columnist Karen Attiah resigned as co-chair of the 2024 convention Tuesday morning following the announcement.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" Attiah tweeted.\n\nTrump \"disparages Black journalists and works to discredit the work that journalists do every day,\" said Morgan Elise Johnson, co-founder and publisher of The TRiiBe, a digital publication reshaping the narrative of Black Chicago.\n\nRyan, the White House Correspondent and recipient of NABJ's 2017 \"Journalist of the Year\" award who reported on Harris' not attending the convention, shared a video of Trump attacking Black journalists on Twitter Tuesday.\n\n\"Leaders like Donald Trump who continuously show that they don't value the press, I just don't know why he got such an open invitation to come to this,\" Johnson said. \"That just shows how misaligned the leadership is with its members, and how they've made this decision that makes members feel unsafe.\"\n\nNABJ previously called out Trump for disrespecting Black, female journalists, demanding the then-president \"stop his verbal assault\" on reporters.\n\nTrump has also caused damage to Black queer and trans people -- \"including those who are journalists and members of NABJ,\" said Femi Redwood, chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ Task Force. The task force \"was not invited into conversations about hosting Trump,\" Redwood said on Twitter.\n\n\"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable, [they] will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him,\" Redwood said.\n\nPeople spent hundreds of dollars to attend the convention before NABJ announced the Trump panel, Johnson said.\n\nRegistration ranges from $300 to $450 for NABJ members and $500 to $600 for non-member journalists. Any member of the press can register to attend Trump's panel for free.\n\nJournalism is in a \"crisis\" where many reporters are underpaid, Johnson said. This decision \"could feel like a slap in the face\" to the media workers who scrounged up the money to pay for travel, hotel costs and more for the event, Johnson said.\n\nSafety is another concern for members attending the convention's kick-off event, Johnson said.\n\nDonald Trump famously canceled a Chicago rally during the 2016 election when attendees and protestors clashed. Local organizers have announced they will host a protest at the convention Wednesday.\n\nLollapalooza, a music festival that welcomes hundreds of thousands of people to the city, also begins Thursday in Grant Park, across the street from the convention site.\n\n\"This is a hostile environment at a very politically hot time right before the DNC where there's a lot of movement and organizing taking place in the city,\" Johnson said. \"There was a certain lack of care and concern about safety that is disappointing because we're going to be now subject to potentially over-policing and all types of security protocols where it takes away the family and communal vibe that NABJ is supposed to be for so many people.\"\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson tweeted the city is prepared to \"uphold safety\" during Trump's appearance Wednesday.\n\n\"My administration's values and practice are in complete opposition to former President Donald Trump's agenda, but I want the people of Chicago to know that City departments and agencies are fully prepared to uphold safety during his scheduled visit on Wednesday,\" the mayor said.\n\nTrump's panel is a \"double-edged sword,\" said Josh McGee, Chicago bureau chief and investigative reporter at MindSite News. McGee will host two panels at this year's convention.\n\nIt's important to hold people in power accountable and, if done properly, the young journalists attending Trump's event will witness that work in action, McGee said. But there were also many local Black journalists who could've moderated the event, McGee said.\n\nHaving a former candidate on the convention bill is \"newsworthy\" and draws eyes to the national celebration, but it's only fair if Harris was invited, too, McGee said.\n\nNABJ leaders said they typically invite presidential nominees from both parties in an election year.\n\nGiven the focus on misinformation, the association needs someone to fact-check Trump in real-time, \"otherwise, they're not keeping the promise of what this conference is about,\" McGee said.\n\n\"This is a collection of hundreds and thousands of media people, people good at their jobs,\" McGee said. \"NABJ made a promise with their headlines to talk about disinformation. They put the panel together, now let's see how they plan it. That's what's key to me.\"\n\nLeaders at The TriiBe saw the convention as \"an opportunity to build bridges and uplift the work that we do,\" Johnson said.\n\nJohnson will speak on the panel \"Leading Voices In Chicago's Black Storytelling\" on Thursday. The event is free and separate from NABJ's convention schedule.\n\nJournalists planned to speak about their experiences in the field at Thursday's event. That might change now, Johnson said.\n\n\"I think now that conversation needs to be a critique of where the Black press is today and whether we're operating like the legendary press of the past,\" Johnson said. \"It'll have a much more serious tone and function as a space for people to air their grievances with identity politics, assimilations into journalism, leaders of the Black press while calling us to think about who we are going to be.\"\n\nThe Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression plans to protest Trump's visit 11:30 a.m. Wednesday.\n\nTrump, a frequent critic of Chicago, rarely comes to the city that overwhelmingly voted for his opponents in the past two presidential elections.\n\nHe last came to town in 2019 to speak at a conference for the International Association of Chiefs of Police, criticizing Supt. Eddie Johnson and saying \"Afghanistan is a safer place\" than Chicago. Before that, he'd not held a public event in Chicago since protesters forced him to cancel a rally in March 2016.", "source": {"uri": "blockclubchicago.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Block Club Chicago"}, "authors": [{"uri": "atavia_reed@blockclubchicago.org", "name": "Atavia Reed", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harris_Faulkner", {"uri": "8251167218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:34:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:34:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:33:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/07/30/rooke-trump-kamala-harris-black-journalists/", "title": "ROOKE: Trump Continues To Outflank Kamala", "body": "Former President Donald Trump accepted an invitation to speak with black journalists in Chicago, outflanking Vice President Kamala Harris on what would have been an easy media appearance to prove she could handle the vigors of campaigning.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) announced that Trump accepted their invitation to speak with a panel of black journalists in Chicago around two weeks before the Democrat National Convention, which is set to take place in the same city. While Harris seems to be avoiding public media opportunities (she hasn't had a sit-down interview since her \"coronation\" as the presumptive Democrat nominee), Trump is taking them head-on.\n\nTrump agreed to sit with a panel at the NABJ Annual Convention & Career Fair moderated by \"Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor,\" NABJ announced.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\" (ROOKE: Media Didn't Learn A Single Lesson From Hiding Biden)\n\nWhile the general public cannot attend, the event will be live-streamed, allowing Trump to speak freely about his plans to fix the issues in black American communities. Harris has reportedly declined to speak at the panel, making her look scared to campaign. Soon, Americans will wonder if her avoidance of panels like this means that Democrats intend to run a basement campaign with her like they did President Biden in 2020.\n\nAlthough it was successful for Biden, times have changed. There is no national campaign fearmongering over COVID-19 to blame her public absence on; she isn't a senile old man who needs to be protected. The media sells Harris as the \"savior of Democracy\" (big D). If that were true, why is the supposed tyrant (Trump) willing to go into what would be a seemingly hostile event to campaign and Harris is not? (ROOKE: Swing-State Candidate Gives Republicans Clear-Cut Plan To End Kamala's Momentum)\n\nThere's a reason she's hiding. Trump's decision to attend the NABJ Annual Convention & Career Fair exposes her. Either she doesn't think she can handle the panel and come out unscathed, or her campaign staff has no faith in her.
