{"uri": "8251390903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:49:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.cjr.org/analysis/nabj-black-journalists-donald-trump.php", "title": "The National Association of Black Journalists booked Donald Trump. Many had strong feelings", "body": "On Monday evening, at 12 minutes past 9 p.m. local time in Chicago, the National Association of Black Journalists sent out an email, marked with a red square in the subject line to help it stand out in inboxes, informing the general membership that its annual convention would have a special guest speaker on Wednesday at noon: Donald Trump.\n\n\"My reaction was, Wait, this can't be real. This has to be a joke,\" Femi Redwood, NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force chair, told CJR. She has since been fielding messages from members of the task force expressing their confusion and dismay.\n\nOn Tuesday, the reaction spread quickly. Karen Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, announced on X that she was stepping down as this year's NABJ conference co-chair. \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" she posted.\n\nOthers took a different view. \"Some of the best journalists in the country are members of NABJ. So, why wouldn't they interview Trump.... Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" wrote Symone D. Sanders Townsend, cohost of the MSNBC show The Weekend. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did.\"\n\n\"As journalists we can never be afraid to tackle Trump,\" journalist Jemele Hill said, also on X. In a separate posting she added: \"I do think we might overestimate how much people know about what he plans to do in office.\"\n\nThese defenses of Trump's attendance missed a larger point, said Ernest Owens, a journalist and president of the Philadelphia Association of Black Journalists. In the past, he pointed out, NABJ has been critical of Trump's treatment of Black journalists and the press and have given a \"thumbs down\" award to Fox News.\n\n\"As an advocacy organization, you don't have to act like a newsroom, you can take a stance,\" Owens told CJR. \"For them to now weaponize journalism ethics to defend this circus, as an advocacy organization that does not have to do this, is irresponsible and intellectually dishonest,\" Owens added.\n\n\"I fully understand that journalists interview vile people as part of the job but a conference is not intended to be a regular day on the job\" wrote Jen\u00e9e Desmond-Harris, a writer and editor at Slate. \"You're not there for your beat.\"\n\n\"It was always billed to me as a family reunion,\" Redwood said of the annual conference. \"It's the place you can come where you don't have to explain certain things you have to explain in a newsroom.\" She said the gathering has always strived to be a safe space for Black journalists to develop skills, meet hiring managers and expand their networks. \"The question I would ask the organization is, 'How does this align with any of those things?'\" she said.\n\nMany others voiced their discontent online. April Ryan, the Grio's White House Correspondent and an MSNBC contributor, posted, \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee.\"\n\nKeith Boykin, an author and former White House aide, shared a video to X that included moments in which Trump insulted various Black journalists. The former president can be seen calling journalist April Ryan a \"loser,\" describing Don Lemon as the \"stupidest man on television,\" and accusing Yamiche Alcindor of asking racist questions. Boykin wondered whether the panel would ask Trump about these moments -- and accused one of the journalists interviewing Trump, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, of being \"in the tank for Trump.\" Faulkner will moderate alongside ABC News congressional correspondent Rachel Scott and Semafor political reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ's president Ken Lemon released a statement on Monday after the announcement: \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nOwens feels that the NABJ was merely seeking spectacle. \"There is this very messy opportunity -- one Trump, desperate to try to get in the face of Black people, and [the other] NABJ, thirsty for some level of relevance -- and so the two interests kind of, in a very weird, bizarre way, align,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "cjr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Columbia Journalism Review"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Association of Black Journalists"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Weeknd", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "The Weeknd"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journalist", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Journalist"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karen_Attiah", "type": {"uri": "8250741419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:33:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:33:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:33:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://newsone.com/5444594/nabj-defends-trump-event/", "title": "NABJ Leader Defends Inviting Trump To Black Journalists Convention Ami", "body": "NewsOne Featured Video CLOSE\n\nDonald Trump speaks during a rally at Herb Brooks National Hockey Center on July 27, 2024, in St Cloud, Minnesota. | Source: Stephen Maturen / Getty\n\nA reporter and leader with the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) is defending the organization's decision to invite Donald Trump to appear at its annual convention in the face of growing outrage from members.\n\nNABJ announced late Monday night in a press release that it would host Trump on its convention's opening day on Wednesday in Chicago.\n\n\"Trump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community,\" the press release said in part.\n\nTrump's appearance is set to be moderated by ABC News senior congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba and, controversially, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner.\n\nThe outrage was swift and spread quickly, particularly among some of its more influential dues-paying members who said on social media in no uncertain terms that the decision to provide Trump with a platform to speak directly to Black journalists - a group he has long maligned - was not a good idea.\n\nThat is nothing to speak for the open disdain Trump has generally demonstrated toward Black women for years.\n\nJournalist Carron J. Phillips notably called out NABJ as being \"idiotic\" in a series of social media posts.\n\n\"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have, potentially unsafe, all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else,' when this is....idiotic at best,\" Phillips posted on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nThat post followed another from Phillips in which he claimed inviting Trump is \"the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history. Whoever made this call is an idiot. And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and the chairperson of NABJ's Political Task Force, responded to Phillips' first post by identifying herself as someone who \"helped make this call.\"\n\nMitchell went on to defend the decision to invite Trump to address Black journalists as a standing precedent that is \"in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades.\"\n\nNABJ's invitation to Vice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, is still pending, the group said.\n\nMitchell, who also addressed other posts critical of NABJ's decision to host Trump, vowed to \"continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nThat was likely no solace for Jim Trotter, NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year who called it such \"a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nRoland Martin, a former winner of NABJ's coveted Journalist of the Year award who has been active within the organization for years, called out the organization for not choosing a Black male journalist to help moderate the event; what with the myriad reports suggesting Trump has made notable inroads with Black male voters.\n\nIt also can't be ignored that NABJ decided against any Black-owned and operated media participating in the event.\n\nAn email seeking comment from NABJ was not immediately returned.\n\nAdding to the outrage was NABJ President Ken Lemon's statement that predicted Trump -- a proven and habitual unabashed liar -- \"will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nMitchell and Lemon were not alone in their defense of NABJ.\n\nJemele Hill, NABJ's 2018 Journalist of the Year, suggested she understood NABJ's invitation to Trump - with whom she clashed in 2017 about the topic of white supremacy - and said she's \"not mad about him being there. If there is any room I'd want to see how he operates in, it's in the company of 3,000 Black journalists.\"\n\nHill suggested there could be a reaction similar to when NABJ hosted then-Trump aide Omarosa Manigault-Newman at its convention in New Orleans in 2017.\n\nThat was when several activists and journalists turned their backs on Manigault-Newman as she spoke during a panel discussion moderated by journalist Ed Gordon. The panel ended when Manigault-Newman walked off of the stage as then-NABJ President Sarah Glover explained why she was invited to speak.\n\nMeanwhile, Trump's campaign has already seized on the opportunity of the optics of him being surrounded by Black professionals by boasting about the NABJ invitation in a late-night email on Monday that was -- surprise! -- replete with lies.\n\n\"President Trump accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history,\" a campaign press release says in part without substantiating such a claim with any quantifiable data. Instead, the press release goes on to state without proof that \"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has, including landmark unemployment rates for Black Americans, increased median income for Black households, historic permanent funding for HBCUs (Historically Black Colleges and Universities), comprehensive bipartisan criminal justice reform, and nearly $50 billion in funds to revitalize Opportunity Zones.\"\n\n(To be sure, President Joe Biden has delivered the lowest Black unemployment rate on record; the Associated Press reported that \"Trump is exaggerating economic gains for African Americans during his administration;\" records show that Trump never requested increased funding for HBCUs during his presidency; the so-called First Step Act criminal justice reform bill signed by Trump \"never produced the spike in support from Black voters that he expected,\" Politico reported; and Trump's 2017 tax plan that created Opportunity Zones -- efforts meant to revitalize urban neighborhoods -- never achieved the desired economic growth in low-income communities and were exploited by investors, PBS reported.)\n\nBut as Trump has repeatedly demonstrated, facts don't matter when it comes to his rhetoric, which is in direct conflict with the foundation of journalism and its mission to report the truth.\n\nConsidering that coming collision of circumstances in Chicago, something's likely got to give on Wednesday.\n\nWhite Editor Goes Viral For Twitter Thread About Media Racism Black Journalists Face\n\nBlack Journalists Association Says CBS Must Change 'Toxic Culture'\n\nA Timeline Of Trump's Unprovoked Attacks On Black Women 12 photos", "source": {"uri": "newsone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News One"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bruce_c_t_wright@newsone.com", "name": "Bruce C.T. {"uri": "8251652347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:15:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:15:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:14:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_afa94b68-c10f-5880-a028-1c7d8e867ae2.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon Antiques showcased at Virginia Highlands Festival HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Versatile Elliott to see plenty of the field for Vikings Owens will be missed at annual Creeper Trail Ride to End Cancer Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better BHC SOFTBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: Muncy completes stellar career with state title at Rye Cove Drug probe leads to arrests, seizure of $1.9M of meth, fentanyl MLB: Evan Carter's back injury among Rangers concerns Badcock Furniture closing all its retail locations This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage PRO GOLF: Runner-up for Connor Creasy (Abingdon) in PGA Americas Tour tourney in Ottawa Candidate Cao meets with Republicans in Abingdon\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "2024-07-438579199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:52:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:52:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:51:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/4800387-nabj-conference-trump-speaking/", "title": "NABJ members divided over decision to allow Trump to speak at conference", "body": "The National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) announced late Monday evening that former President Trump will be speaking at the organization's annual conference this week in Chicago, sparking a furious debate among Black reporters.\n\nThough some said the event will offer Black journalists the opportunity to grill Trump on how he plans to address the most pressing issues facing Black Americans, others have expressed concerns over the former president's rhetoric both toward and around Black Americans.\n\nKen Lemon, NABJ's president, said that the organization understands \"the serious work of our members\" and that this will be \"the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nIt was a sentiment echoed by several other members of the organization, including Jemele Hill, a contributing writer for The Atlantic.\n\nHill said journalists can \"never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump.\"\n\n\"The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such,\" Hill posted on X. \"Being questioned by journalists is part of the job, and especially important in the company of Black journalists. Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nNABJ invitations to candidates are not new. In 2004, both George W. Bush and John Kerry spoke at the convention. In 2007, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton addressed the convention.\n\nVice President Harris was also invited to speak this year; her response is pending, according to the organization.\n\nTrump, who is hoping to win 20 percent of Black voter support this election, has already made several campaign stops in predominantly Black communities this cycle. He is now leaning into Wednesday's event.\n\nIn a press release announcing the event, Trump's campaign said he has \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history by implementing America First policies on the economy, immigration, energy, law and order, and foreign policy.\"\n\nThe Hill has reached out to Trump's campaign.\n\nTia Mitchell, Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said she helped make the call to invite Trump.\n\n\"I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next president,\" Mitchell added.\n\nBut Arionne Nettles, author of \"We are the Culture: Black Chicago's Influence on Everything,\" pointed out on X that not a single Black media organization is represented in the panel of moderators for the event. Instead, the conversation will be moderated by ABC's Rachel Scott, FOX News's Harris Faulkner and Semafor's Kadia Gibbs.\n\n\"Not even any Black orgs? On top of everything. So please don't claim to give 'opportunities' to anyone but those who would already have them,\" Nettles said.\n\nNettles is not the only critic of NABJ's decision to offer Trump a platform.\n\nOn Tuesday afternoon, Karen Attiah, a columnist for the Washington Post, announced she would be stepping down as co-chair of the convention.\n\n\"I have decided to step down as co-chair from this year's NABJ24 convention in Chicago,\" Attiah posted on X. \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck.\"\n\nAttiah continued: \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nApril Ryan, NABJ's 2017 Journalist of the Year, offered a harsh rebuke of the organization's decision, highlighting the treatment she received from Trump during his time in the White House.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" said Ryan, White House correspondent for theGrio.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025. I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago.\"\n\nRyan has been open about the treatment she faced from Trump during press conferences, including when she was repeatedly told to \"sit down\" and when the former president called her \"nasty\" and a \"loser.\"\n\nTrump has also previously gone after CNN's Abby Phillip, accusing her of asking \"a lot of stupid questions.\"\n\nOthers pointed out controversial statements Trump has made about the city of Chicago, a hub for Black journalism and the hometown of icons like Ida B. Wells.\n\n\"I would like to unwelcome @NABJ for surprising Chicago with this Trump news, a man who has threatened Chicago with state violence in his stump speeches-and attracts a white supremacist following to a Black affinity space,\" Morgan Elise Johnson, co-founder of The Triibe, a Black-led and focused newsroom in Chicago, posted on X.\n\nThe discussion has now bled into other areas, with non-journalist organizations offering a harsh condemnation of NABJ.\n\n\"NABJ has betrayed legacy of Ida B Wells,\" Cliff Albright, co-founder of Black Voters Matter, posted on X.", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "cheyanne_m_daniels@thehill.com", "name": "Cheyanne M. {"uri": "8251654240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:17:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:17:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:16:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_24d2f92d-0629-5ba2-9eb4-0e8cb85ff7ee.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says Rosie's Pub owner leaves beloved downtown business after 21 years REO Speedwagon, Loverboy to perform in Bloomington this fall 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Normal man pleads guilty, sentenced for reckless driving in crash that injured 2 students Funerals pending for July 27\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8251372986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:30:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:30:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:30:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists-6150977.html", "title": "World News | A Speaking Invitation to Donald Trump Splits the Most Prominent American Group for Black Journalists | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, Jul 31 (AP) Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organisation and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organisations for people of colour traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nAlso Read | US Presidential Elections 2024: Donald Trump is the Biggest Threat to Health, Welfare and Social Security Programmes, Says Kamala Harris Campaign.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 pm CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organisation turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nAlso Read | Food Poisoning in Japan: 1 Die, Over 140 Sick After Eating Grilled Eel.\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run.\n\nSome group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labelling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organisation's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X. The event, closed to the public but livestreamed, will tackle issues important to Black Americans. Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited but has yet to confirm.\n\nOn Monday, Donald Trump's campaign announced that the Republican presidential candidate would attend a question-and-answer session at the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) annual convention in Chicago this week. This move comes as Trump attempts to court Black voters, with some polls indicating he may be gaining ground within this demographic. Trump will engage with political journalists in front of registered attendees on Wednesday.\n\nWhile the event is closed to the public, it will be livestreamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, according to a statement from NABJ. 'We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,' said NABJ president Ken Lemon.\n\nHe added that the event would give Black journalists the opportunity to 'ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.' {"uri": "8251375612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:32:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/trump-nabj-conference-invite-black-journalists-rcna164327", "title": "Black journalist group sparks backlash for inviting Trump to its convention", "body": "Donald Trump on July 27 in St. Cloud, Minn.Stephen Maturen / Getty Images\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists is facing backlash after announcing Monday that Donald Trump would take part in a Q&A at the organization's annual convention.\n\nThe group announced the session late Monday, with the convention set to kick off Wednesday in Chicago. The former president will discuss issues facing the Black community through questions from ABC News, FOX News and Semafor journalists.\n\nThe announcement quickly prompted backlash from some Black journalists who said they were \"disgusted\" and expressed concerns over Trump's rhetoric toward Black people.\n\nOrganizers with the Black Voters Matter Fund, a voting rights advocacy group founded in 2016 amid Trump's ascent, called the decision \"unacceptable\" in a post on X on Tuesday.\n\n\"It's a slap in the face to every Black journalist and the communities we serve,\" the post read.\n\nMeanwhile, Washington Post columnist and global opinions editor Karen Attiah said Tuesday on X that she was stepping down from her position as co-chair of the convention. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she added in a follow-up post.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment from NBC News.\n\nLeaders in the organization defended the decision to host the Republican presidential nominee. NABJ President Ken Lemon said on social media that the organization invites the presidential nominees from both major parties every election year, and added that it had invited presumptive Democratic nominee Kamala Harris.\n\nHarris cited logistical reasons -- including attending the funeral for Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee and choosing a running mate -- for why she would not be able to the attend the convention this year, according to a source familiar with her plans. The source added that NABJ turned down Harris' offer of a virtual discussion or holding one at a later date.\n\nBoth George W. Bush and John Kerry spoke at the NABJ's 2004 convention, and Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton did so in 2007, according to The Hill. Clinton returned for a speech and news conference in 2016. President Joe Biden spoke at the virtual conference held in 2020; Trump did not.\n\nTia Mitchell, co-chair of the convention, echoed Lemon's explanation and said she had helped organize the Q&A \"to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nCritics said these explanations did not adequately address concerns from journalists and other NABJ members who balked at giving Trump such a high-profile platform at the convention, given his history, in their view, of emboldening white supremacists, racist rhetoric and laying the groundwork for education restrictions, anti-DEI legislation and anti-LGBTQ laws.\n\nVeteran White House correspondent April Ryan, the 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote in a post Tuesday on X that she objected to Trump's appearance in Chicago.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\nThe Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression, a justice organization, announced in an Instagram post that it would protest Trump's Chicago visit in a rally on Wednesday.\n\nThe event comes as Trump works to ramp up support among Black voters and polls suggest younger Black voters are showing more openness to him as a candidate. As a result, some critics suggested Trump only accepted the NABJ's invitation to lure Black voters. Trump's team also announced the event on his website, writing that Trump has \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", {"uri": "8251648267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:10:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:10:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:10:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/07/30/media/national-association-of-black-journalists-faces-internal-ire-over-trump-qampa/", "title": "National Association of Black Journalists faces internal ire over...", "body": "A national organization for black journalists is under fire after it announced former President Donald Trump would appear at its convention Wednesday.\n\nLeaders for the National Association of Black Journalists defended its decision to have Trump, 78, speak during a Q&A session as scores of its rank-and-file members and other reporters blasted the invite.\n\nTrump was asked to attend in 2016 and 2020, but turned down the association both times before accepting this year as the Republican nominee looks to retake the White House.\n\n\"To say I'm disappointed in @NABJ would be an understatement,\" supervising producer Jasmine Ellis tweeted.\n\n\"This decision and announcement should've been handled with much more care. It feels shortsighted, self serving and the damage to the org reputation will be significant.\"\n\nCBS Sports host Ashley Nicole Moss called the decision \"extremely disappointing.\"\n\n\"this is supposed be a safe place for Black journalists to connect/network. it's a space to uplift current and upcoming journalists,\" she wrote on X. \"to remind each other that we belong. he has absolutely ZERO business being in a room like that/this.\"\n\n\"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have, potentially unsafe, all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else,' when this is....idiotic at best,\" former Deadspin writer Carron Phillips tweeted.\n\nThe association consistently invites presidential candidates from each major party to attend their conference, its leaders pointed out in defending the invitation.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" Atlanta Journal-Constitution Washington correspondent Tia Mitchell said in response to another tweet from Phillips, according to Page Six.\n\n\"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon also defended the decision.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" he posted.\n\nFormer senior adviser to President Biden and current MSNBC host Symone D. Sanders Townsend also agreed with the decision.\n\n\"Some of the best journalists in the country are members of NABJ. So, why wouldn't they interview Trump? He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" she explained in a social media post.\n\n\"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for president, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions. That's happening Wednesday.\"\n\nAdding to the contention, Vice President Kamala Harris, 59, turned down appearing at the convention because she's attending the funeral of Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee on Wednesday.\n\nBut the organization declined Harris' offer to set up a virtual Q&A or hold it at another date, a source told NBC News.\n\nFox News host Harris Faulkner, ABC News congressional correspondent Rachel Scott and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba will moderate the event with Trump, which will focus on issues most important to the black community.\n\nTrump's campaign said the 45th president was \"grateful\" for the invite.\n\n\"Team Trump believes it's important to give black journalists more access to presidential candidates so they can better inform black voters,\" Sheila Jackson Lee (D-TX) and finalizing a vice presidential nominee, the source said. She offered to appear for a virtual fireside chat during the convention or an in-person conversation at a later date, but the convention's organizers declined.\n\nNABJ did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The news, first reported by theGrio, came hours after a co-chair of this year's NABJ convention stepped down after the convention announced Donald Trump would appear for a moderated conversation.\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said her choice was influenced by \"a variety of factors,\" though she did not directly attribute it to the group's decision to host the former president. She said she was not consulted about the move to platform Trump.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" she wrote in an X post.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Her abrupt exit a day before the convention is set to begin follows a torrent of backlash over its plan to host Trump, who is set to participate in a moderated Q&A with ABC News reporter Rachel Scott, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon and convention co-chair Tia Mitchell have defended the decision in social media posts, saying it conformed to a tradition of inviting presidential candidates during an election year and it was an opportunity for Trump to face questions from top Black journalists. Lemon said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited. (The Harris campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.)\n\n\"Some of yall need to take a step back and ask why you're questioning why a group of JOURNALISTS wants to ask former and possibly future President Trump questions,\" Mitchell, a Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X. \"Do you hear yourselves?\"\n\nStill, a number of Black journalists aired their grievances about the programming move on X, noting Trump's penchant for racist comments and attacking Black journalists.\n\nApril Ryan, a White House reporter for theGrio and a 2017 NABJ \"Journalist of the Year,\" condemned NABJ's platforming by citing the attacks she faced from Trump directly.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" she wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility\"\n\n-- Jemele Hill\n\n\"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him,\" Femi Redwood, the chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, wrote on X.\n\nJemele Hill, a contributing writer at The Atlantic, said she didn't have a problem with the decision to host Trump under \"the right circumstances,\" but she said she wasn't aware how \"right\" this year's conditions were.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" she wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. {"uri": "8251745180", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:44:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:44:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:43:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://hollywoodunlocked.com/several-national-association-of-black-journalists-outraged-and-canceling-memberships-after-nabj-invites-donald-trump-to-convention-in-chicago-co-chair-steps-down/", "title": "Several Members Of The National Association Of Black Journalists Outraged And Canceling Memberships After NABJ Invites Donald Trump To Convention In Chicago; Co-Chair Steps Down", "body": "Several Members Of The National Association Of Black Journalists Outraged And Canceling Memberships After NABJ Invites Donald Trump To Convention In Chicago; Co-Chair Steps Down\n\n#Socialites, get a load of this! Several members of the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) were left outraged and ready to cancel their memberships after the organization invited former President Donald Trump to its convention in Chicago this week; it has also lost its co-chair, who stepped down after the move.\n\nRELATED: Social Media Reacts To Rep. John James Telling RNC Crowd 'You Ain't Black If You Don't Vote Donald Trump' -- 'Said The Only Black Man In The Room'\n\nDonald Trump, the GOP nominee in the 2024 presidential race, was invited to appear at the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention in Chicago on Wednesday (July 31). However, many of the organization's members and some of the nation's top Black journalists immediately became enraged to learn about the move.\n\nOne member, Pulitzer Prize nominee Carron J. Phillips, slammed the group on X (formerly Twitter), writing, \"When membership numbers and those dues fall off a cliff, remember the day y'all made this dumb a** decision.\" He also tweeted and said, \"This is the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history. Whoever made this call is an idiot. And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nIn another tweet, Phillips added, \"Y'all just made the only safe haven that Black journalists have, potentially unsafe, all because y'all want to look 'smarter than everybody else,' when this is.... idiotic at best.\" Phillips continued to blast the NABJ and its organizers who invited Donald Trump to this week's event. However, while slamming the organization, Phillips also retweeted others, who eventually revealed that each election year the NABJ invites all candidates. It just so happens that this year, Trump accepted the invite for the Republicans, which some users claimed is unheard of.\n\nRELATED: Post And Delete: Forbes 'DEI Expert' Poses Controversial Question: 'Will Surviving Gunfire Be Donald Trump's Next Appeal To Black Voters?'\n\nMeanwhile, other users online wanted to know if Donald Trump was invited to represent the Republicans, was Vice President Kamala Harris offered the same invitation as the presumptive Democratic nominee in the 2024 presidential race. It turns out that she was invited, but it was later revealed that VP Harris reportedly will not be attending the NABJ Convention in Chicago this week.\n\nApril D. Ryan, who is the White House Correspondent for TheGrio and 2017 NABJ \"Journalist of the Year,\" made the announcement and said, \"A source familiar also says Harris is hitting the ground running as the new presumptive Democratic Nominee days into her campaign working through all of the necessary planning and attending the funeral of late Texas Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. The source also says the Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option. The NABJ team, unfortunately, denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in-person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\nIn the midst of all of the hoopla, Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah spoke out and announced that she was stepping down as co-chair of this year's convention with Donald Trump. Taking to X, Attiah said, \"I have decided to step down as co-chair from this year's #NABJ24 convention in Chicago. To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck. For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City. #NABJ.\" In a second tweet, she continued to clarify her move, stating, \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nRELATED: Omarosa Slams Donald Trump Over 'Black Jobs' Debate Comments, Compares Remarks To 'Slavery'\n\n#Socialites, be sure to check out the post below, then leave us your thoughts in a comment after!", "source": {"uri": "hollywoodunlocked.com", Chicago with ABC News' Rachel Scott, Fox News' Harris Faulkner and Semafor's Kadia Goba as moderators.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members and welcome the opportunity to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement posted to X/Twitter.\n\nHe said Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris had been invited to appear, following the tradition of inviting candidates from both major parties each presidential cycle.\n\nBut a number of reporters rejected the decision to highlight Trump, whose campaign promoted his presence in an ad Monday night.\n\nAmong them was April Ryan, White House correspondent for protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential candidate who is pushing an authoritarian agenda aimed at destroying this nation and its democracy with his 2025 agenda.\"\n\nJim {"uri": "2024-07-438912893", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:33:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:33:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:20:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://thegrio.com/2024/07/30/harris-wont-attend-nabj-convention-as-group-faces-backlash-over-trump-invitation/", "title": "Harris won't attend NABJ convention as group faces backlash over Trump invitation", "body": "SCOOP: A source told theGrio that NABJ denied a request for the vice president to take part in a fireside chat virtually or schedule an in-person one at a later date.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris will not attend the annual convention of the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) in Chicago, a source with direct knowledge of negotiations told theGrio. The source was granted anonymity to discuss private discussions between Harris's campaign team and NABJ.\n\nThe source told theGrio that Harris is unable to attend the convention, which begins July 31 and ends Aug. 4, due to planning and travels during the first days of the presumptive Democratic nominee's nascent presidential campaign. Harris is also traveling to Houston to attend the funeral service of late U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas.\n\nThe source also told theGrio that Harris's campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option. The NABJ team, according to the source, denied a request for the vice president to take part in a fireside chat virtually or schedule an in-person one with Harris at a later date.\n\nWhen asked during the White House daily briefing on Tuesday about whether Harris or President Joe Biden, who traveled to Austin on Monday to commemorate the Civil Rights Act of 1964, would attend the convention in Chicago, White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told theGrio, \"The NABJ makes their own decision on guests.\"\n\nThe Biden spokesperson referred other questions related to Biden and Harris and the NABJ convention to the vice president's campaign.\n\nThe news that Harris will not attend the convention came as NABJ is marred by controversy. The organization announced it is hosting a town hall on Wednesday with former President Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee. Three Black female journalists -- Fox News host Harris Faulkner, ABC reporter Rachel Scott, and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba -- will moderate the conversation.\n\nCritics of NABJ's decision to host Trump point out that, as president, he attacked a number of Black journalists and undermined the free press. The former president notably popularized the term \"Fake News\" when disparaging news coverage he did not agree with.\n\nRecommended Stories\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon defended the decision to facilitate the Q&A with Trump. He explained that the non-partisan invitation is a years-long tradition and that it was not an endorsement of Trump.\n\n\"We invited both [Trump and Harris]. We got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said in video remarks posted on NABJ's official X page.\n\nLemon also shared that the organization is working to ensure Trump, known for telling falsehoods, is fact-checked during the conversation.\n\nSince the news of Trump's visit broke on Monday, backlash has ensued, including the resignation of the convention's co-chair, Karen Attiah.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she wrote on X.\n\nThe National Newspaper Publishers Association (NNPA) on Tuesday called for NABJ to rescind the Trump invitation. The organization posted an altered version of the event's digital graphic with the word \"Condemned.\"\n\nA protest is scheduled for Wednesday morning just before Trump's appearance at the NABJ convention at the Hilton Chicago. According to the Chicago-based digital news site The Triibe, the \"Trump is not welcome in Chicago\" demonstration is organized by Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression (CAARPR), Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP)-Chicago, and US Palestinian Community Network.\n\nAs for Vice President Harris, three sources with direct knowledge about NABJ's planning related to her now-scrapped appearance told theGrio that, similar to Wednesday's talk with Trump, a panel of respected journalists was on standby to conduct the conversation.\n\nDuring Tuesday's press briefing, Jean-Pierre said the Biden-Harris administration has \"always been ... very direct and very focused on speaking to both local and national Black-owned outlets.\"\n\n\"We understand the importance of Black Americans [hearing] directly from this administration,\" she added.", "source": {"uri": "thegrio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheGrio"}, "authors": [{"uri": "april_ryan@thegrio.com", {"uri": "8251221853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:20:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:20:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:19:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/30/trump-speak-black-journalists-nabj-co-chair-quits.html", "title": "Trump address to Black journalist convention prompts co-chair Karen Attiah to quit", "body": "The co-chair of the annual National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down Tuesday in apparent reaction to that group's decision to have former President Donald Trump speak at its convention and career fair in Chicago on Wednesday, among other factors.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" NABJ24 convention co-chair Karen Attiah wrote in a social media post announcing her decision to resign her position. \"For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City.\"\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" wrote Attiah, a columnist for The Washington Post who writes about international affairs, culture and human rights issues.\n\nFounded in 1975, NABJ is the largest association of journalists of color in the United States. Over the years it has hosted speakers who included then-presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, as well as former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.\n\nCNBC has requested comment from Attiah and from NABJ, as well as from a spokesman for Trump's presidential campaign about Attiah's announcement.\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, in her own post on X responded to controversy over Trump's appearance, saying she helped arrange the event as a chair member of NABJ's political task force.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" wrote Mitchell in that X post. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nMitchell's post was only visible to users who she had given access to.\n\nNABJ on Monday announced that the Republican nominee Trump would \"participate in a conversation with journalists\" at the convention before attendees.\n\nThe group said the event with Trump will be moderated by Rachel Scott, the senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Fox News' Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ said it has also invited the Democratic Party's de-facto presidential nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, to speak at the convention. \"Her confirmation is pending,\" the group said.\n\nHarris's father is Black, and her mother was born in India. If elected president, she would be the first woman and the first South Asian person elected president.\n\nDuring his presidency, Trump was criticized for making racist remarks when he referred to Haiti and African nations as \"s---hole countries\" during a meeting with senators at the White House in 2018.\n\nTrump's nephew Fred Trump III recounted hearing Donald Trump twice using the n-word, in his newly released memoir, after finding that his convertible had been slashed while parked. {"uri": "8251650779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:13:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:13:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:12:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_c40b9907-fcc1-512e-8bf1-e7e461e4691f.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "New York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Sierra signage going up at former Sioux City Bed Bath & Beyond North Sioux City crash kills one 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street Sioux City's Lyons Park getting $1.22 million in upgrades BNSF Railway wants to remove collapsed Big Sioux River train bridge Now streaming and on DVD: 'The Richmond Way' gives us the whole 'Ted Lasso' story Jason's Frozen Treats open second dine-in ice cream parlor Body found in Floyd River in Sioux City Sioux City driver charged with vehicular homicide from weekend crash Elk Point man killed in North Sioux City crash Tom and Molly Bedell's West Lake Okoboji home sells for state record $9.5M Wife of Dakota Dunes fatal stabbing suspect charged as an accessory Financial situation for McCook Lake residents still murky a month after flood State baseball: Scrapy dynamic duo sends Crusaders to state title game, down top seed Wahlert Woodbury County Court Report for July 22, 2024\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "2024-07-438964476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:18:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:18:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:19:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_5d77f4dc-bad1-58d4-b63d-f3373d09e78d.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nWaterloo traffic cameras adjust ticket threshold by 1 mph NEW DETAILS: Deere offers statement on severance package for salaried employees let go Wednesday in Waterloo UPDATE: 69 John Deere Waterloo salaried employees let go Wednesday, 34 in Dubuque Waterloo Christian School makes offer on old Cedar Falls High School 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street Waterloo man arrested for trying to run over women Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo Waterloo man arrested following short chase Oelwein man dead in two-vehicle crash southwest of Hazleton Neighbors, crews rescue man from sinking vehicle Olympics: Independence wrestling coaches will serve as volunteers at Paris Games Deere held employee meeting Wednesday, no word yet on potential layoffs Waterloo man sentenced to prison for sawed-off shotgun 67 Johnston workers added to Deere layoffs list, bringing Iowa total to 170 this week John Deere idled more than 300 workers in Quad Cities on Wednesday, bringing last week's total to 489\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8251295467", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:24:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:24:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:23:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://spokesman-recorder.com/2024/07/30/nnpa-demands-nabj-rescind-invitation-to-donald-trump/", "title": "NNPA condemns NABJ's decision to include Trump in annual panel | Minnesota Spokesman-Recorder", "body": "The National Newspaper Publishers Association (NNPA) has forcefully condemned the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) for including former President Donald Trump in a panel during its annual convention. The stunning invitation has sparked widespread outrage within the journalism community.\n\n\"I strongly oppose Trump's participation in the NABJ annual convention and career fair,\" declared NNPA National Chair Bobby Henry. The NNPA represents over 250 African-American-owned newspapers and media companies and has been a pillar of the Black Press of America for 197 years. \"His divisive rhetoric and actions have harmed marginalized communities, particularly the Black community,\" Henry continued. \"Allowing him a platform at this event undermines the NABJ's values of inclusion and solidarity and risks normalizing his damaging behavior.\"\n\nHenry emphasized the necessity of Black journalists to foster dialogues that uplift and empower marginalized voices, not those who have historically opposed minority interests.\n\nFounded in 1975, the NABJ is a prominent organization for journalists of color in America. The decision to invite the controversial, twice-impeached, and 34-times convicted felon and former president has triggered a significant backlash from its members.\n\n\"I have decided to step down as co-chair from this year's #NABJ24 convention in Chicago,\" tweeted NABJ convention co-chair Karen Attiah to her 234,000 followers. \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck. For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City.\" Attiah noted that NABJ leadership did not consult her in the decision to provide Trump with a platform.\n\nJournalist Kathia Woods, who will host a panel during the event, voiced her disappointment but affirmed her commitment to attending the convention due to her responsibilities. \"I'm here for my young journalists to support and will continue to advocate for you,\" Woods stated. \"Also, Brandon is a friend, and he and his team worked really hard.\"\n\nProminent journalists April Ryan and Yamiche Alcindor, both of whom Trump has previously targeted, also condemned the NABJ's decision. However, Jemele Hill and Simone Sanders argued that the criticism might be premature. \"We interviewed the President of the Heritage Foundation on @TheWeekendMSNBC,\" Sanders wrote.\n\n\"Some people thought it was a bad idea, but we asked real questions and got him on the record on key issues. Folks shouldn't assume that all the journalists interviewing Trump at NABJ aren't going to ask real questions or hold him accountable.\"\n\nRoland Martin, another prominent NABJ member, added that he found it troubling that no Black male journalists were invited to question Trump. Like so many others, Martin vehemently objected to including Fox News personality and Trump apologist Harris Faulkner, who will serve as moderator.\n\nAs the backlash grows, NABJ President Ken Lemon faces increasing calls for his resignation. \"The NNPA is resolutely opposed to Donald Trump being scheduled to speak at the 2024 NABJ national convention in Chicago,\" stated NNPA President and CEO Dr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr.\n\n\"For 197 years, the Black Press of America has been on the frontline of Black America's struggle for freedom, justice, and equality. It is a tragic affront to Black America for NABJ to permit Trump to spew racist lies, hatred, and fascism at an NABJ national convention. The NNPA urgently calls upon NABJ leadership to immediately rescind the invitation. The eyes of Black America and the world are watching with shame and disgust.\"", "source": {"uri": "spokesman-recorder.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Minnesota Spokesman-Recorder"}, "authors":
