{"uri": "2024-07-438774342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:01:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:01:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:20:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/politics/donald-trump-nabj-journalists/2024/07/30/id/1174578/", "title": "Black Journalists' Leader Quits Before Trump Speech", "body": "An invitation to speak by the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) to former President Donald Trump caused a key resignation in its leadership, Axios reported Tuesday.\n\nKaren Attiah, a longtime Washington Post columnist, announced she is stepping down as co-chair of the NABJ after internal and external protests after the announcement of Trump being a featured speaker at this week's convention.\n\n\"I have decided to step down as co-chair from this year's #NABJ24 convention in Chicago,\" she posted.\n\nTrump's campaign announced Monday that he had accepted an invitation to attend a question-and-answer session Wednesday in Chicago. The event is closed to the public but will be live streamed on NABJ's YouTube and Facebook pages, the group said in a statement.\n\n\"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said. \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nAxios noted that the group's Instagram post announcing Trump's speaking engagement had garnered over 800 comments in less than one day.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" Attiah said. \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck.\"\n\nConference co-chair Tia Michell defended her position according to Axios, saying: \"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades.\"\n\nThe NABJ, founded in 1975, is the nation's largest association of journalists of color. In the past, it hosted speakers who included former presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, as well as former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.\n\nJames Morley III \u2709 James Morley III is a writer with more than two decades of experience in entertainment, travel, {"uri": "8252118963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:15:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:15:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:13:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2808454/", "title": "National Association of Black Journalists faces backlash over Trump's invitation to Chicago convention - ExBulletin", "body": "National Association of Black Journalists faces backlash over Trump's invitation to Chicago convention\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists is facing backlash after announcing Monday that Donald Trump will participate in a question-and-answer session at the organization's annual convention.\n\nThe group announced the session Monday night, with the convention set to begin Wednesday in Chicago. The former president will discuss issues facing the black community through questions posed by reporters from ABC News, FOX News and Semafor.\n\nThe announcement quickly drew a backlash from some black journalists who said they were disgusted and concerned by Trump's rhetoric toward black people.\n\nOrganizers of the Black Voters Matter Fund, a voting rights group founded in 2016 amid Trump's rise, called the decision unacceptable in a post on X on Tuesday.\n\nThis is a slap in the face to every black journalist and to the communities we serve, the message read.\n\nMeanwhile, Karen Attiah, a Washington Post columnist and global opinion editor, said on X on Tuesday that she was stepping down as convention co-chair. While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted in any way in the decision to present Trump in this format, she added in a separate message.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe organization's leaders defended the decision to host the Republican presidential nominee. NABJ President Ken Lemon said on social media that the organization invites presidential candidates from both major parties every election year, and added that it had invited presumptive Democratic nominee Kamala Harris.\n\nAccording to a source familiar with her plans, Harris cited logistical reasons, including attending Texas Democratic Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee's funeral and choosing a running mate, as reasons for her inability to attend the convention this year. The source added that NABJ declined Harris' offer to host a virtual discussion or to hold one later.\n\nAccording to The Hill, George W. Bush and John Kerry both spoke at the NABJ convention in 2004, and Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton did so in 2007. Clinton returned for a speech and press conference in 2016. Joe Biden spoke at the virtual conference in 2020; Trump did not.\n\nTia Mitchell, the convention's co-chair, echoed Lemons' explanation and said she helped organize the question-and-answer session to create opportunities for reporters to interview the potential next president.\n\nCritics said those explanations did not adequately address the concerns of journalists and other NABJ members who were hesitant to give Trump such a prominent platform at the convention, given his history, they said, of emboldening white supremacists, pushing racist rhetoric and preparing for education restrictions, anti-DEI legislation and anti-LGBTQ laws.\n\nApril Ryan, a veteran White House correspondent and the 2017 NABJ Journalist of the Year, wrote in an article published Tuesday on X that she opposed Trump's presence in Chicago.\n\nHaving an allegedly orchestrated sit-down with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the black women journalists (NABJ Journalists of the Year) who have had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential candidate who is pushing an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and its democracy with his 2025 agenda.\n\nThe Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression, a justice organization, announced in an Instagram post that it would protest Trump's visit to Chicago at a rally on Wednesday.\n\nThe event comes as Trump is working to build support among black voters, and polls suggest that younger black voters are more open to his candidacy. As a result, some critics have suggested that Trump accepted the NABJ invitation only to appeal to black voters. Trump's team also advertised the event on its website, writing that Trump has accomplished more for black Americans than any other president in recent history.\n\nFor more from NBC BLK, sign up for our weekly newsletter.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-439271721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:06:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:06:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:57:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2808468/", "title": "Trump's visit to Chicago sparks reaction from group of black journalists", "body": "The National Association of Black Journalists is facing internal and external backlash following its last-minute announcement that it would host former President Donald Trump at its annual conference Wednesday in Chicago.\n\nOn Monday night, the Trump campaign announced it would participate in a question-and-answer session with political reporters at the conference at the Hilton Chicago. The campaign said it would focus on the most pressing issues facing the black community.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris will not attend the convention for logistical reasons, including selecting her running mate, according to a source familiar with the discussions.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon posted on social media: \"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members and welcome the opportunity to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers that Black Americans want and need to know.\"\n\nOn Tuesday morning, the conference's co-chair, Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah, announced on X that she was stepping down.\n\nTo the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them good luck, Attiah wrote.\n\nSome NABJ members and media outlets believe Trump's treatment of black journalists during his presidency should prevent him from attending. Others are upset about the timing of the announcement two days before the five-day convention begins, when many members were already en route to Chicago for the event.\n\nMorgan Elise Johnson, co-founder of Triibe, wrote: \"I want to salute @NABJ for surprising Chicago with this news about Trump, a man who has threatened Chicago with state violence in his campaign speeches - and who is attracting a white supremacist audience to a Black affinity space.\"\n\nThe event will be hosted by Rachel Scott, ABC News' senior congressional correspondent, Fox News' Harris Faulkner and Kadia Goba, a political reporter at Semafor. Goba interviewed Trump this year and Faulkner spoke with Trump this month.\n\nIn a statement, Semafor defended Goba's participation: \"As a political journalist, Kadia has conducted tough and fair interviews with high-ranking figures from across the political spectrum, including the former president. We look forward to his responses tomorrow.\"\n\nOthers also defended the event, including Symone Sanders-Townsend, a former senior adviser to Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nSome of the best journalists in the country are members of NABJ. So why wouldn't they interview Trump? He's the Republican nominee, Sanders-Townsend wrote on X. It seems like the complaining journalists don't understand that their job is to ask the questions.\n\nThe association regularly invites candidates from both parties during election years. Harris was invited after it became clear she would likely become the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, Lemon said.\n\nBut according to a source familiar with the discussions, Harris will not attend because it was not logistically feasible. Harris' campaign worked with NABJ leaders to find an alternative option, including a virtual fireside chat or a later in-person event, but their requests were denied, the source said.\n\nBefore withdrawing from the race, President Joe Biden had confirmed his attendance at the conference.\n\nSpeaking on WBEZ's Reset with Sasha-Ann Simons, WBEZ's race, class and community editor Natalie Moore called Trump's appearance a surprise.\n\nI know it was a shock to me, but what does it mean for the organization? Moore said. What does it mean for the members that he's here?\n\nMoore also questioned how Trump's footage could be used for his campaign and why journalists from Black-owned media outlets were not invited to participate.\n\n\"I think members want answers from NABJ leadership,\" Moore said. \"Yes, we know the invitation was extended, but how was this panel created? And again, my question is, were there negotiations with Trump?\n\nTriibe co-founder Tiffany Walden also told WBEZ: \"The city itself ran Trump out of town in 2016. Trump canceled a rally in Chicago during his 2016 campaign after scuffles broke out at the UIC pavilion. In 2019, Trump came to Chicago for his first presidential visit and disparaged the city, calling it an embarrassment to us as a nation, at a police conference. Later, he was greeted by thousands of protesters outside Trump Tower at a fundraiser he hosted.\"\n\n\"It's clear that he's not welcome here. As black journalists, we have to be the organization that rolls out the red carpet... This is a different situation. I know they've invited presidential candidates before, including Republicans, but in this case, Trump is not a Republican,\" Walden said. \"He's not your average candidate. He's spreading harmful misinformation, disinformation and dog whistles about black communities and some of the people who are going to be in this room.\"\n\nAt a Chicago Police Department graduation ceremony Tuesday, Mayor Brandon Johnson also criticized Trump's visit and his past behavior toward black journalists. The mayor, however, said the city would be prepared for his visit.\n\n\"The black press has played a vital role in transforming our city, here in Chicago, but also our country and our world,\" Johnson said. \"We're going to prepare ourselves as a city if he decides to come to Chicago to make sure that the wickedness and the education that he brings doesn't taint the soul of Chicago.\"\n\nThe Sun-Times reached out to several NABJ members. None would comment. Representatives for ABC and Fox did not immediately respond to requests for comment.\n\nAs for Chicago, the city has been Trump's favorite scapegoat since his 2016 campaign. He continued his frequent attacks while in the White House, often without regard to whether crime in Chicago was up or down.\n\nHe has spoken frequently about deploying the military, telling a Fox News host in 2020: \"We're going to have to do something about crime in Chicago.\"\n\nAnd in listing the city's crime statistics at a White House event that year, President Trump said, \"It's worse than Afghanistan.\" I hate to say it: It's worse than any war zone we've ever been in, by a long shot. It makes places seem peaceful by comparison. So we're not going to let that continue.\n\nContribution by Mary Norkol\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. For more info and free online quotes, please visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/the-advantages-of-comparing-prices-with-car-insurance-quotes-online/ The modern society has numerous technological advantages. One important advantage is the speed at which information is sent and received. With the help of the internet, the shopping habits of many persons have drastically changed. The car insurance industry hasn't remained untouched by these changes. On the internet, drivers can compare insurance prices and find out which sellers have the best offers. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Accurate insurance estimates. Online quotes can only be accurate if the customers provide accurate and real info about their car models and driving history. Lying about past driving incidents can make the price estimates to be lower, but when dealing with an insurance company lying to them is useless. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price. Using brokerage websites will allow drivers to get quotes from multiple insurers, thus making the comparison faster and easier. For additional info, money-saving tips, and free car insurance quotes, visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/ Compare-autoinsurance.Org is an online provider of life, home, health, and auto insurance quotes. This website is unique because it does not simply stick to one kind of insurance provider, but brings the clients the best deals from many different online insurance carriers. In this way, clients have access to offers from multiple carriers all in one place: this website. On this site, customers have access to quotes for insurance plans from various agencies, such as local or nationwide agencies, brand names insurance companies, etc. \"Online quotes can easily help drivers obtain better car insurance deals. All they have to do is to complete an online form with accurate and real info, then compare prices\", said Russell Rabichev, Marketing Director of Internet Marketing Company. {"uri": "8251646289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:08:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:08:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_e9cdf245-b09f-5573-8305-65e92cdb5ecb.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August McDowell calendar: Trump Road Rally goes from Morganton to Marion, and more events Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Sheriff: Marion man intentionally hit pedestrian with car Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged McDowell girls basketball coach Zack McCartha to coach in 2025 East-West All-Star game Hickory law firm partner disbarred for taking $55,000 for personal use McDowell native wants to create Marion walk of fame Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Family of missing Burke woman pleads for her return; $1K reward offered Drag queens help open Olympics but 'Last Supper' tableau draws criticism McDowell Titans wrapping up summer camp as 2024 football season nears Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Three polling places changing in McDowell County Orchard at Altapass releases August 2024 music and events schedule\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8251380144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:38:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:38:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:37:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://pagesix.com/2024/07/30/gossip/national-associaton-of-black-journalists-members-disgusted-by-orgs-donald-trump-invite-co-chair-steps-down/", "title": "National Association of Black Journalists members outraged after it...", "body": "Donald Trump has been invited to appear at National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention in Chicago on Wednesday, and some of the nation's top black journos are furious. Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah even stepped down as co-chair of the convention after the move.\n\nTrump is expected on opening day to participate in a \"special conversation\" with moderators Harris Faulkner of Fox News, ABC News' Rachel Scott and Semafor's Kadia Goba.\n\nSome members of the organization are outraged over the decision, we're told, and some are so disgusted they've even canceled their plans to attend.\n\nIt's become a hot topic on social media with several prominent journos and longtime members of the association saying they're frustrated with the NABJ's decision to provide a platform for the former president.\n\nNABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year recipient, Jim Trotter, was so upset by the \"poor decision\" that he said \"it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nPulitzer Prize nominee and past NABJ award winner Carron J. Phillips wrote on X, \"This is the single dumbest and worst decision in NABJ history. Whoever made this call is an idiot. And I'll say it to their face this week.\"\n\nTia Mitchell of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution responded to Phillips, revealing that she was a part of the decision to host Trump.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades. But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President,\" she shot back.\n\nAttiah, on the other hand, made it clear she had no say in the plan when she announced she's stepping down as co-chair on Tuesday.\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she wrote.\n\nThe Atlantic's Jemele Hill wrote: \"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump... Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nOthers pointed out that Trump has consistently insulted black journalists like CNN's Abby Phillips, Don Lemon, Yamiche Alcindor and White House vet April D. Ryan, who was NABJ's 2017 Journalist of the Year recipient.\n\nRyan, too, objects to Trump's NABJ visit. \"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" she wrote.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of the Republican presidential nominee... I object to this NABJ session with Donald Trump in Chicago,\" she concluded.", "source": {"uri": "pagesix.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Page Six"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251134355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:06:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:06:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:05:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/elections/former-president-donald-trump-to-attend-black-journalists-convention-in-chicago/article_eb60033b-ca31-5e11-8574-079cada4ac54.html", "title": "Former President Donald Trump to attend Black journalists convention in Chicago", "body": "Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe says what he saw at the Pennsylvania site where a gunman fired at former President Donald Trump made him \"ashamed.\" Rowe testified before a Senate panel examining the security around the assassination attempt.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump is scheduled to attend a panel discussion Wednesday at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Chicago.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said in a statement.\n\nTrump's first publicly announced visit to Chicago in years would come just a few weeks before the full force of the Democratic Party descends on the city for its national convention. The party is expected to celebrate the historic presidential nomination of Vice President Kamala Harris, who would be the first Black woman to lead a presidential ticket.\n\nThe NABJ also invited Harris to participate in the convention and \"her confirmation is pending,\" the organization said in a statement late Monday. Other former chief executives, including former President Barack Obama, have participated in NABJ conventions either as presidents or candidates, the statement noted.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe REO Speedwagon, Loverboy to perform in Bloomington this fall Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Normal man pleads guilty, sentenced for reckless driving in crash that injured 2 students Funerals pending for July 27 McLean County pathologist recognized for death investigation, tissue donation work\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson issued a statement on social media saying the city is prepared for Trump's visit.\n\n\"My administration's values and practice are in complete opposition to former President Donald Trump's agenda, but I want the people of Chicago to know that City departments and agencies are fully prepared to uphold safety during his scheduled visit,\" Johnson wrote on X.\n\nTrump's campaign confirmed the appearance late Monday night, saying in an emailed statement that he was \"participate in a conversation with journalists\" at the NABJ event. It will be held on noon on Wednesday.\n\n\"Black voters know that President Trump is the only presidential candidate who can deliver results on day one because he already has,\" the Trump campaign said in the statement.\n\nThe Q&A will be moderated by Rachel Scott of ABC News, Harris Faulkner of Fox News and Kadia Goba of the digital publication Semafor. It will be livestreamed and open to convention attendees but not open to the general public.\n\nTrump has said he wants to court Black voters for the November election, particularly with his economic policies. But his campaign agenda also has called for expanding police practices such as stop and frisk that have disproportionately affected Black Americans.\n\nDuring Trump's first visit to Chicago as president in 2019, he was met by hundreds of protesters and lobbed criticism at the city's then-police superintendent and other city leaders.\n\nAs a candidate for president in 2016, Trump was forced to cancel a rally at the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion amid security concerns as thousands of protesters demonstrated in the area.\n\nReaction on social media immediately after the NABJ's announcement was mixed.\n\n\"This is such a poor decision by @NABJ that it's difficult to put into words,\" Jim Trotter, a sports journalist and NABJ's 2023 Journalist of the Year, wrote on X.\n\n\"[L]ike many people said, this is where you go to get away from the hostility of your newsroom. It's supposed to be your safe space,\" Chicago-based journalist and author Arionne Nettles wrote of the convention, which serves as a gathering and networking space for Black journalists.\n\nTia Mitchell, a Washington-based correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said she helped make the decision to host Trump and in social media posts Monday night said she stood by the decision to invite Trump.\n\n\"Members can disagree. No one is forcing them to attend. But there is precedent of such invitations and great care taken with this particular one,\" Mitchell wrote.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your {"uri": "8251656691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:18:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/trump-appearance-national-association-black-journalists-debate/", "title": "Planned Trump appearance at National Association of Black Journalists event in Chicago sparks heated debate", "body": "CHICAGO (CBS) -- Current Republican presidential nominee and former President Donald Trump is set to be in Chicago on Wednesday -- he says he will attend the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention & Career Fair.\n\nThe decision to host Trump did not go over well with some NABJ members. But on Tuesday night -- a night after the announcement that Trump would be appearing -- NABJ President Ken Lemon reiterated that the invitation to Trump was not an endorsement.\n\nIt was something extended to both Trump and presumed Democratic presidential nominee Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nStill, despite the invitation of presidential candidates to the convention being a tradition that goes back decades, it has divided many within the organization with Trump involved.\n\nA fiery debate ensued online between members of the organization when the Trump campaign announced plans to attend the convention.\n\nSome journalists welcomed the idea of grilling the former president.\n\n\"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump. The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such. Being questioned by journalists is part of the job, and especially important in the company of Black journalists,\" Jemele Hill, a contributing writer for The Atlantic, wrote on X, formerly Twitter. \"Mainstream media keeps trying to convince us that he actually is gaining support among Black people. Let's see if it's true.\"\n\nOthers pushed back, flooding social media with frustration about the decision.\n\n\"This is platforming a tyrant. Nothing more, nothing less,\" wrote communications strategist Queen Muse.\n\nThe decision even led the co-chair for the convention, Karen Attiah, to step down.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote. \"For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City.\"\n\nJournalist and NABJ member April Ryan, White House correspondent for The Grio, called the Trump invitation \"a slap in the face to Black women journalists.\" On X, she shared a highlight reel of her contentious run-ins with Trump over the years.\n\nAva Thompson Greenwell is a journalism professor at Northwestern University, who is also a member of NABJ.\n\n\"I can understand how she feels disrespected,\" Greenwell said of Ryan. \"But I think in the end, it's really important for us as journalists not to be partisan.\"\n\nGreenwell also sees the controversial panel conversation with Trump as an opportunity.\n\n\"We need to the journalists to hold his feet to the fire, and to ask those difficult questions,\" she said. \"so that's what I'm going to be looking for tomorrow.\"\n\nThe sentiment was shared by NABJ President Lemon, who said panelists will be factchecking as the former presidents speaks.\n\n\"We have people whose lives are depending on what happens in November,\" Lemon said. \"For us as journalists -- people who go into and have very uncomfortable conversations for the sake of our members -- this is an important time.\"\n\nWhile Vice President Harris has yet to confirm whether she will be in attendance for the five-day conference, a source within the organization told CBS News Chicago they are close to finalizing a possible virtual speaking engagement with the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee.\n\nMeanwhile, with Trump scheduled to take the stage at noon Wednesday at the Chicago Hilton and Towers, at least three activist groups are planning protests outside -- sending a message that he is not welcomed in Chicago.\n\nMayor Brandon Johnson said he will make sure the former president gets the security he needs.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", Trump did not attend the convention during his four years as president so his inclusion this year raised concerns among some.\n\nThe decision to give Trump a platform for his policy messaging ahead of the November elections was seen as an affront to Black women journalists and Black people in general considering Trump's public record of pointed attacks at Black members of the press.\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and member of the NABJ's Political Task Force, defended the inclusion of Trump via X after the organization received heavy pushback.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades, Mitchell wrote in response to one user decrying the Trump session. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nMitchell has since made her X account private after a deluge of comments under her reply.\n\nThe issue has developed into a public relations disaster for the association, but NABJ President Ken Lemon did clear up any confusion surrounding chatter that Vice President Kamala Harris was not invited.\n\nYes we did ask both candidates. {"uri": "8251180598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:46:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:46:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:45:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/nabj-co-chair-karen-attiah-steps-down-after-trump-accepts-convention-invite", "title": "Black Journalists' Association Co-Chair Steps Down After Trump Accepts Invite", "body": "Karen Attiah's abrupt exit a day before the start of the NABJ convention follows a backlash by members over the organization's planned interview session with Donald Trump.\n\nA co-chair of this year's National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down on Tuesday, less than a day after the convention announced Donald Trump would appear for a moderated conversation.\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said her choice was influenced by \"a variety of factors,\" though she did not directly attribute it to the group's decision to host the former president. She said she was not consulted about the move to platform Trump.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" she wrote in an X post.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Her abrupt exit a day before the convention is set to begin follows a torrent of backlash over its plan to host Trump, who is set to participate in a moderated Q&A with ABC News reporter Rachel Scott, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon and convention co-chair Tia Mitchell have defended the decision in social media posts, saying it conformed to a tradition of inviting presidential candidates during an election year and it was an opportunity for Trump to face questions from top Black journalists. Lemon said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited. (The Harris campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.)\n\n\"Some of yall need to take a step back and ask why you're questioning why a group of JOURNALISTS wants to ask former and possibly future President Trump questions,\" Mitchell, a Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X. \"Do you hear yourselves?\"\n\nStill, a number of Black journalists aired their grievances about the programming move on X, noting Trump's penchant for racist comments and attacking Black journalists.\n\nApril Ryan, a White House reporter for The Grio and a 2017 NABJ \"Journalist of the Year,\" condemned NABJ's platforming by citing the attacks she faced from Trump directly.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" she wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\n\"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him,\" Femi Redwood, the chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, wrote on X.\n\nJemele Hill, a contributing writer at The Atlantic, said she didn't have a problem with the decision to host Trump under \"the right circumstances,\" but she said she wasn't aware how \"right\" this year's conditions were.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" she wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. The Trump campaign also confirmed this, noting the conversation \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nIn its announcement, the NABJ acknowledged Vice President Kamala Harris \"was also invited to participate in this year's convention; her confirmation is pending.\"\n\n\"Yes we did ask both candidates,\" NABJ president Ken Lemon added via X. \"Every presidential election year we ask the nominees to attend.\"\n\nLemon also said the invitations were \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\n\"These discussions have gone on in earnest, in true earnest, probably more than a month back and forth with both teams,\" he said. \"Even before it was Kamala [Harris] it was [Joe] Biden.\"\n\nThis acknowledgement, however, did little to quell apparent outrage among members and anti-Trump onlookers. Washington Post columnist Karen Attiah announced via X she would step down as co-chair for the group's 2024 convention in Chicago.\n\nThough Attiah did not outline the specific reason for her departure, she pointed to the fact she was \"not involved\" with the decision to provide Trump a platform.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\n\"If he refuses to debate the soon to be Democratic Presidential Nominee, who happens to be a Black woman then he shouldn't be granted an interview by a panel of all Black women, at an all Black Journalist conference,\" MSNBC medical contributor Ebony Jade Hilton added. \"He can say what needs to be said to HER face on Sept 10.\"\n\nFormer BET News journalist Jacque Reid also lashed out at the group via Instagram.\n\n\"I could not be more disappointed by this,\" she wrote. \"I know NABJ has a history of inviting all presidential candidates, but this is not the year for that. Not with this man. We need to be bombarding the world with how dangerous he is, not playing into news media efforts trying to normalize him and participating in efforts to put him back in office. Doug Jones Tells ElectionLine Podcast; Kamala Harris' Hollywood Appeal\n\nThe president of the National Association of Black Journalists is defending its decision to invite Donald Trump to appear at a Q&A session on Wednesday, as some members decried the move given the former president's conduct.\n\nTrump is scheduled to appear at a session at the association's Chicago convention with ABC News' Rachel Scott, Fox News' Harris Faulkner and Semafor's Kadia Goba as moderators.\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Ken Lemon, the president of NABJ, said in a statement posted on X/Twitter.\n\nHe said that Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris were invited to appear, in keeping with a tradition of inviting candidates of both major parties each presidential cycle.\n\nBut a number of journalists have pushed back on the decision to feature Trump, whose campaign promoted his appearance in an announcement on Monday evening.\n\nAmong them was April Ryan, White House correspondent for The Grio.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" Ryan wrote. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\nJim Trotter, national columnist for The Athletic, wrote that the Trump invite \"is such a poor decision by NABJ that it's difficult to put into words.\"\n\nOthers blasted the It will be livestreamed at 1 p.m. ET on the group's Facebook and YouTube pages.\n\nThe event gives Trump, who won just 12% of Black voters in his 2020 election loss to President Joe Biden, an opportunity to directly appeal to voters of color.\n\nBut he may have more trouble courting these voters in a competition against Harris, who is the first Black person, first woman and first person of South Asian descent to serve as vice president.\n\nSome polls already show that Harris has more support among Black, Latino and young voters than Biden did before she replaced him as the de facto Democratic nominee.\n\nOn Tuesday, a new Bloomberg/Morning Consult survey of battleground states found that Harris has effectively eliminated Trump's lead in the seven battleground states likely to determine which candidate wins the Electoral College.\n\nThe Trump campaign, in a press release Monday night announcing his NABJ appearance, claimed that he \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\"\n\nThe decision by NABJ, the nation's largest association of journalists of color, to host Trump quickly spurred a backlash both inside and outside the group.\n\nConvention co-chair Karen Attiah resigned her position on the eve of the event, writing in a social media post, \"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck.\"\n\nShe added in follow-up post, \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a {"uri": "8251650586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:13:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:13:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:12:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_28b3f4b7-3eaf-5213-b514-fe6500c22c43.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bankrupt owner of Napa Valley wineries announces 377 layoffs Drivers to soon get a taste of Napa's Soscol Junction roundabouts Vintage Wine Estates files for bankruptcy, sells Cosentino Winery in Napa Valley Growing pains: Violence-related NVUSD suspensions track with enrollment in middle schools Napa's Soscol Junction makes its partial debut. A Register reporter tests it. Register Explainer: A deeper look at Belia Ramos vs. Debra Dommen Napa Valley Distillery plans to rebuild, reopen after fiery crash Interconnected relationships at heart of restraining order case involving Napa supervisor and wine executive Restaurant owners, workers urge action against unpermitted food vending in Napa Update: Highway 128 reopens in Napa County after submerged vehicle found Napa County judge denies resentencing in 2014 Kayleigh Slusher death Letter: Stop tainting the name of Alta Heights 'No place in our community,' police and DA say after antisemitic flyers scattered in Napa New website supporting Napa day care goes live after controversial site taken down Update: Distillery building damaged by fire after Highway 29 crash in Napa\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8251230655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:29:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:29:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:27:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/trump-address-to-black-journalist-convention-prompts-co-chair-karen-attiah-to-quit/5649965/", "title": "Trump address to Black journalist convention prompts co-chair Karen Attiah to quit", "body": "NABJ said it has also invited Vice President Kamala Harris, the de facto Democratic party presidential nominee.\n\nThe co-chair of the annual National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down Tuesday in apparent reaction to that group's decision to have former President Donald Trump speak at its convention and career fair in Chicago on Wednesday, among other factors.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" NABJ24 convention co-chair Karen Attiah wrote in a social media post announcing her decision to resign her position. \"For everyone else, I'm looking forward to meeting and reconnecting with all of you in the Windy City.\"\n\n\"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" wrote Attiah, a columnist for The Washington Post who writes about international affairs, culture and human rights issues.\n\nFounded in 1975, NABJ is the largest association of journalists of color in the United States. Over the years it has hosted speakers who included then-presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, as well as former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.\n\nCNBC has requested comment from Attiah and from NABJ, as well as from a spokesman for Trump's presidential campaign about Attiah's announcement.\n\nTia Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, in her own post on X responded to controversy over Trump's appearance, saying she helped arrange the event as a chair member of NABJ's political task force.\n\n\"I helped make this call. And it's in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades,\" wrote Mitchell in that X post. \"But continue to go off on your feed. I'll continue to work to create opportunities for journalists to interview the potential next President.\"\n\nMitchell's post was only visible to users who she had given access to.\n\nNABJ on Monday announced that the Republican nominee Trump would \"participate in a conversation with journalists\" at the convention before attendees.\n\nThe group said the event with Trump will be moderated by Rachel Scott, the senior congressional correspondent for ABC News, Fox News' Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ said it has also invited the Democratic Party's de-facto presidential nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, to speak at the convention. \"Her confirmation is pending,\" the group said.\n\nHarris's father is Black, and her mother was born in India. If elected president, she would be the first woman and the first South Asian person elected president.\n\nDuring his presidency, Trump was criticized for making racist remarks when he referred to Haiti and African nations as \"s---hole countries\" during a meeting with senators at the White House in 2018.\n\nTrump's nephew Fred Trump III recounted hearing Donald Trump twice using the n-word, in his newly released memoir, after finding that his convertible had been slashed while parked. Trump's campaign said Fred Trump's claim was \"total fake news of the highest order.\"\n\nDonald Trump and his father Fred Trump were sued by the Department of Justice in 1973 for allegedly discriminating against Black would-be tenants in their New York housing complexes because of their race.\n\nDonald Trump has noted that he and his father settled the case two years later \"with no admission of guilt.\"\n\nAttiah was named NABJ's journalist of the year in 2019.\n\nThe same year, she won a special George Polk Award, one of the most prestigious prizes in American journalism, along with fellow Post columnist David Ignatius, for their writings about the murder of Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi in the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul, Turkey in November 2018.\n\nAttiah, whose parents are from the African nations of Ghana and Nigeria, had recruited Khashoggi to The Post and hired him.\n\nTrump, who was president at the time of Khashoggi's murder, rejected the conclusions by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency that the killing was done on the orders of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.\n\nThe State Department in March 2020, while Trump remained in the White House, {"uri": "8251650199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:13:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:13:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:12:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/partners/cnn/black-journalists-group-faces-member-backlash-over-trump-speaking-invitation/article_2dc9a0e1-f843-53b1-b4b1-a3cc1f5c9b34.html", "title": "Black journalists group faces member backlash over Trump speaking invitation", "body": "By Oliver Darcy, CNN\n\nNew York (CNN) -- The National Association of Black Journalists is trying its best to weather a storm of backlash.\n\nThe organization on Tuesday drew a torrent of criticism over its decision to invite Donald Trump to sit for an interview at its annual convention in Chicago. The Wednesday afternoon Trump event -- moderated by ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner, and Semafor politics reporter Kadia Goba -- has roiled the NABJ, with some of its most prominent members publicly expressing dismay.\n\nKaren Attiah, The Washington Post columnist who worked as co-chair of this year's conference, even announced Tuesday that she would resign from her role. While Attiah said a \"variety of factors\" influenced her decision, she specifically homed in on the Trump interview when making her abrupt announcement.\n\nPeople are also reading... Homeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks Mayo Clinic likely to demolish 94-year-old St. Francis Hospital building after opening new La Crosse facility Steve Cahalan: City panel to review plans for new Starbucks at Valley View Mall New building plans unveiled, along with TIF agreement at La Crosse's $300M River Point District project Complaint says La Crosse man assaulted with sheathed machete during 'school yard brawl' on lawn La Crosse County examines large affordable housing development in West Salem with nearly 600 units La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana Steve Cahalan: LAX Grille opens, Pastissimo is leaving and Ichiddo Ramen is coming to La Crosse UPDATE: New public hearing date set to discuss overnight unsheltered sleeping areas in La Crosse Man accused of OWI while pulling camper containing 9 kids, Wisconsin State Patrol says New retreat house for pilgrims and visitors at Shrine of Our Lady Guadalupe would house up to 66 guests Onalaska man faces felony charge after injury hit-and-run in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Candle maker adds to number of woman-owned shops in downtown Galesville Daylong standoff ends with arrest of man who shot Sauk County deputy, authorities say No injuries, one dog rescued from fire on Rose Street in La Crosse\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on X, adding that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nGiven Trump's adoration of authoritarianism, coupled with the vile campaign he has waged for years on the fourth estate, his appearance at any media-focused conference would be certain to generate heightened levels of controversy. But the fact that the former president, who has flirted with racist elements of his MAGA movement, had been invited to speak at the NABJ conference struck a particular nerve among many of its members.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the veteran White House correspondent and 2017 NABJ journalist of the year, wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists ... who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda.\"\n\nBut while there was an outpouring of disapproval Tuesday, not everyone was in agreement. Symone Sanders, the former Kamala Harris spokesperson turned MSNBC host, wrote on X that \"some of the best journalists in the country are members of the NABJ\" and wondered, \"So why wouldn't they interview Trump?\"\n\n\"He is the Republican nominee. Seems like the journalists complaining don't understand their jobs are to actually ask the questions,\" Sanders argued. \"NABJ didn't platform Trump. The voters in the Republican primary did. Just like anyone else who is running for President, he should sit for serious interviews and answer real questions.\"\n\nAnd despite Trump's aggressive posture toward the press, his attendance at the NABJ as a presidential candidate would not be completely out of the ordinary. Former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush have all attended accepted invitations to attend in recent decades.\n\nThe NABJ did not respond to multiple requests for comment Tuesday, but in its announcement it said the Q&A with Trump, \"will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\"\n\nMaking matters worse for the NABJ, while the organization has welcomed Trump to its stage to speak, it rejected requests by the Harris campaign to make accommodations for her to address the conference. A person familiar with the matter told CNN that Harris' schedule has been filled to the brim since her sudden ascension to the top of the Democratic ticket. To that end, she was unable to attend the Chicago conference in person. Her campaign did try to make an appearance work, the person said, but was rejected by the NABJ.\n\n\"The Harris for President campaign team worked very closely with NABJ leadership to find an alternative option,\" the person said. \"The NABJ team unfortunately denied a request for the VP to take part in a fireside chat virtually, or to host an in person fireside chat with the VP at a later date.\"\n\n\"Harris has always, and will always, value the NABJ and work to ensure Black reporters have a seat at the table,\" the person added, drawing a not-so-subtle contrast between the vice president and Trump. \"The Harris for President team still welcomes the opportunity to make one of the alternative options happen.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8251193730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:57:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:57:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:56:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/black-journalists-association-co-chair-steps-down-after-trump-accepts-invite/", "title": "Black Journalists' Association Co-Chair Steps Down After Trump Accepts Invite", "body": "A co-chair of this year's National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down on Tuesday, less than a day after the convention announced Donald Trump would appear for a moderated conversation.\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said her choice was influenced by \"a variety of factors,\" though she did not directly attribute it to the group's decision to host the former president. She said she was not consulted about the move to platform Trump.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" she wrote in an X post.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Her abrupt exit a day before the convention is set to begin follows a torrent of backlash over its plan to host Trump, who is set to participate in a moderated Q&A with ABC News reporter Rachel Scott, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon and convention co-chair Tia Mitchell have defended the decision in social media posts, saying it conformed to a tradition of inviting presidential candidates during an election year and it was an opportunity for Trump to face questions from top Black journalists. Lemon said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited. (The Harris campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.)\n\n\"Some of yall need to take a step back and ask why you're questioning why a group of JOURNALISTS wants to ask former and possibly future President Trump questions,\" Mitchell, a Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X. \"Do you hear yourselves?\"\n\nStill, a number of Black journalists aired their grievances about the programming move on X, noting Trump's penchant for racist comments and attacking Black journalists.\n\nApril Ryan, a White House reporter for The Grio and a 2017 NABJ \"Journalist of the Year,\" condemned NABJ's platforming by citing the attacks she faced from Trump directly.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" she wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility\"\n\n-- Jemele Hill\n\n\"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him,\" Femi Redwood, the chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, wrote on X.\n\nJemele Hill, a contributing writer at The Atlantic, said she didn't have a problem with the decision to host Trump under \"the right circumstances,\" but she said she wasn't aware how \"right\" this year's conditions were.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" she wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. {"uri": "2024-07-438575827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:50:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:50:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:34:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://thetriibe.com/2024/07/opinion-nabj-fails-to-read-the-room-with-last-minute-donald-trump-addition/", "title": "OPINION: NABJ fails to read the room with last-minute Donald Trump addition * The TRiiBE", "body": "On Wednesday, Donald Trump will attend a convention of journalists, well-meaning writers, editors and multimedia talent he's referred to as the enemy of the people.\n\nOn Wednesday, Donald Trump will talk to a room full of Black folks after he celebrated the elimination of affirmative action -- a tool that has helped Black people, and others, fight or prevent discriminatory practices for decades.\n\nOn Wednesday, the topic, presence and coverage of Trump will suck the air out of every panel, discussion and session on the opening day of the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) annual national conference as attention fixates on the former president.\n\nTo be clear, I have no issue with a presidential candidate campaigning. I'm not writing to endorse one candidate or tell you to vote.\n\nMy issue is with decision-makers distracting from a highly anticipated week of affirmation and education to invite someone who has before declined to be part of the NABJ convention and undermined the profession. It feels like our convention and organization is being used. (Also, as a 708 native, I dislike when people squarely focus on the negatives of the Chi.)\n\nNABJ leaders decided to platform a person who has insulted the convention's host city and its residents. In previous proclamations of using the military to address Chicago's crime and insinuating it could be eradicated in \"a day,\" Trump downplayed the racism, redlining and decades of disinvestment that create the city's cycles of poverty and violence. I hope Wednesday is a chance for him to outline his plan to strengthen Black families, education in Black communities and job opportunities in Chicago's poorest zip codes.\n\nI'm just not sure why he'd do that here at NABJ instead of speaking at a local church,chamber of commerce or community center.\n\nAs a journalist, I applaud uneasy conversations. As a daily newspaper editor, I engage in the \"both-siderism\" some decry, and I have defended the concept of intelligent objectivity. I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way.\n\nBut this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated.\n\nPeople shouldn't be asked to choose between attending a useful session or a self-serving side-show. They shouldn't be challenged to confront unsettling situations in an environment that is supposed to be welcoming for Black people. Uncomfortability and anxiety can be expected when the \"star\" of the opening day has repeatedly belittled our profession and questioned our intentions.\n\nThis is no doubt an excellent opportunity for the former president's image. But his outreach should be in the streets of Chicago. And I'm not lobbying for Democrats to show up to NABJ. I was looking forward to not seeing any politicians and forgetting for a few days that a high-stakes election is looming.\n\nNow NABJ as an organization, for the remainder of this campaign cycle, will be leveraged as a thin example of outreach.\n\nMy grievance isn't about political parties or who the best candidate is -- it's about maintaining the essence of the event.\n\nI was excited to attend my first NABJ convention after helping out at three separate chapters over the last decade-plus. The camaraderie I feel at local NABJ chapter meetings is refreshing and unique. About a dozen friends tell me the national convention is that times 10, something like a family reunion.\n\nAnd NABJ's greatness isn't born out of some challenging panel or cheeky debate -- the joy came from the togetherness. The turn-ups. The common respect. The shared struggles and triumphs of working in an isolating industry.\n\nInstead we get last-minute notice of a huge scheduling change with no opportunity for input, and a dismissive leadership hiding behind \"well, we've always done this,\" which is a poor excuse newsrooms often use to explain unpopular decisions. NABJ has dealt with a number of divisive topics and issues over the past several years and now has unnecessarily volunteered for another.\n\nOn Wednesday, I was going to renew my NABJ membership. On Wednesday, I was going to pay $450 at the gate for a weeklong ticket. But I may opt instead to save my money, go see my niece and nephew, and catch up with my already-exhausted colleagues after hours.\n\nI hope, going forward, the organization reads the room better and improves its understanding of what exactly the convention is about.", "source": {"uri": "thetriibe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The TRiiBE"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251520912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:27:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:27:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:26:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "http://chicagoreader.com/columns-opinion/editors-note-trump-journalist-chicago/", "title": "Editor's note: Trump . . . at NABJ? - Chicago Reader", "body": "The presidential candidate was invited to participate on opening day of the National Association of Black Journalists's convention.\n\nOn Monday, July 29, the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) announced that former president Trump would be participating in a \"conversation with journalists\" as part of the organization's opening day of its national convention, hosted at the Hilton Chicago. The release was posted just after 9 PM Chicago time to the NABJ website, two days ahead of the 2024 convention's opening day, July 31.\n\nAccording to the release, Trump is scheduled to talk at the gathering with a panel of three moderators, including Fox News host and anchor Harris Faulkner. In case you're not familiar, in 2023 while hosting the program Fox News Tonight, Faulkner used her opening monologue to opine that \"women and children are being redesigned by some sort of mad leftist science experiment,\" and that her pronouns are \"U.S.A.\"\n\nResponse to the news was swift from both NABJ members and others. Some members, participating in a spirited debate on the app formerly known as Twitter, pointed out that the organization has a tradition of inviting presidential candidates to address the convention. This dates back to at least 2004 when then candidate George W. Bush was the last Republican to accept the invitation before Trump. Journalist Jemele Hill wrote in a tweet, \"As journalists, we can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump. The reality is that he is running for president and needs to be treated as such.\"\n\nBut as journalist Tyler J. Davis pointed out in a TRiiBE op-ed published on Tuesday, July 30, \"NABJ leaders decided to platform a person who has insulted the convention's host city and its residents.\" That same day, a coalition of Chicago organizations, including the Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression (CAARPR), announced plans for a response rally outside the hotel timed around the convention kickoff to \"tell Trump he's not welcome in Chicago.\"\n\nAn alternative event\n\nThe local nonprofit Public Narrative invites the public to \"celebrate Black Chicago's contributions to journalism\" and attend the free panel discussion Leading Voices in Chicago's Black Storytelling featuring panelists Yohance Lacour (Invisible Institute), Tacuma Roeback (Chicago Defender), Morgan Elise Johnson (The TRiiBE), DeAnna Sherman (True Star Media), and moderator Natalie Moore.\n\nThu 8/1, 4:30-7 PM, Semicolon Books & Sweets, 400 N. Michigan, Suite 100; reserve tickets at Eventbrite\n\nFor their part, some members of the Chicago chapter of NABJ have pointed out that Trump's invitation was a decision made by the national organizers. And on Tuesday afternoon, Washington Post editor and columnist Karen Attiah announced her decision to step down as cochair of this year's convention.\n\nCandidate or not, it is a terrible decision to hand a platform to a person who during his previous campaigns regularly reposted and reshared messages from white supremacists and neo-Nazis and signed an executive order banning people from majority Muslim countries from entering the U.S. There's a big difference between a chance for a journalist to ask questions of a candidate in an open forum and the program that NABJ's national team seems to be organizing for this week. Will anyone ask Trump about the time he attacked Yamiche Alcindor in a press conference? Will he be forced to answer for past transgressions against journalists?\n\nNABJ is one of the largest journalists associations in the country and has several Reader staffers, contributors, and alumni in its membership ranks. I believe in the power of these associations to strengthen journalism.\n\nBut as a Chicagoan and an anti-racist, I cannot believe that this situation will be any different than the circus-like rallies we've seen from Trump's campaign in the past. And that's not fair to the NABJ members who deserve to spend their convention time comparing notes about better ways to report on the truth in our local communities.", "source": {"uri":
