{"uri": "8251181029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:46:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:46:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:45:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/black-journalists-association-co-chair-184203689.html", "title": "Black Journalists' Association Co-Chair Steps Down After Trump Accepts Invite", "body": "A co-chair of this year's National Association of Black Journalists convention stepped down on Tuesday, less than a day after the convention announced Donald Trump would appear for a moderated conversation.\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said her choice was influenced by \"a variety of factors,\" though she did not directly attribute it to the group's decision to host the former president. She said she was not consulted about the move to platform Trump.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" she wrote in an X post.\n\nAttiah did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Her abrupt exit a day before the convention is set to begin follows a torrent of backlash over its plan to host Trump, who is set to participate in a moderated Q&A with ABC News reporter Rachel Scott, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner, and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nJ.D. Vance Says Racism 'Definitely' Helped Trump Win in Resurfaced Clip\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon and convention co-chair Tia Mitchell have defended the decision in social media posts, saying it conformed to a tradition of inviting presidential candidates during an election year and it was an opportunity for Trump to face questions from top Black journalists. Lemon said Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited. (The Harris campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.)\n\n\"Some of yall need to take a step back and ask why you're questioning why a group of JOURNALISTS wants to ask former and possibly future President Trump questions,\" Mitchell, a Washington correspondent for the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, wrote on X. \"Do you hear yourselves?\"\n\nStill, a number of Black journalists aired their grievances about the programming move on X, noting Trump's penchant for racist comments and attacking Black journalists.\n\nApril Ryan, a White House reporter for The Grio and a 2017 NABJ \"Journalist of the Year,\" condemned NABJ's platforming by citing the attacks she faced from Trump directly.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" she wrote on X. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\n\"I'm disappointed that in a space where so many queer and trans members still feel vulnerable will now feel even more unsafe due to Trump being invited and the possibility of his most vicious followers coming to the hotel to support him,\" Femi Redwood, the chair of NABJ's LGBTQ+ task force, wrote on X.\n\nJemele Hill, a contributing writer at The Atlantic, said she didn't have a problem with the decision to host Trump under \"the right circumstances,\" but she said she wasn't aware how \"right\" this year's conditions were.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" she wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen. You have to answer to your membership and you run the risk of permanently disengaging folks. Trump isn't worth that.\"\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "2024-07-438828461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:28:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:28:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:14:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/07/30/nabj-convention-co-chair-karen-attiah-resigns-trump-chicago-qa/", "title": "Black journalists convention leader resigns ahead of Trump Q&A in Chicago", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's scheduled appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists convention has forced one of its leaders to jump ship.\n\nOn Tuesday, co-chair Karen Attiah announced on social media she was stepping down ahead of the former president's planned Q&A on Wednesday in Chicago.\n\nAttiah, an editor and columnist for The Washington Post, said a \"variety\" of factors influenced her decision, but confirmed she was not consulted about giving Trump a \"platform\" at the gathering.\n\nMonday night's announcement of Trump's sitdown interview during the convention's opening day has caused a firestorm both in and out of the 49-year-old nonprofit organization.\n\nThe National Newspaper Publishers Association, which represents over 250 Black-owned newspapers and media companies, condemned the decision on Tuesday, pointing to Trump's \"divisive rhetoric and actions [that] have harmed marginalized communities, particularly the Black community.\"\n\nOn Instagram, \"New York Live\" host Jacque Reid wrote that she \"could not be more disappointed by this.\"\n\n\"I know NABJ has a history of inviting all presidential candidates, but this is not the year for that. Not with this man,\" Reid said. \"We need to be bombarding the world with how dangerous he is, not playing into news media efforts trying to normalize him and participating in efforts to put him back in office.\"\n\nRoland Martin, a former CNN anchor and NABJ Hall of Fame inductee, called the decision \"an abomination\" and said he found it troubling that no Black male journalists were invited to question \"serial liar\" Trump.\n\nABC News congressional correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News anchor Harris Faulkner and Semafor politics editor Kadia Goba were announced as the moderators of Wednesday's conversation.\n\nTrump's appearance at the NABJ convention marks the first time a GOP presidential candidate has accepted such an invitation since George W. Bush spoke before the 2004 Unity: Journalists of Color coalition.\n\nIn their announcement, NABJ acknowledged that Vice President Kamala Harris \"was also invited to participate in this year's convention\" but that her confirmation was \"pending.\"", "source": {"uri": "nydailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "karu_f_daniels@nydailynews.com", "name": "Karu F. {"uri": "8251389601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:50:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:50:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:48:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/a-speaking-invitation-to-donald-trump-splits-the-most-prominent-american-group-for-black-journalists/article_d1a3b535-f32c-5b80-8df2-bf29436a4e8e.html", "title": "A speaking invitation to Donald Trump splits the most prominent American group for Black journalists", "body": "By MATT BROWN - Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump's invitation to address the National Association of Black Journalists has sparked an intense debate within the organization and a flurry of arguments online.\n\nJournalism organizations for people of color traditionally invite presidential candidates to address their summer gatherings during election years. But Trump's acceptance of NABJ's invitation has led at least one high-profile group member to step down as a convention co-chair and others to argue their convention may become a platform for Trump to make false claims or be seen as winning NABJ's endorsement.\n\nTrump will be interviewed at 12 p.m. CDT Wednesday in Chicago by three reporters: Kadia Goba of Semafor, Rachel Scott of ABC News and Harris Faulkner of Fox News. Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic nominee and first Black woman to hold her office, is not currently scheduled to address the convention. A person familiar with her schedule, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Harris campaign was unable to find a time to appear at NABJ in person and claimed the organization turned down an offer for her to appear virtually.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington REO Speedwagon, Loverboy to perform in Bloomington this fall Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Normal man pleads guilty, sentenced for reckless driving in crash that injured 2 students Funerals pending for July 27 McLean County pathologist recognized for death investigation, tissue donation work\n\nThe debate over NABJ's invite reflects how many journalists are still grappling with how to approach Trump nearly a decade after his first presidential run. Some group members argued journalists should allow newsmakers to be heard, while others pointed to Trump's demeaning of prominent Black journalists while president and his frequent attacks on the free press, including labeling reporters \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\n\"I understand that the job should put us in tough situations if we're doing it in a meaningful way,\" wrote Tyler J. Davis, an NABJ member and freelance journalist, in The TRiiBE, a local Chicago Black news outlet.\n\n\"But this isn't a story assignment or a news conference or a newsroom. NABJ is a place of learning, networking and feeling supported. It's a space for Black folks to feel safe and celebrated; for Black media, specifically, to feel safe and celebrated,\" Davis wrote.\n\nKen Lemon, president of NABJ, insisted that the invitation was \"absolutely not an endorsement.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"We invited both of them, we got a yes from one of them,\" Lemon said. \"We'd love to get a yes from Kamala as well, but in this case this is an important hour.\"\n\nLemon added that the event would be a \"great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground\" and added that the association had worked with both campaigns for \"probably for more than a month\" and each had given \"the inclination that both were interested in being a part of what we're doing.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, a global opinions columnist for The Washington Post, stepped down as the co-chair of the 2024 convention in the wake of the announcement of Trump's appearance.\n\n\"To the journalists interviewing Trump, I wish them the best of luck,\" Attiah wrote on social media. \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format,\" she continued.\n\nSome industry leaders pushed back on the claim that Black journalists should not take opportunities to interview Trump, noting that any opportunity to hold powerful figures to account should not be wasted and that NABJ as a forum is especially suited to that mission.\n\n\"To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous,\" Rana Cash, the executive editor of the Charlotte Observer and an NABJ member, wrote on X.\n\nAssociated Press writer Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8251242758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:40:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:40:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:37:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/trump-invitation-to-conference-for-black-journalists-sets-off-intense-debate/", "title": "Trump Invitation to Conference for Black Journalists Sets Off Intense Debate", "body": "A scheduled appearance by former President Donald J. Trump at a conference for Black journalists in Chicago has generated fierce debate.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists, which is hosting the conference, announced on Monday that Mr. Trump would take part in a question-and-answer session with political reporters on Wednesday.\n\nThe conference's description says the session will \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\" Harris Faulkner, a Fox News anchor; Kadia Goba, a politics reporter at Semafor; and Rachel Scott, an ABC News correspondent, will moderate the session. The event is expected to be live-streamed on the organization's YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nAfter the announcement of the event with Mr. Trump, a number of well-known Black journalists harshly criticized the group for arranging it, arguing that the organization was giving a platform to someone who had openly denigrated a number of reporters.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then-president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the White House correspondent for The Grio, a media company geared toward Black Americans, wrote on the social platform X. She said the session was \"a slap in the face\" to Black female journalists \"who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\nJemele Hill, who hosts a podcast and is contributing writer for The Atlantic, said that while she did not have a problem with Mr. Trump's appearance \"under the right circumstances because he's a presidential candidate,\" she questioned the wisdom of the event.\n\n\"A sham of an interview will destroy the organization's credibility,\" she wrote on X. \"If the majority of NABJ's membership is against Trump being there, the organization should listen.\"\n\nKaren Attiah, a Washington Post columnist, said on X on Tuesday that she was stepping down as co-chair of this year's N.A.B.J. convention. She added in another post: \"While my decision was influenced by a variety of factors, I was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nBut the president of the N.A.B.J., as well as some other journalists, argued that the group had a long tradition of inviting presidential nominees and it was a chance to hold them accountable through questioning. Former Presidents George W. Bush Jr., Barack Obama and Bill Clinton had all previously attended, and the group had invited the presumptive Democratic presidential candidate, Vice President Kamala Harris, to this year's convention.\n\nIn a statement on N.A.B.J.'s website, its president, Ken Lemon, said that the organization looked forward to conference attendees' hearing from Mr. Trump.\n\n\"While N.A.B.J. does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" Mr. Lemon said.\n\nIn a video posted on Tuesday by NABJ Monitor, a student journalist-led outlet covering the convention, Mr. Lemon said that discussions with both the Republican and Democratic teams had been happening for more than a month.\n\n\"We invited both of them; we got a yes from one of them,\" he said.\n\nHe continued: \"This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate right here on our ground.\"\n\nMr. Lemon said that N.A.B.J. was working to set up a fact-checking process for Mr. Trump's appearance.\n\nLeroy Chapman Jr., the editor in chief of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, said in a post on X that he looked forward to the Republican presidential nominee visiting the convention, and that he would welcome the presumptive Democratic nominee there too.\n\n\"Here is what we need to 'normalize' -- candidates for office standing before journalists, answering questions,\" he wrote.\n\nRana Cash, the executive editor of The Charlotte Observer, said on X: \"It's the National Association of Black 'Journalists' -- journalists who are experts at their craft, highly qualified and critical thinkers. To suggest they not interview a Presidential candidate on issues relevant to the organization's constituency is outrageous.\"\n\nFor nearly a decade, there have been furious journalistic debates about the degree to which Mr. Trump should be given a platform, given his propensity to lie and make false claims in speeches. The appearance at a conference for Black journalists adds more complexity: Mr. Trump has frequently denigrated working journalists and has a history of racist comments about Black voters.\n\nMr. Trump's presidential campaign said in a news release on Monday announcing his appearance at the N.A.B.J. convention that he had \"accomplished more for Black Americans than any other president in recent history.\" The campaign also pointed to an April poll in The Wall Street Journal that showed increased support for Mr. Trump among Black men.\n\nJaniyah Thomas, director of Black media for Mr. Trump's campaign, wrote in an email: \"While Kamala Harris has ignored the invitation from the National Association of Black Journalists, President Trump is grateful for the opportunity to bring his message to their diverse audience. Team Trump believes it's important to give Black journalists more access to presidential candidates so they can better inform Black voters.\"", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-438814349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:06:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:06:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:47:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.axios.com/local/chicago/2024/07/30/president-trump-nabj-conference", "title": "Trump's planned appearance at NABJ conference upsets some Chicago journalists", "body": "Why it matters: The group has a history of inviting presidential candidates to its annual conference, but Trump's participation is causing a rift between members, especially in a city that the former president has openly maligned.\n\nCatch up quick: Trump will be interviewed at noon by a panel of Black journalists, including ABC News correspondent Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nWhat they're saying: Chicago journalists joined the national chorus denouncing the decision to include Trump.\n\nThe other side: NABJ president Ken Lemon defended the decision saying, \"Every year, every presidential election cycle, we invite the presidential candidates. We extend that to anyone who is a nominee. And in this case, we have two presumptive nominees. We invited both of them. We got a yes from one of them.\"\n\nState of play: Several groups have planned to protest at the Chicago Hilton, where the conference is being held, including the U.S. Palestinian Community Network and the Chicago Alliance Against Racist and Political Repression.\n\nFlashback: In 2016, Trump abruptly canceled a campaign rally at UIC after chaotic protests disrupted the area hours before. This will mark only his second time returning to the city limits since then.\n\nZoom out: An Instagram post from NABJ on Monday has racked up over 1,000 comments from members and onlookers of NABJ who are expressing frustration either with Trump's participation or with the pushback against it.\n\nZoom in: The Chicago chapter of NABJ was not involved in the decision to schedule Trump, sources told {"uri": "8250961729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:57:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:57:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:56:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.theroot.com/trump-is-visiting-the-nabj-conference-in-chicago-and-b-1851608852", "title": "Trump is Visiting the NABJ Conference in Chicago, and Black Twitter is Sharply Divided About the Whole Thing", "body": "Former president Donald Trump will appear at the National Association of Black Journalists' annual conference in Chicago on Wednesday (July 31). The announcement Monday night. He will sit for a panel moderated by three Black women -- ABC's Rachel Scott, FOX News' Harris Faulkner and Semafor reporter Kadia Goba.\n\nIn response to the news, Black Twitter became ablaze with anger, frustration and confusion.\n\nMany feel that Trump, who has a disturbing history of racism -- including discriminating against Black tenants, calling for the execution of the Central Park 5, deeming white supremacists \"very fine people\" and quoting Hitler -- should not be platformed at an event for Black journalists.\n\nEsteemed White House correspondent April Ryan spoke out and shared her disgust over the shocking announcement.\n\n\"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025,\" she wrote.\n\nMorgan Elise Johnson plainly wrote: \"I would like to unwelcome @NABJ for surprising Chicago with this Trump news, a man who has threatened Chicago with state violence in his stump speeches -- and attracts a white supremacist following to a Black affinity space.\n\nAnother user, @MelechThomas, called the choice for NABJ Convention to host Trump nasty work. \"Even if you're trying to 'dunk' on him, Donald Trump should not be platformed at all. Idc how brilliant your clapbacks are, he should not be allowed to speak publicly. He is a danger to our nation.\"\n\nSome are supporting NABJ's decision to platform Trump, including Atlanta Journal-Constitution correspondent Tia Mitchell, who suggested that journalists should want to ask the potential future president questions.\n\nSports journalist Jemele Hill tried to both sides the situation, saying that journalists \"can never be afraid to tackle someone like Trump\" and that Trump is \"running for president and needs to be treated as such.\" However, @ocbuckner quickly checked Hill with one of her past tweets.\n\nIn the screenshot, Hill previously stated \"It's journalistically irresponsible to give a platform to known liars. Our profession can't continue to die on the stupid hill of both-side-rism.\"\n\nDavid Dennis Jr. put it best when he stated: \"[Trump]\" doesn't even believe the National Association Of Black Journalists should even exist lmao like what are we doing right now.\"", "source": {"uri": "theroot.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Root"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438797601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:35:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:35:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:34:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://thegrio.com/2024/07/30/the-national-association-of-black-journalists-should-rescind-donald-trumps-invitation-to-the-cookout/", "title": "The National Association of Black Journalists should rescind Donald Trump's invitation to the cookout", "body": "Editor's note: The following article is an op-ed, and the views expressed are the author's own. Read more opinions on theGrio.\n\nMy grandmother was a follower of the Gospel of Jesus Christ.\n\nEvery day at sunrise, noon and sunset, she rested all 128 pounds of her body weight on her 74-year-old, cartilage-depleted knees to thank her Lord and Savior for his mercy and grace. In exchange for his divine protection, she lived by the letter of the Mosaic law. She did not steal. She did not bear false witness. And no human being who ever had the honor of basking in the glorious presence of Marvell Harriot would use profanity in her company.\n\nUntil she gave her grandson a lesson on blessing, biblical cussing and -- most of all -- journalism.\n\nAt 6 years old, I was either a juvenile storytelling prodigy or my mother's mother was the most talented improvisational actress in history. Grumma listened patiently to every single word of my rambling childhood stories. She howled with laughter at my jokes and asked follow-up questions. Yet, when I briefly forgot about her anointing, I knew I was in trouble. \"Goddamnit!\" I yelled while performing a spot-on impersonation of my foul-mouthed uncle's reaction to a bee sting. \"Goddamn these goddamned bees done stung-\"\n\nFreezing midsentence as my grandma's guffaws transformed into shock, I hung my head as she stared at her heretofore favorite grandson. \"You can say it,\" said my grandmother, shattering the awkward silence. \"Long as you ain't bearin' false witness. It's not a sin if it's the truth.\"\n\nRecommended Stories\n\nI still wasn't buying it. Not only had I used the Lord's name in vain, I might have killed my grandmother. What if my obscene language penetrated Granny's Holy Ghost deflector shield? Breaking two of the top 10 Commandments at once would surely send me straight to hell. But when she said: \"Baby, yo ox in the ditch,\" I immediately felt relief. She wanted me to be free.\n\nGrumma was referencing Luke 14. According to the story, a guest at a Pharisee cookout suggested that Jesus was violating his daddy's rules by healing a sick man on God's designated day off. \"What if your child or your ox falls into a ditch on the Sabbath day,\" asked God's vice president in charge of prayer relations \"Would you let them die or would you pull it out?\" While the Pharisees didn't have an answer, if the National Association of Black Journalists wrote the Bible, the scripture would probably be different:\n\nIt is a fact that Trump told the 2017 NABJ Journalist of the Year to \"sit down\" when theGrio's White House Correspondent and Washington Bureau Chief April Ryan confronted him about voter suppression. During a White House press briefing, Trump's press secretary called for 2018 Journalist of the Year Jemele Hill to be fired. After 2020 NABJ Journalist of the Year Yamiche Alcindor caught him in a lie, Trump wondered why \"you people act\" so negatively, warning Alcindor to \"be nice.\" Yet those attacks pale in comparison to Trump's tweets about Black journalist Don Lemon.\n\nApparently, none of that matters.\n\n\"President Donald J. Trump, 45th President of the United States of America, will participate in a conversation with journalists at the National Association of Black Journalists Annual Convention and Career Fair on Wednesday, July 31, 2024, at 12:00 PM CST,\" read a press release by from the lying, aspiring dictator who levied racial attacks against NABJ members. \"President Trump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community. The event will be moderated by Rachel Scott, senior congressional correspondent for ABC News; Harris Faulkner, anchor of The Faulkner Focus and co-host of Outnumbered on FOX News; and Kadia Goba, politics reporter at Semafor.\"\n\nAlthough Donald Trump describes all media as the \"enemy of the people,\" NABJ Political Journalism Task Force chair Tia Mitchell was technically correct when she claimed Trump's appearance is \"in line with invitations NABJ has sent to every presidential candidate for decades.\" According to the age-old notion of \"journalistic objectivity,\" I believe we should treat all political candidates equally. But who cares about the rules of objectivity? The letter of the law is less important than the spirit of the law. Whether they serve as religious principles, moral codes or ethical guidelines, the most effective rules are created in service of an outcome, not just to regulate behavior. This universal concept is so simple that a 6-year-old storyteller, a septuagenarian grandparent and even the greatest nepo baby ever born can understand.\n\nEven though I am a dues-paying NABJ member, my feelings about Donald Trump are inconsequential. It is not my opinion that Black journalists make up 6% of the profession. It is not my opinion that ESPN, CNN and MSNBC did nothing to protect employees like Hill, Lemon and Tiffany Cross from racist attacks. As someone who attends the NABJ national convention every year and is also scheduled to lead a convention panel on Project 2025, my belief should not matter. However, NABJ's stated purpose is \"sensitizing all media to the importance of fairness in the workplace for Black journalists\" is what matters. An organization that \"advocates for Black journalists worldwide\" matters. It is not my opinion that welcoming Donald Trump to a place created to protect Black journalists is like asking a slave catcher to the abolitionist's meeting. Yet, behind the scenes, some of your favorite media icons are clamoring to bask in the orange glow of the biggest threat to democracy since the MAGA minions tried to disappear the ballots of Black voters and overthrow the country we built.\n\nAnd, for what?\n\nIf the greatest Black journalists who ever existed manage to expose Donald Trump for the vile, racist, wannabe dictator that he is, will we learn anything new? Even if they manage to achieve the most rigorous interrogation of the aspiring dictator to date, how many minds will they change? What are they trying to show us about this hate monger that we haven't already seen? I thought we were going to \"protect Black women\"? How are we \"saving democracy\" while aiding and abetting the man who wants to destroy it? Whose minds are they trying to change anyway? Who are they trying to prove themselves to?\n\nThe answer is \"white people.\"\n\nWhite people are the reason the NABJ exists. We already know white people don't trust our voices or care about us. If they did, we wouldn't need an NABJ. If white people listened to Black people, Donald Trump wouldn't be a presidential candidate in the first place. We are the only ones who believe in performatively following a set of arbitrary rules that we have the power to change. Ask the women who can't get an abortion because Trump stripped them of their reproductive rights. Ask the \"diversity hires\" and the people who were victimized by the Trump-inspired rise in white supremacy.\n\nAsk my grumma.\n\nGod damn Donald Trump and the National Association of Black Journalists.\n\nI would never use the Lord's name in vain. Then again, it is not a sin if it is the truth. I want God to damn his presidential campaign. I want my ancestors to smite the false notion of appealing to white sensibilities that fosters an allegiance to ideas and rules created to harm Black people. I want us to protect Black women and ourselves. But more than anything ...\n\nI want us to be free.", "source": {"uri": "thegrio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheGrio"}, "authors": [{"uri": "michael_harriot@thegrio.com", "name": "Michael {"uri": "8250893468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:09:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:09:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:09:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.essence.com/news/money-career/donald-trump-nabj-convention-chicago/", "title": "The Internet Responds To Donald Trump's Planned Appearance At NABJ -- A Convention And Career Fair For Black Media | Essence", "body": "The annual National Association Of Black Journalists Convention is an event aimed at convening, connecting and empowering Black media professionals. However, a recent addition to its speaker lineup is leading some onlookers to believe the move is the antithesis of the event's mission.\n\nOn July 29, it was reported that former President Donald J. Trump will participate in a conversation with journalists during its opening day in Chicago on Wednesday, July 31, at noon CST. The conversation would be moderated by ABC News's Rachel Scott, Fox News host Harris Faulkner and Kadia Goba Semafor, a politics reporter who covered Congress for Axios and BuzzFeed News.\n\nJournalists took to X to express their thoughts on the addition, with many vehemently opposing it, claiming the move was counterproductive.\n\nSome users pointed to Trump's fraught relationship with Chicago, the location the convention will be taking place this year. The city's Mayor, Brandon Johnson stated that the Chicago's city departments are 'fully prepared to uphold safety', a reference to the Trump's track record of inciting violent loyalists at public events.\n\nDuring his 2016 election run, Trump blamed President Obama for the blighted conditions some Chicagoans faced in his \"home town\" during the Republican National Convention, and subsequently almost obsessively mentioned Chicago in a negative light during his public speeches.\n\n\"We have a situation where we have our inner cities - African Americans, Hispanics are living in hell because it's so dangerous,\" Trump said in September 2016 presidential debate. \"You walk down the street, you get shot. In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1. Thousands of shootings. And I say, where is this? Is this is a war-torn country? What are we doing?\"\n\nOther X users pointed out that NABJ is a non-partisan organization and have invited past Presidential candidates from both sides of the aisle to participate in the convention.\n\n\"People really upset about Trump speaking at NABJ? The organization is non partisan,\" one user wrote. \"I think some of y'all forget that the job of journalists are to ask the questions, regardless of who they are. This isn't CNN. NABJ doesn't monetarily gain anything by doing this.\"", "source": {"uri": "essence.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Essence"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "Former President Donald Trump will travel to Chicago this week to speak at the National Association of Black Journalists convention, and the news has drawn mixed reactions from the group and from local and state officials.\n\nTrump's visit comes amid a turbulent presidential campaign that has already seen plenty of drama, and the invitation for him to address the group in an interview has sparked plenty of debate in its own right.\n\n\"We invite presidential candidates to come forward,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said. \"We reach out to anyone who is a candidate, and in this case, we have two presumptive candidates.\"\n\nLemon also said there would be real-time fact-checking of the president's remarks, rather than a campaign-style speech.\n\n\"It's our job as journalists to have those uncomfortable conversations, so that the people who rely on us to inform them get their information from an informed source,\" he said.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic nominee, will not be able to address the convention but has made efforts to schedule another meeting with the group, according to NBC 5 political reporter Mary Ann Ahern.\n\nTrump's appearance has caused serious divisions within the NABJ, with the co-chair of this week's convention, Washington Post reporter Karen Attiah, announcing she was resigning from her position after not being consulted about the event.\n\nThe last time Trump visited Chicago was for a rally in 2019, with hundreds of protesters gathered outside Trump Tower in the Loop, dozens of physical altercations in the audience at the University of Illinois at Chicago and plenty of rancor from the then-president himself, who criticized former Chicago Police Superintendent David Brown as a disgrace.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump, the current Republican presidential nominee, will travel to Chicago on Wednesday and attend the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention and career fair, the NABJ announced Monday night.\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, a harsh critic of the former president, vows the city will be prepared for the visit, but has had strong words about Trump's alleged disdain for Chicago.\n\n\"It's no secret that former President Donald Trump is an abuser,\" he said. \"He was particularly cruel to many people, particularly in the black press.\"\n\nIllinois Gov. {"uri": "2024-07-438717810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:38:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:38:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_4b59ad3e-a149-591d-a9e0-be7e63103b5c.html", "title": "Chicago GOP anticipates bump from upcoming Trump event with Black journalists", "body": "(The Center Square) - Former President Donald Trump is scheduled to speak Wednesday afternoon at the National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Chicago.\n\nThe NABJ said Trump will engage in a Q&A with political journalists before an audience of registered convention attendees that will concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\n\nNABJ President Ken Lemon said, \"We look forward to our attendees hearing from former President Trump on the critical issues our members and their audiences care about most.\"\n\nChicago Republican Party Chairman and 38th Ward Committeeman Chuck Hernandez said Trump's popularity is skyrocketing in the Black community.\n\n\"You know, it's just amazing to see him travel the country with the energy that he has and reaching out to every group in America,\" Hernandez said.\n\nHernandez expects the former president's visit to energize Republicans in the city.\n\n\"We are making inroads in every demographic group in Chicago. We want to reach every neighborhood,\" Hernandez said.\n\nHernandez said he would like the former president to remind the audience that the economy was flourishing when Trump was in office.\n\n\"We had a strong economy. We had low inflation. Every demographic group in America was making more money, you know,\" he said. \"We were at peace. He was ending wars. And even to that specific group, right, he led the permanent funding for Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and that had never happened before,\" Hernandez said.\n\nFellow presidential candidate and current Vice President Kamala Harris was also invited to participate. {"uri": "2024-07-439367493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-07-31/trump-sitdown-at-black-journalists-convention-sparks-backlash", "title": "Trump Sitdown at Black Journalists' Convention Sparks Backlash", "body": "CHICAGO (Reuters) - Donald Trump speaks at the country's largest annual gathering of Black journalists on Wednesday, an effort to bolster the Republican presidential candidate's standing that has divided the group's members.\n\nTrump's first-ever appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention in Chicago comes a week after the 2024 election was shaken up by President Joe Biden's decision to drop out.\n\nThe group, founded in 1975, regularly invites presidential candidates to address its annual gathering, but Trump is the first Republican to accept the offer since George W. Bush spoke at a conference they co-hosted in 2004.\n\nTrump is scheduled to be interviewed on Wednesday afternoon at the event by three Black women journalists, Fox News' Harris Faulkner, ABC News' Rachel Scott and Semafor's Kadia Goba.\n\nSome members said the group should not offer a platform to Trump, who has denigrated the work of Black journalists, sometimes in personal terms. Trump has also used racist and dehumanizing language on the campaign trail.\n\nWashington Post columnist Karen Attiah stepped down as a co-chair from the convention, saying on social media that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nIn Chicago, a protest was expected outside the venue where Trump was scheduled to speak. Trump has regularly criticized the city's largely Democratic political leadership for Chicago's levels of street violence.\n\n\"Here is what we need to 'normalize' - candidates for office standing before journalists, answering questions,\" said Leroy Chapman Jr, editor of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, a newspaper.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists includes a range of members, from reporters with legacy media outlets that hope to preserve a working relationship with Trump to Black-owned outlets and journalists whose work takes a stridently anti-Trump tone.\n\nTrump made his resentful relationship with many of the media outlets who cover him a focus of his 2016, 2020 and 2024 campaigns and sparred with members of the White House press corps during his 2017-2021 presidency.\n\nNow, Trump's campaign faces a likely race against Vice President Kamala Harris as she seeks to be the first Black and Asian woman president, the prospect of which has drawn millions of dollars in donations to the Democrat's campaign.\n\nBiden was planning to attend this year's convention before he dropped his presidential bid on July 21.\n\nHarris, who was invited, could not make it to Chicago in person but is willing to participate in a virtual fireside chat with the organization, according to a person familiar with her plans.\n\nAs a candidate, Biden had been struggling to mobilize Black voters, especially Black men, allowing Trump to make inroads with that demographic.\n\nA Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Tuesday showed Harris slightly increasing her support from Black voters over Biden's numbers, with 73%, up from Biden's 69% earlier in July and Trump's support dropping to 10%, from 15%. Nine in 10 Black voters supported Biden in 2020.\n\nTrump has been actively courting Black voters and has held events in cities with large Black populations, including Atlanta, where he plans a rally on Saturday.\n\n\"For us as journalists, people who go into and have very uncomfortable conversations for the sake of our members, this is an important time,\" National Association of Black Journalists president Ken Lemon said on social media. \"This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate.\"\n\nThe organization picked the moderators, there were no preconditions for Trump to appear and he was not given questions in advance, according to people familiar with the campaign's planning for the session.\n\n(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt, Tyler Clifford, Bianca Flowers, Tim Reid and Jim Oliphant; Editing by Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Republican Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "2024 United States presidential election"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Fox News"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harris_Faulkner", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Harris Faulkner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_of_Black_Journalists", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "National Association of Black Journalists"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_W._Bush", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "George W. {"uri": "8252154216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:35:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:35:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:34:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://richmond.com/opinion/columnists/williams-black-journalists-organization-should-not-platform-trump/article_37f02384-4e82-11ef-a08a-0f461cb0db72.html", "title": "Williams: Black journalists' organization should not platform Trump", "body": "Michael Paul Williams\n\nDespite Donald Trump's incitement of an insurrection and the ongoing campaign to install him as an American f\u00fchrer, my fellow journalists still haven't grasped the pitfalls of platforming a pathological liar who branded them as \"the enemy of the people.\"\n\nThe normalization of Trump continues apace with the National Association of Black Journalists inviting him to speak Wednesday at its convention in Chicago. He's scheduled to participate in a Q&A session, with Rachel Scott of ABC News, Harris Faulkner of FOX News and Kadia Goba of Semafor serving as moderators.\n\nWilliams: From George Floyd to Sonya Massey, still waiting for justice\n\n\"While NABJ does not endorse political candidates as a journalism organization, we understand the serious work of our members, and welcome the opportunity for them to ask the tough questions that will provide the truthful answers Black Americans want and need to know,\" NABJ president Ken Lemon said on the organization's website.\n\nPeople are also reading... Outer Banks wild stallion hit, killed on the beach 'Illegal' recruiting a hot topic at VHSL meeting in Abingdon; John Marshall called out Former Virginia EMS employee pleads guilty to embezzling $4 million As Kings Dominion merges with Six Flags, some fans worry quality will suffer Virginia collects $1.2 billion more revenue than expected Thousands watch Chincoteague wild ponies complete 99th swim UPDATE: Police ID victim, announce arrest in shooting involving Chesterfield couple UVa's Gretchen Walsh sets Olympic record in 100 butterfly on opening night of Paris Games Youngkin names Scalia daughter to Board of Education Search for missing 12-year-old swimmer on Outer Banks ends in tragedy Dominion customers' bills to rise for offshore project costs Henrico homeowners upset by Goochland quarry expansion Teel: Jeff Jones hosts special Virginia basketball reunion Kline's Dairy Bar opens in Chesterfield Richmonders weigh in on Kamala Harris as presumptive Democratic nominee\n\nTruthful answers?\n\nTrump?\n\nBwahahahaa!\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic Party nominee, has also been invited to the convention as part of NABJ's tradition of asking the nominee of each major party to appear. That's a fine practice in times when the future of democracy is not on the ballot and rogue jurists have not functioned as wholly owned subsidiaries of MAGA Inc. in placing Trump above the law. But this is no time to embrace the banality of bothsidesism.\n\nWilliams: Demonizing DEI is the latest GOP dog whistle\n\nThe nostalgia that frames Trump's \"Make America Great Again\" sloganeering is a rejection of Black uplift and advancement.\n\nTrump was the lead dog-whistler in the racist birther lie that Barack Obama was a noncitizen and illegitimate president. He tried the same stunt on Kamala Harris, the California-born daughter of immigrants of Jamaican and South Asian descent.\n\nHe instituted a ban against Muslim immigrants. His past and present campaigns have been centered on fear-mongering of would-be immigrants from Latin America. He found \"very fine people, on both sides\" in the aftermath of a Charlottesville rally of Nazis and other white supremacists that turned deadly. And several months before the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the U.S. Capitol by his supporters, he told the Proud Boys to \"stand back and stand by.\"\n\nAll of this has helped make him the favored candidate of white supremacists, who've attacked Usha Vance, the wife of Trump running mate JD Vance, because she is Indian-American and Hindu.\n\nIn the meantime, Trump allies have been pushing an agenda to purge America of all vestiges of diversity, equity and inclusion. (They must be hating the gold medal-winning U.S. women's gymnastics team right now.)\n\nIn this context, it takes a lot of mental gymnastics to view Trump as a supporter of Black people.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nJournalists have no obligation to disseminate misinformation, Trump's specialty. NABJ's stated role is as an advocacy group for Black journalists and media professionals. And Trump's contempt for Black journalists was on vivid display during his presidency.\n\nWilliams: Political violence? This is who we are\n\nApril Ryan, White House correspondent for The Grio, objected to Trump's appearance at NABJ in a social media post.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" Ryan wrote. \"To have a presumed orchestrated session with the former president is an affront to what this organization stands for and a slap in the face to the Black women journalists (NABJ journalists of the year) who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\nWashington Post columnist Karen Attiah stepped down as co-chair of the convention, posting on X, formerly known as Twitter, that she \"was not involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nI saw this hens-invites-fox scenario play out in July 1998, when the National Bar Association, the nation's largest Black lawyers group, invited Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas to their Memphis, Tennessee, gathering amid internal conflict. On that occasion, Thomas offered no apologies for his record and painted himself as a victim.\n\nHow'd that turn out for us?\n\nIt would be astonishing for any NABJ-member question, no matter how penetrating, to extract a meaningful response from a guy whose superpower is his imperviousness to accountability. It should be clear ever since the Access Hollywood tape that nothing Trump says will cool the ardor of his devoted supporters.\n\nWilliams: Is America approaching its expiration date?\n\nConversely, Trump can't lose by appearing in Chicago, a city he has used as fear-stoking shorthand for the perils of urban America. If the questions are too hard-hitting for his taste, he'll do what he does best: play the victim. If he lashes out at Black journalists, his followers will cheer. And if he comes off as reasonable, or even charming, it might bolster his inexplicable support among some Black voters.\n\nTrying to extract substance from Trump is a fool's errand, for reasons beyond his rambling stream-of-consciousness incoherence. Journalists cannot divine truths from a man seemingly incapable of mouthing them. Instead, this invite confers credibility on a guy who -- if we were truly a nation of laws and not of men -- would be behind bars instead of campaigning for president.\n\nThere's a weird compulsion in the media, and a chunk of the electorate, to not take Trump's words and actions at face value even as he says the incriminating part out loud. He said he has no plans to be a dictator \"except for day one\" -- and America shrugged. He told a gathering of Christian conservatives that if they support him this time around, \"In four years, you don't have to vote again.\" In March, American Conservative, a partner of the Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 wish list for a second Trump term, argued on behalf of overturning the 22nd Amendment limiting presidents to two terms.\n\nIt's as if America hadn't heard Trump express admiration for dictators or witness his attempt to overturn the 2020 election -- he's still repeating the lie that it was stolen. Somehow, despite the plain language of the 14th Amendment barring those who have \"engaged in insurrection or rebellion\" from holding office again, America is giving Trump a chance to return to the White House.\n\nBlack journalists, part of America's most enduringly vulnerable population, should realize this is no ordinary election. The focus in Chicago should be on nurturing Black journalism professionals, not making news.\n\nThere isn't ground high enough to justify this invite. It's never wise to hand a megaphone to a madman.\n\nPHOTOS: Trump rally in Richmond\n\nMichael Paul Williams (804) 649-6815\n\nmwilliams@timesdispatch.com\n\nMichael Paul Williams\n\nColumnist\n\nAuthor twitter Author email Follow Michael Paul Williams Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! NABJ Officials Face Major Backlash For Inviting Donald Trump To Panel Discussion\n\nDonald Trump is very likely the most polarizing public figure in modern American history. Anything, anyone, or any group associated with him is instantly subject to criticism, ridicule, and insult. That was just the short list of Trump's undignified accomplishments but the rabbit hole goes deep, we could go further, we promise.\n\nWe say all that to say that inviting said individual to a Black a** function is not only bad PR but poor judgment and inexplicable malpractice. However, that is exactly what the National Association of Black Journalists (NABJ) has decided to do. Chaos erupted on Twitter last night after the organization announced that Trump would be in attendance at the 2024 conference this week.\n\nInstantly, everyone from prominent Black journalists to people who have no connection to professional media whatsoever began collectively scratching their heads and firing off soul-piercing tweets toward NABJ, the chairperson, and the organization's president.\n\nChairwoman Tia Mitchell spent much of the evening trying to justify her decision which only further irritated the members who were appalled at her lack of foresight, care, or consideration.\n\nNABJ President, Ken Lemon attempted to clean up aisle 6 but the damage was already done...\n\nSome folks are defending NABJ's decision to have Trump as a platform to ask \"tough questions\" or \"seek truth\" or whatever other silly journalistic mantras that some feel emotionally beholden to. "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/dnc-chicago-2024/as-trump-prepares-for-chicago-visit-johnson-and-pritzker-share-strong-reactions/3506092/", "title": "As Trump prepares for Chicago visit, Johnson and Pritzker share strong reactions", "body": "Former President Donald Trump will visit Chicago this week to speak at the National Association of Black Journalists' convention, and the news has sparked mixed reaction both within that group and from local and state officials.\n\nTrump's visit comes amid a heated presidential campaign that has already seen plenty of drama, and the invitation for him to address the group in an interview-style setting has sparked plenty of debate on its own.\n\n\"We invite the presidential candidates to come,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said. \"We extend to anyone who's a nominee, and in this case, we have two presumptive nominees.\"\n\nLemon also said there will be a real-time fact check of the president's remarks, rather than a campaign-style speech.\n\n\"It's our job as journalists to have those uncomfortable conversations, so that the people who count on us to inform them get it from an informed source,\" he said.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party, will not be able to address the convention, but has made efforts to schedule another meeting with the group, according to NBC 5 Political Reporter Mary Ann Ahern.\n\nTrump's appearance has caused serious division within NABJ, with the co-chair of this week's convention, Washington Post reporter Karen Attiah, announcing that she was stepping down from her role after not being consulted about the event.\n\nTrump last visited Chicago for a 2019 rally, with hundreds of protesters gathering outside Trump Tower in the Loop, dozens of physical altercations in the audience at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and plenty of rancor from the then-president himself, who criticized former Chicago Police Supt. David Brown as a \"disgrace.\"\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, a harsh critic of the former president, pledges that the city will be prepared for the visit, but had strong words about Trump's alleged contempt for Chicago.\n\n\"There's no secret that the former president Donald Trump is an abuser,\" he said. \"He was quite cruel to many individuals in the Black press in particular.\"\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker also blasted Trump's visit, saying he has repeatedly insulted Midwestern cities and values.\n\n\"Every time Donald Trump visits the Midwest he tells us how much he hates it,\" he said. \"He called Milwaukee horrible. He called Detroit corrupt. He denigrated Chicago police. Trump at a conference for Black journalists in Chicago has generated fierce debate.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists, which is hosting the conference, announced on Monday that Mr. Trump would take part in a question-and-answer session with political reporters on Wednesday.\n\nThe conference's description says the session will \"concentrate on the most pressing issues facing the Black community.\" Harris Faulkner, a Fox News anchor; Kadia Goba, a politics reporter at Semafor; and Rachel Scott, an ABC News correspondent, will moderate the session. The event is expected to be live-streamed on the organization's YouTube and Facebook pages.\n\nAfter the announcement of the event with Mr. Trump, a number of well-known Black journalists harshly criticized the group for arranging it, arguing that the organization was giving a platform to someone who had openly denigrated a number of reporters.\n\n\"The reports of attacks on Black women White House correspondents by the then-president of the United States are not myth or conjecture, but fact,\" April Ryan, the White House correspondent for The Grio, a media company geared toward Black Americans, wrote on the social platform X. She said the session was \"a slap in the face\" to Black female journalists \"who had to protect themselves from the wrath of this Republican presidential nominee who is promoting an authoritarian agenda that plans to destroy this nation and her democracy with his Project 2025.\"\n\nJemele Hill, who hosts a podcast and is contributing writer for The Atlantic, said that while she did not have a {"uri": "8252359151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:35:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:35:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:33:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/us-politics/article-donald-trumps-appearance-at-black-journalists-convention-sparks/", "title": "Donald Trump's appearance at Black journalists' convention sparks backlash", "body": "Donald Trump speaks at the country's largest annual gathering of Black journalists on Wednesday, an effort to bolster the Republican presidential candidate's standing that has divided the group's members.\n\nTrump's first-ever appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists' annual convention in Chicago comes a week after the 2024 election was shaken up by President Joe Biden's decision to drop out.\n\nThe group, founded in 1975, regularly invites presidential candidates to address its annual gathering, but Trump is the first Republican to accept the offer since George W. Bush spoke at a conference they co-hosted in 2004.\n\nTrump is scheduled to be interviewed on Wednesday afternoon at the event by three Black women journalists, Fox News' Harris Faulkner, ABC News' Rachel Scott and Semafor's Kadia Goba.\n\nSome members said the group should not offer a platform to Trump, who has denigrated the work of Black journalists, sometimes in personal terms. Trump has also used racist and dehumanizing language on the campaign trail.\n\nWashington Post columnist Karen Attiah stepped down as a co-chair from the convention, saying on social media that she had not been \"involved or consulted with in any way with the decision to platform Trump in such a format.\"\n\nIn Chicago, a protest was expected outside the venue where Trump was scheduled to speak. Trump has regularly criticized the city's largely Democratic political leadership for Chicago's levels of street violence.\n\n\"Here is what we need to 'normalize' - candidates for office standing before journalists, answering questions,\" said Leroy Chapman Jr, editor of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, a newspaper.\n\nThe National Association of Black Journalists includes a range of members, from reporters with legacy media outlets that hope to preserve a working relationship with Trump to Black-owned outlets and journalists whose work takes a stridently anti-Trump tone.\n\nTrump made his resentful relationship with many of the media outlets who cover him a focus of his 2016, 2020 and 2024 campaigns and sparred with members of the White House press corps during his 2017-2021 presidency.\n\nNow, Trump's campaign faces a likely race against Vice President Kamala Harris as she seeks to be the first Black and Asian woman president, the prospect of which has drawn millions of dollars in donations to the Democrat's campaign.\n\nBiden was planning to attend this year's convention before he dropped his presidential bid on July 21.\n\nHarris, who was invited, could not make it to Chicago in person but is willing to participate in a virtual fireside chat with the organization, according to a person familiar with her plans.\n\nAs a candidate, Biden had been struggling to mobilize Black voters, especially Black men, allowing Trump to make inroads with that demographic.\n\nA Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Tuesday showed Harris slightly increasing her support from Black voters over Biden's numbers, with 73%, up from Biden's 69% earlier in July and Trump's support dropping to 10%, from 15%. Nine in 10 Black voters supported Biden in 2020.\n\nTrump has been actively courting Black voters and has held events in cities with large Black populations, including Atlanta, where he plans a rally on Saturday.\n\n\"For us as journalists, people who go into and have very uncomfortable conversations for the sake of our members, this is an important time,\" National Association of Black Journalists president Ken Lemon said on social media. \"This is a great opportunity for us to vet the candidate.\"\n\nThe organization picked the moderators, there were no preconditions for Trump to appear and he was not given questions in advance, according to people familiar with the campaign's planning for the session.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8252366878", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:39:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:39:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:38:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/dnc-chicago-2024/trump-in-chicago-at-nabj-event-wednesday-traffic-protests-expected/3506571/", "title": "Trump in Chicago at NABJ event Wednesday; traffic, protests expected", "body": "At least two outside groups are planning to protest Former President Donald Trump's address, set to take place in the early afternoon\n\nProtests and traffic are expected in downtown Chicago Wednesday as former President Donald Trump will be in town to speak at the National Association of Black Journalists.\n\nAccording to organizers, Trump will be at the five-day convention, which begins Wednesday at the Hilton Hotel, 720 S. Michigan Avenue, for a question and answer session moderated by three journalists. Tight security is expected, and only registered convention attendees can attend, organizers said.\n\nTrump's appearance at the convention has sparked mixed reactions from within the NABJ, with the co-chair of this week's convention, Washington Post reporter Karen Attiah, announcing that she was stepping down from her role after not being consulted about initiation for Trump to speak.\n\nAt least two outside groups are planning to protest Trump's address, set to take place in the early afternoon.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party, was also invited to the convention, but was not able to attend, organizers said. According to NBC 5 Political Reporter Mary Ann Ahern, Harris has made efforts to schedule another meeting with the group.\n\n\"We invite the presidential candidates to come,\" NABJ President Ken Lemon said. \"We extend to anyone who's a nominee, and in this case, we have two presumptive nominees.\"\n\nLemon also said there will be a real-time fact check of the president's remarks, rather than a campaign-style speech.\n\n\"It's our job as journalists to have those uncomfortable conversations, so that the people who count on us to inform them get it from an informed source,\" he said.\n\nTrump last visited Chicago for a 2019 rally, with hundreds of protesters gathering outside Trump Tower in the Loop, dozens of physical altercations in the audience at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and plenty of rancor from the then-president himself, who criticized former Chicago Police Supt. David Brown as a \"disgrace.\"\n\nChicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, a harsh critic of the former president, pledges that the city will be prepared for the visit, but had strong words about Trump's alleged contempt for Chicago.\n\n\"There's no secret that the former president Donald Trump is an abuser,\" he said. \"He was quite cruel to many individuals in the Black press in particular.\"\n\nIllinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker also blasted Trump's visit, saying he has repeatedly insulted Midwestern cities and values.\n\n\"Every time Donald Trump visits the Midwest he tells us how much he hates it,\" he said. \"He called Milwaukee horrible. He called Detroit corrupt. He denigrated Chicago police. His visit to Chicago tomorrow will no doubt be another attempt to distract from his flailing campaign, with as many lies as there are vacancies at Trump Tower.\"\n\nThe appearance from Donald Trump comes weeks away from the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, scheduled for Aug. 19-22.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [],
